  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Adjunction models for call-by-push-value With stacks</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Call-by-push-value is a "semantic machine code", providing a set of simple primitives from which both the call-by-value and call-by-name paradigms are built. We present its operational semantics as a stack machine, suggesting a term judgement of stacks. We then see that CBPV, incorporating these stack terms, has a simple categorical semantics based on an adjunction between values and stacks. There are no coherence requirements.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="185" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="185" filesize="167700" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/6/14-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Abstract Physical Traces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We revise our `Physical Traces' paper in the light of the results in [Abramsky and Coecke LiCS`04]. The key fact is that the notion of a <i>strongly compact closed category</i> allows abstract notions of adjoint, bipartite projector and inner product to be defined, and their key properties to be proved. In this paper we improve on the definition of strong compact closure as compared to the one presented in [Abramsky and Coecke LiCS`04]. This modification enables an elegant characterization of strong compact closure in terms of adjoints and a Yanking axiom, and a better treatment of bipartite projectors.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="176">
        <givenname locale="en">Samson</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Abramsky</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #186:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="186" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="186" filesize="590163" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/7/14-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A MONADIC APPROACH TO POLYCATEGORIES</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In the quest for an elegant formulation of the notion of ``polycategory'' we develop a more symmetric counterpart to Burroni's notion of ``T- category'', where T is a cartesian monad on a category X with pullbacks. Our approach involves two such monads, S and T, that are linked by a suitable generalization of a distributive law in the sense of Beck. This takes the form of a span omega : TS <--> ST in the functor category [X,X] and guarantees essential associativity for a canonical pullback-induced composition of S-T-spans over X, identifying them as the 1-cells of a bicategory, whose (internal) monoids then qualify as ``omega-categories''. In case that S and T both are the free monoid monad on set, we construct an omega utilizing an apparently new classical distributive law linking the free semigroup monad with itself. Our construction then gives rise to so-called ``planar polycategories'', which nowadays seem to be of more intrinsic interest than Szabo's original polycategories. Weakly cartesian monads on X may be accommodated as well by first quotienting the bicategory of X-spans.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>cartesian monad</keyword>
      <keyword>S-T-span</keyword>
      <keyword>(cartesian) distributive law</keyword>
      <keyword>multicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>(planar) polycategory</keyword>
      <keyword>fc-polycategory</keyword>
      <keyword>associative double semigroup</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="178">
        <givenname locale="en">Juergen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Koslowski</familyname>

      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #189:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="189" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-10.pdf</name>
    <file id="189" filesize="238997" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/10/14-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Canonical and op-canonical lax algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The definition of a category of (T,V)-algebras, where V is a unital commutative quantale and T is a Set-monad, requires the existence of a certain lax extension of T. In this article, we present a general construction of such an extension. This leads to the formation of two categories of (T,V)-algebras: the category Alg(T,V) of <i>canonical </i>(T,V)<i>-algebras</i>, and the category Alg(T',V) of <i>op-canonical </i>(T,V)<i>-algebras</i>. The usual topological-like examples of categories of (T,V)-algebras (preordered sets, topological, metric and approach spaces) are obtained in this way, and the category of closure spaces appears as a category of canonical (P,V)-algebras, where P is the powerset monad. This unified presentation allows us to study how these categories are related, and it is shown that under suitable hypotheses both Alg(T,V) and Alg(T',V) embed coreflectively into Alg(P,V).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>V-matrix</keyword>
      <keyword>(T</keyword>
      <keyword>V)-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>ordered set</keyword>
      <keyword>metric space</keyword>
      <keyword>topological space</keyword>
      <keyword>approach space</keyword>
      <keyword>closure space</keyword>
      <keyword>closeness space</keyword>
      <keyword>topological category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #190:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="190" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="190" filesize="326502" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/11/14-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the representability of actions in a semi-abelian category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider a semi-abelian category V and we write Act(G,X) for the set of actions of the object G on the object X, in the sense of the theory of semi-direct products in V. We investigate the representability of the functor Act(-,X) in the case where V is locally presentable, with finite limits commuting with filtered colimits. This contains all categories of models of a semi-abelian theory in a Grothendieck topos, thus in particular all semi-abelian varieties of universal algebra. For such categories, we prove first that the representability of Act(-,X) reduces to the preservation of binary coproducts. Next we give both a very simple necessary condition and a very simple sufficient condition, in terms of amalgamation properties, for the preservation of binary coproducts by the functor Act(-,X) in a general semi-abelian category. Finally, we exhibit the precise form of the more involved ``if and only if'' amalgamation property corresponding to the representability of actions: this condition is in particular related to a new notion of ``normalization of a morphism''. We provide also a wide supply of algebraic examples and counter-examples, giving in particular evidence of the relevance of the object representing Act(-,X), when it turns out to exist.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>semi-abelian category</keyword>
      <keyword>variety</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-direct product</keyword>
      <keyword>action</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="42">
        <givenname locale="en">F.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Borceux</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="31">
        <givenname locale="en">G.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Janelidze</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="32">
        <givenname locale="en">G. M.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kelly</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #193:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="193" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="193" filesize="226050" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/14/14-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Classification of concrete geometrical categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A precise concept of concrete geometrical category is introduced in an axiomatic way. To any algebra L for an many-sorted infinitary algebraic theory <b>T</b> is associated a concrete geometrical category <b>Geo</b>(L), the so-called classifying concrete geometrical category of L, satisfying a universal property. The terminology "geometrical" is justified firstly for <b>Geo</b>(L) and secondly for any concrete geometrical category by proving that they are all classifying ones. The legitimate category <b>CGC</b> of concrete geometrical categories is build up and proved to be the dual of the legitimate category <b>TGC</b> of topological geometrical categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>concrete geometrical category</keyword>
      <keyword>classifying geometrical category</keyword>
      <keyword>topological geometrical category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="185">

        <familyname locale="en">Diers</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #194:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="194" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Localic completion of generalized metric spaces I</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Following Lawvere, a generalized metric space (gms) is a set $X$ equipped with a metric map from $X^{2}$ to the interval of upper reals (approximated from above but not from below) from 0 to $\infty$ inclusive, and satisfying the zero self-distance law and the triangle inequality.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Enlargements of categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In order to apply nonstandard methods to modern algebraic geometry, as a first step in this paper we study the applications of nonstandard constructions to category theory. It turns out that many categorical properties are well behaved under enlargements.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #196:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="196" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">14-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="196" filesize="251416" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/14/17/14-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Notes on enriched categories with colimits of some class</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The paper is in essence a survey of categories having $\phi$-weighted colimits for all the weights $\phi$ in some class $\Phi$. We introduce the class $\Phi^+$ of $\Phi$-<i>flat</i> weights which are those $\psi$ for which $\psi$-colimits commute in the base $\cal V$ with limits having weights in $\Phi$; and the class $\Phi^-$ of $\Phi$-<i>atomic</i> weights, which are those $\psi$ for which $\psi$-limits commute in the base $\cal V$ with colimits having weights in $\Phi$. We show that both these classes are <i>saturated</i> (that is, what was called <i>closed</i> in the terminology of Albert and Kelly). We prove that for the class $\cal P$ of <i>all</i> weights, the classes $\cal P^+$ and $\cal P^-$ both coincide with the class $\Q$ of <i>absolute</i> weights. For any class $\Phi$ and any category $\cal A$, we have the free $\Phi$-cocompletion $\Phi(\cal A)$ of $\cal A$; and we recognize $\cal Q(\cal A)$ as the Cauchy-completion of $\cal A$. We study the equivalence between ${(\cal Q(\cal A^{op}))}^{op}$ and $\cal Q(\cal A)$, which we exhibit as the restriction of the Isbell adjunction between ${[\cal A,\cal V]}^{op}$ and $[\cal A^{op},\cal V]$ when $\cal A$ is small; and we give a new Morita theorem for any class $\Phi$ containing $\cal Q$. We end with the study of $\Phi$-continuous weights and their relation to the $\Phi$-flat weights.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>limits</keyword>
      <keyword>colimits</keyword>
      <keyword>flat</keyword>
      <keyword>atomic</keyword>
      <keyword>small presentable</keyword>
      <keyword>Cauchy completion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="32">
        <givenname locale="en">G. M.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kelly</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="188">
        <givenname locale="en">V.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Schmitt</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="196"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>14</volume>
      <year>2005</year>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Birkhoff's Variety Theorem With and Without Free Algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For large signatures $\Sigma$ we prove that Birkhoff's Variety Theorem holds (i.e., equationally presentable collections of $\Sigma$-algebras are precisely those closed under limits, subalgebras, and quotient algebras) iff the universe of small sets is not measurable. Under that limitation Birkhoff's Variety Theorem holds in fact for $F$-algebras of an arbitrary endofunctor $F$ of the category <b>Class</b> of classes and functions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>variety</keyword>
      <keyword>Birkhoff s Theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="15">
        <givenname locale="en">Jiri</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Adamek</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">Trnkova</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #198:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Generalized Brown representability in homotopy categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Brown representability approximates the homotopy category of spectra by means of cohomology functors defined on finite spectra. We will show that if a model category $\cal K$ is suitably determined by $\lambda$-small objects then its homotopy category $Ho(\cal K)$ is approximated by cohomology functors defined on those $\lambda$-small objects. In the case of simplicial sets, we have $\lambda = \omega_1$, i.e., $\lambda$-small means countable.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2005</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quillen model category</keyword>
      <keyword>Brown representability</keyword>
      <keyword>triangulated category</keyword>
      <keyword>accessible category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="16">

        <familyname locale="en">Rosicky</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #199:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="199" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">15-01.pdf</name>
    <file id="199" filesize="317937" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/1/15-01.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Predicative algebraic set theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper the machinery and results developed in [Awodey et al., 2004] are extended to the study of constructive set theories. Specifically, we introduce two constructive set theories <b>BCST</b> and <b>CST</b> and prove that they are sound and complete with respect to models in categories with certain structure. Specifically, <i>basic categories of classes</i> and <i>categories of classes</i> are axiomatized and shown to provide models of the aforementioned set theories. Finally, models of these theories are constructed in the category of <i>ideals</i>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2004</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>algebraic set theory</keyword>
      <keyword>categorical logic</keyword>
      <keyword>predicativity</keyword>
      <keyword>ideal completion</keyword>
      <keyword>dependent type theory</keyword>
      <keyword>$\Pi$-pretopos</keyword>
      <keyword>small maps</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="200" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <file id="200" filesize="250792" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/2/15-02.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Reflective Kleisli subcategories of the category of Eilenberg-Moore algebras for factorization monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is well known that for any monad, the associated Kleisli category is embedded in the category of Eilenberg-Moore algebras as the free ones. We discovered some interesting examples in which this embedding is reflective; that is, it has a left adjoint. To understand this phenomenon we introduce and study a class of monads arising from factorization systems, and thereby termed factorization monads. For them we show that under some simple conditions on the factorization system the free algebras are a full reflective subcategory of the algebras. We provide various examples of this situation of a combinatorial nature.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2004</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>factorization systems</keyword>
      <keyword>monads</keyword>
      <keyword>Kleisli categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Schanuel topos</keyword>
      <keyword>Joyal species</keyword>
      <keyword>combinatorial structures</keyword>
      <keyword>power series</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Model structures for homotopy of internal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The aim of this paper is to describe Quillen model category structures on the category CatC of internal categories and functors in a given finitely complete category C. Several non-equivalent notions of internal equivalence exist; to capture these notions, the model structures are defined relative to a given Grothendieck topology on C.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #202:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="202" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">15-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="202" filesize="462296" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/4/15-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The shape of a category up to directed homotopy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This work is a contribution to a recent field, Directed Algebraic Topology. Categories which appear as fundamental categories of `directed structures', e.g. ordered topological spaces, have to be studied up to appropriate notions of <i>directed homotopy equivalence</i>, which are more general than ordinary equivalence of categories. Here we introduce <i> past</i> and <i> future equivalences </i> of categories - sort of symmetric versions of an adjunction - and use them and their combinations to get `directed models' of a category; in the simplest case, these are the join of the <i>least full reflective</i> and the <i>least full coreflective</i> subcategory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2004</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>omotopy theory</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunctions</keyword>
      <keyword>reflective subcategories</keyword>
      <keyword>directed algebraic topology</keyword>
      <keyword>fundamental category</keyword>
      <keyword>concurrent processes</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="96">
        <givenname locale="en">Marco</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Grandis</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #203:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="203" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">15-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="203" filesize="186110" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/5/15-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Algebraic Models of Intuitionistic Theories of Sets and Classes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper constructs models of intuitionistic set theory in suitable categories. First, a Basic Intuitionistic Set Theory (BIST) is stated, and the categorical semantics are given. Second, we give a notion of an <i>ideal</i> over a category, using which one can build a model of BIST in which a given topos occurs as the sets. And third, a sheaf model is given of a Basic Intuitionistic Class Theory conservatively extending BIST. The paper extends the results in Awodey, Butz, Simpson and Streicher (2003) by introducing a new and perhaps more natural notion of ideal, and in the class theory of part three.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2004</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>algebraic set theory</keyword>
      <keyword>topos theory</keyword>
      <keyword>sheaf theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="194">

FILE #204:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="204" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">15-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="204" filesize="176827" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/6/15-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Generic commutative separable algebras and cospans of graphs</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the generic symmetric monoidal category with a commutative separable algebra which has a $\Sigma$-family of actions is the category of cospans of finite $\Sigma$-labelled graphs restricted to finite sets as objects, thus providing a syntax for automata on the alphabet $\Sigma$. We use this result to produce semantic functors for $\Sigma$-automata.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #205:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="205" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">15-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="205" filesize="182801" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/15/7/15-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Galois theory with stable units for simplicial sets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We recall and reformulate certain known constructions, in order to make a convenient setting for obtaining generalized monotone-light factorizations in the sense of A. Carboni, G. Janelidze, G. M. Kelly and R. Par&eacute;. This setting is used to study the existence of monotone-light factorizations both in categories of simplicial objects and in categories of internal categories. It is shown that there is a non-trivial monotone-light factorization for simplicial sets, such that the monotone-light factorization for reflexive graphs via reflexive relations is a special case of it, obtained by truncation. More generally, we will show that there exists a monotone-light factorization associated with every full subcategory <i>Mono(F_n)</i>, <i>n >= 0</i>, consisting of all simplicial sets whose unit morphisms are monic for the localization $F_n:\mathbf{Set}^{\Delta^{op}}\rightarrow\mathbf{Set}^{\Delta^{op}_n}$, which truncates each simplicial set after the object of n-simplices. The monotone-light factorization for categories via preorders is as well derived from the proposed setting. We also show that, for regular Mal'cev categories, the reflection of internal groupoids into internal equivalence relations necessarily produces monotone-light factorizations. It turns out that all these reflections do have stable units, in the sense of C. Cassidy, M. H&eacute;bert and G. M. Kelly, giving rise to Galois theories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2004</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>simplicial object</keyword>
      <keyword>simplicial set</keyword>
      <keyword>internal category</keyword>
      <keyword>internal preorder</keyword>
      <keyword>regular category</keyword>
      <keyword>Mal cev category</keyword>
      <keyword>descent theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Galois theory</keyword>
      <keyword>reflection with stable units</keyword>
      <keyword>monotone-light factorization</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan extension</keyword>
      <keyword>elementary topos</keyword>
      <keyword>geometric morphism</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="206" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-01.pdf</name>
    <file id="206" filesize="344941" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/1/16-01.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monads of effective descent type and comonadicity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show, for an arbitrary adjunction $F \dashv U : \cal B \to \cal A$ with $\cal B$ Cauchy complete, that the functor $F$ is comonadic if and only if the monad $T$ on $\cal A$ induced by the adjunction is of effective descent type, meaning that the free $T$-algebra functor $F^{T}: \cal A \to \cal A^{T}$ is comonadic. This result is applied to several situations: In Section 4 to give a sufficient condition for an exponential functor on a cartesian closed category to be monadic, in Sections 5 and 6 to settle the question of the comonadicity of those functors whose domain is <b>Set</b>, or <b>Set</b>$_{\star}$, or the category of modules over a semisimple ring, in Section 7 to study the effectiveness of (co)monads on module categories. Our final application is a descent theorem for noncommutative rings from which we deduce an important result of A. Joyal and M. Tierney and of J.-P. Olivier, asserting that the effective descent morphisms in the opposite of the category of commutative unital rings are precisely the pure monomorphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Monad of effective descent type</keyword>
      <keyword>(co)monadicity</keyword>
      <keyword>separable functor</keyword>
      <keyword>coring</keyword>
      <keyword>descent data</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Action groupoid in protomodular categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give here some examples of non pointed protomodular categories $\mathbb C$ satisfying a property similar to the property of representation of actions which holds for the pointed protomodular category $Gp$ of groups: any slice category of $Gp$, any category of groupoids with a fixed set of objects, any essentially affine category. This property gives rise to an internal construction of the center of any object $X$, and consequently to a specific characterization of the abelian objects in $\mathbb C$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #208:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="208" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-03.pdf</name>
    <file id="208" filesize="237083" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/3/16-03.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Inverting weak dihomotopy equivalence using homotopy continuous flow</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A flow is homotopy continuous if it is indefinitely divisible up to S-homotopy. The full subcategory of cofibrant homotopy continuous flows has nice features. Not only it is big enough to contain all dihomotopy types, but also a morphism between them is a weak dihomotopy equivalence if and only if it is invertible up to dihomotopy. Thus, the category of cofibrant homotopy continuous flows provides an implementation of Whitehead's theorem for the full dihomotopy relation, and not only for S-homotopy as in previous works of the author. This fact is not the consequence of the existence of a model structure on the category of flows because it is known that there does not exist any model structure on it whose weak equivalences are exactly the weak dihomotopy equivalences. This fact is an application of a general result for the localization of a model category with respect to a weak factorization system.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>concurrency</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy</keyword>
      <keyword>Whitehead theorem</keyword>
      <keyword>directed homotopy</keyword>
      <keyword>weak factorization system</keyword>
      <keyword>model category</keyword>
      <keyword>localization</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="100">
        <givenname locale="en">Philippe</givenname>

        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #209:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="209" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="209" filesize="503640" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/4/16-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Frobenius algebras and ambidextrous adjunctions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we explain the relationship between Frobenius objects in monoidal categories and adjunctions in 2-categories. Specifically, we show that every Frobenius object in a monoidal category $M$ arises from an ambijunction (simultaneous left and right adjoints) in some 2-category $\mathcal{D}$ into which $M$ fully and faithfully embeds. Since a 2D topological quantum field theory is equivalent to a commutative Frobenius algebra, this result also shows that every 2D TQFT is obtained from an ambijunction in some 2-category. Our theorem is proved by extending the theory of adjoint monads to the context of an arbitrary 2-category and utilizing the free completion under Eilenberg-Moore objects. We then categorify this theorem by replacing the monoidal category $M$ with a semistrict monoidal 2-category $M$, and replacing the 2-category $\mathcal{D}$ into which it embeds by a semistrict 3-category. To state this more powerful result, we must first define the notion of a `Frobenius pseudomonoid', which categorifies that of a Frobenius object. We then define the notion of a `pseudo ambijunction', categorifying that of an ambijunction. In each case, the idea is that all the usual axioms now hold only up to coherent isomorphism. Finally, we show that every Frobenius pseudomonoid in a semistrict monoidal 2-category arises from a pseudo ambijunction in some semistrict 3-category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>pseudoadjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>pseudomonad</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius pseudomonoid</keyword>
      <keyword>Eilenberg-Moore completion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="161">
        <givenname locale="en">Aaron D.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lauda</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="209"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>16</volume>
      <year>2006</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>84-122</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #210:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="210" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="210" filesize="99426" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/5/16-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Every Grothendieck topos has a one-way site</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Lawvere has urged a project of characterizing <i>petit</i> toposes which have the character of generalized spaces and <i>gros</i> toposes which have the character of categories of spaces. Etendues and locally decidable toposes are seemingly petit and have a natural common generalization in sites with all idempotents identities. This note shows every Grothendieck topos has such a site. More, it defines <i>slanted products</i> which take any site to an equivalent <i>one way</i> site, a site where all endomorphisms are identities. On the other hand subcanonical one-way sites are very special. A site criterion for petit toposes will probably require subcanonical sites.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Grothendieck topos</keyword>
      <keyword>petit topos</keyword>
      <keyword>locale</keyword>
      <keyword>one way site</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="199">
        <givenname locale="en">Colin</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">McLarty</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Points of affine categories and additivity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A category <b>C</b> is additive if and only if, for every object <i>B</i> of <b>C</b>, the category Pt(<b>C</b>,<i>B</i>) of pointed objects in the comma category (<b>C</b>,<i>B</i>) is canonically equivalent to <b>C</b>. We reformulate the proof of this known result in order to obtain a stronger one that uses not all objects of <i>B</i> of <b>C</b>, but only a conveniently defined generating class <b>S</b>. If <b>C</b> is a variety of universal algebras, then one can take <b>S</b> to be the class consisting of any single free algebra on a non-empty set.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Algebraic categories</keyword>
      <keyword>affine spaces</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We raise the question of saying what it means for a functor between abelian categories to preserve homology. We give a kind of answer and explore the reasons it is unsatisfactory in general (although fine for left or right exact functors).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #213:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="213" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="213" filesize="242541" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/8/16-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Thin fillers in the cubical nerves of omega-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is shown that the cubical nerve of a strict omega-category is a sequence of sets with cubical face operations and distinguished subclasses of thin elements satisfying certain thin filler conditions. It is also shown that a sequence of this type is the cubical nerve of a strict omega-category unique up to isomorphism; the cubical nerve functor is therefore an equivalence of categories. The sequences of sets involved are the analogues of cubical T-complexes appropriate for strict omega-categories. Degeneracies are not required in the definition of these sequences, but can in fact be constructed as thin fillers. The proof of the thin filler conditions uses chain complexes and chain homotopies.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>omega-category</keyword>
      <keyword>cubical nerve</keyword>
      <keyword>stratified precubical set</keyword>
      <keyword>cubical T-complex</keyword>
      <keyword>thin filler</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="40">
        <givenname locale="en">Richard</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Steiner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <title locale="en">Free A_\infty-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a differential graded k-quiver Q we define the free A_\infty-category FQ generated by Q. The main result is that the restriction A_\infty-functor A_\infty(FQ, A) \to A_1(Q,A) is an equivalence, where objects of the last A_\infty-category are morphisms of differential graded k-quivers Q \to A.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">A characterization of quantic quantifiers in orthomodular lattices</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let <i>L</i> be an arbitrary orthomodular lattice. There is a one to one correspondence between orthomodular sublattices of <i>L</i> satisfying an extra condition and quantic quantifiers. The category of orthomodular lattices is equivalent to the category of posets having two families of endofunctors satisfying six conditions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Exponentiability in Lax Slices of <b>Top</b></title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider exponentiable objects in lax slices of <b>Top</b> with respect to the specialization order (and its opposite) on a base space <i>B</i>. We begin by showing that the lax slice over <i>B</i> has binary products which are preserved by the forgetful functor to <b>Top</b> if and only if <i>B</i> is a meet (respective, join) semilattice in <b>Top</b>, and go on to characterize exponentiability over a complete Alexandrov space <i>B</i>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Closedness properties of internal relations I: A unified approach to Mal'tsev, unital and subtractive categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study <i>closedness properties</i> of internal relations in finitely complete categories, which leads to developing a unified approach to: Mal'tsev categories, in the sense of A. Carboni, J. Lambek and M. C. Pedicchio, that generalize Mal'tsev varieties of universal algebras; unital categories, in the sense of D. Bourn, that generalize pointed J&oacute;nsson-Tarski varieties; and subtractive categories, introduced by the author, that generalize pointed subtractive varieties in the sense of A. Ursini.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #218:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="218" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="218" filesize="200110" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/13/16-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Closedness properties of internal relations II: Bourn localization</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We say that a class $\mathbb{D}$ of categories is the <i>Bourn localization</i> of a class $\mathbb{C}$ of categories, and we write $\mathbb{D} = \mathrm{Loc}\mathbb{C}$, if $\mathbb{D}$ is the class of all (finitely complete) categories $\mathcal{D}$ such that for each object $A$ in $\mathcal{D}$, $\mathrm{Pt}(\mathcal{D}\downarrow A) \in \mathbb{C}$, where $\mathrm{Pt}(\mathcal{D}\downarrow A)$ denotes the category of all pointed objects in the comma-category $(\mathcal{D}\downarrow A)$. As D. Bourn showed, if we take $\mathbb{D}$ to be the class of Mal'tsev categories in the sense of A. Carboni, J. Lambek, and M. C. Pedicchio, and $\mathbb{C}$ to be the class of unital categories in the sense of D. Bourn, which generalize pointed J&oacute;nsson-Tarski varieties, then $\mathbb{D} = \mathrm{Loc}(\mathbb{C})$. A similar result was obtained by the author: if $\mathbb{D}$ is as above and $\mathbb{C}$ is the class of subtractive categories, which generalize pointed subtractive varieties in the sense of A. Ursini, then $\mathbb{D} = \mathrm{Loc}(\mathbb{C})$. In the present paper we extend these results to abstract classes of categories obtained from classes of varieties. We also show that the Bourn localization of the union of the classes of unital and subtractive categories is still the class of Mal'tsev categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Mal tsev</keyword>
      <keyword>unital and subtractive categories</keyword>
      <keyword>fibration of points</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="142">
        <givenname locale="en">Zurab</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Janelidze</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="218"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>16</volume>
      <year>2006</year>

    <pages>262-282</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #219:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="219" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="219" filesize="290822" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/14/16-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categorical structures enriched in a quantaloid: tensored and cotensored categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A quantaloid is a sup-lattice-enriched category; our subject is that of categories, functors and distributors enriched in a base quantaloid $\mathcal{Q}$. We show how cocomplete $\mathcal{Q}$-categories are precisely those which are tensored and conically cocomplete, or alternatively, those which are tensored, cotensored and `order-cocomplete'. In fact, tensors and cotensors in a $\mathcal{Q}$-category determine, and are determined by, certain adjunctions in the category of $\mathcal{Q}$-categories; some of these adjunctions can be reduced to adjuctions in the category of ordered sets. Bearing this in mind, we explain how tensored $\mathcal{Q}$-categories are equivalent to order-valued closed pseudofunctors on $\mathcal{Q}^{op}$; this result is then finetuned to obtain in particular that cocomplete $\mathcal{Q}$-categories are equivalent to sup-lattice-valued homomorphisms on $\mathcal{Q}^{op}$ (a.k.a.\ $\mathcal{Q}$-modules).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>quantaloid</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>weighted (co)limit</keyword>
      <keyword>module</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="172">
        <givenname locale="en">Isar</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Stubbe</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <title locale="en">Stable meet semilattice fibrations and free restriction categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The construction of a free restriction category can be broken into two steps: the construction of a free stable semilattice fibration followed by the construction of a free restriction category for this fibration. Restriction categories produced from such fibrations are `unitary', in a sense which generalizes that from the theory of inverse semigroups. Characterization theorems for unitary restriction categories are derived. The paper ends with an explicit description of the free restriction category on a directed graph.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">TFT CONSTRUCTION OF RCFT CORRELATORS V: PROOF OF MODULAR INVARIANCE AND FACTORISATION</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The correlators of two-dimensional rational conformal field theories that are obtained in the TFT construction of Fuchs, Runkel and Schweigert are shown to be invariant under the action of the relative modular group and to obey bulk and boundary factorisation constraints. We present results both for conformal field theories defined on oriented surfaces and for theories defined on unoriented surfaces. In the latter case, in particular the so-called cross cap constraint is included.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #222:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="222" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="222" filesize="265806" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/17/16-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Spectra of finitely generated boolean flows</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A <b>flow</b> on a compact Hausdorff space <i>X</i> is given by a map <i> t : X --> X</i>. The general goal of this paper is to find the "cyclic parts" of such a flow. To do this, we approximate <i>(X,t)</i> by a flow on a Stone space (that is, a totally disconnected, compact Hausdorff space). Such a flow can be examined by analyzing the resulting flow on the Boolean algebra of clopen subsets, using the spectrum defined in our previous TAC paper, The cyclic spectrum of a Boolean flow. In this paper, we describe the cyclic spectrum in terms that do not rely on topos theory. We then compute the cyclic spectrum of any finitely generated Boolean flow. We define when a sheaf of Boolean flows can be regarded as cyclic and find necessary conditions for representing a Boolean flow using the global sections of such a sheaf. In the final section, we define and explore a related spectrum based on minimal subflows of Stone spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Boolean flow</keyword>
      <keyword>dynamical systems</keyword>
      <keyword>spectrum</keyword>
      <keyword>sheaf</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="84">
        <givenname locale="en">John F.</givenname>

FILE #223:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="223" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-18.pdf</name>
    <file id="223" filesize="485836" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/18/16-18.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Paths in double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Two constructions of paths in double categories are studied, providing algebraic versions of the homotopy groupoid of a space. Universal properties of these constructions are presented. The first is seen as the codomain of the universal oplax morphism of double categories and the second, which is a quotient of the first, gives the universal normal oplax morphism. Normality forces an equivalence relation on cells, a special case of which was seen before in the free adjoint construction. These constructions are the object part of 2-comonads which are shown to be oplax idempotent. The coalgebras for these comonads turn out to be Leinster's <b>fc</b>-multicategories, with representable identities in the second case.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>double categories</keyword>
      <keyword>oplax double categories</keyword>
      <keyword>paths</keyword>
      <keyword>localisation</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="163">

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Numerology in topoi</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper studies numerals, natural numbers objects and, more generally, free actions, in a topos. A <i>pre-numeral</i> is a poset with a constant, 0, and a unary operation, <i>s</i>, such that:<br> <i>x\leq y implies sx \leq sy</i><br> <i>x\leq sx</i><br> A <i>numeral</i> is a minimal pre-numeral.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">Categorical representations of categorical groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A representation theory for (strict) categorical groups is constructed. Each categorical group determines a monoidal bicategory of representations. Typically, these bicategories contain representations which are indecomposable but not irreducible. A simple example is computed in explicit detail.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #226:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="226" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-21.pdf</name>
    <file id="226" filesize="299035" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/21/16-21.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Compactifications, C(X) and ring epimorphisms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a topological space $X$, $K(X)$ denotes the upper semi-lattice of its (Hausdorff) compactifications. Recent studies have asked when, for $\alpha X \in K(X)$, the restriction homomorphism $\rho : C(\alpha X) \to C(X)$ is an epimorphism in the category of commutative rings. This article continues this study by examining the sub-semilattice, $K_{epi}(X)$, of those compactifications where $\rho$ is an epimorphism along with two of its subsets, and its complement $K_{nepi}(X)$. The role of $K_z(X)\subseteq K(X)$ of those $\alpha X$ where $X$ is $z$-embedded in $\alpha X$, is also examined. The cases where $X$ is a $P$-space and, more particularly, where $X$ is discrete, receive special attention.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>epimorphism</keyword>
      <keyword>ring of continuous functions</keyword>
      <keyword>category of rings</keyword>
      <keyword>compactifications</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="144">
        <givenname locale="en">W. D.</givenname>

FILE #227:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="227" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="227" filesize="382054" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/22/16-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On categorical crossed modules</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The well-known notion of crossed module of groups is raised in this paper to the categorical level supported by the theory of categorical groups. We construct the cokernel of a categorical crossed module and we establish the universal property of this categorical group. We also prove a suitable 2-dimensional version of the kernel-cokernel lemma for a diagram of categorical crossed modules. We then study derivations with coefficients in categorical crossed modules and show the existence of a categorical crossed module given by inner derivations. This allows us to define the low-dimensional cohomology categorical groups and, finally, these invariants are connected by a six-term 2-exact sequence obtained by using the kernel-cokernel lemma.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>crossed module</keyword>
      <keyword>categorical group</keyword>
      <keyword>categorical crossed module</keyword>
      <keyword>derivation</keyword>
      <keyword>2-exact sequence</keyword>
      <keyword>cohomology categorical group</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Equivalence of 2D-multitopic category and ana-bicategory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper equivalence of the concepts of ana-bicategory and the 2D-multitopic category is proved. The equivalence is FOLDS equivalence of the FOLDS-Specifications of the two concepts. Two constructions for transforming one form of category to another are given and it is shown that we get a structure equivalent to the original one when we compose the two constructions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #229:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="229" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-24.pdf</name>
    <file id="229" filesize="343065" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/24/16-24.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Descent for Monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Motivated by a desire to gain a better understanding of the ``dimension-by-dimension'' decompositions of certain prominent monads in higher category theory, we investigate descent theory for endofunctors and monads. After setting up a basic framework of indexed monoidal categories, we describe a suitable subcategory of Cat over which we can view the assignment C |-> Mnd(C) as an indexed category; on this base category, there is a natural topology. Then we single out a class of monads which are well-behaved with respect to reindexing. The main result is now, that such monads form a stack. Using this, we can shed some light on the free strict $\omega$-category monad on globular sets and the free operad-with-contraction monad on the category of collections.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Descent theory</keyword>
      <keyword>monads</keyword>
      <keyword>globular sets</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="213">

    <title locale="en">Topological *-autonomous categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given an additive equational category with a closed symmetric monoidal structure and a potential dualizing object, we find sufficient conditions that the category of topological objects over that category has a good notion of full subcategories of strong and weakly topologized objects and show that each is equivalent to the chu category of the original category with respect to the dualizing object.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #231:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="231" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-26.pdf</name>
    <file id="231" filesize="284544" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/26/16-26.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Quotient models of a category up to directed homotopy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Directed Algebraic Topology is a recent field, deeply linked with ordinary and higher dimensional Category Theory. A `directed space', e.g. an ordered topological space, has directed homotopies (which are generally non reversible) and a fundamental <i>category</i> (replacing the fundamental groupoid of the classical case). Finding a simple - possibly finite - model of the latter is a non-trivial problem, whose solution gives relevant information on the given `space'; a problem which is of interest for applications as well as in general Category Theory. Here we continue the work ``The shape of a category up to directed homotopy", with a deeper analysis of `surjective models', motivated by studying the singularities of 3-dimensional ordered spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>homotopy theory</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunctions</keyword>
      <keyword>reflective subcategories</keyword>
      <keyword>directed algebraic topology</keyword>
      <keyword>fundamental category</keyword>
      <keyword>concurrent processes</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="96">
        <givenname locale="en">Marco</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Grandis</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="231"/>

FILE #232:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="232" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-27.pdf</name>
    <file id="232" filesize="715090" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/27/16-27.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categories of components and loop-free categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a groupoid G one has, in addition to the equivalence of categories E from G to its skeleton, a fibration F from G to its set of connected components (seen as a discrete category). From the observation that E and F differ unless G[x,x]=id_x for every object x of G, we prove there is a fibered equivalence from C[\Sigma^{-1}] to C/\Sigma when \Sigma is a <i>Yoneda</i>-system of a loop-free category C. In fact, all the equivalences from C[\Sigma^{-1}]$ to C/\Sigma are fibered. Furthermore, since the quotient C/\Sigma shrinks as \Sigma grows, we define the component category of a loop-free category as C/{\overline{\Sigma}} where \overline{\Sigma} is the greatest <i>Yoneda</i>-system of C.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>category of fractions</keyword>
      <keyword>generalized congruence</keyword>
      <keyword>quotient category</keyword>
      <keyword>scwol</keyword>
      <keyword>small category without loop</keyword>
      <keyword>Yoneda-morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>Yoneda-system</keyword>
      <keyword>concurrency</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="215">
        <givenname locale="en">Emmanuel</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Haucourt</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="233" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-29.pdf</name>
    <file id="233" filesize="619032" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/29/16-29.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categorified Algebra and Quantum Mechanics</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The process some call `categorification' consists of interpreting set-theoretic structures in mathematics as derived from category-theoretic structures. Examples include the interpretation of N as the Burnside rig of the category of finite sets with product and coproduct, and of N[x] in terms the category of combinatorial species. This has interesting applications to quantum mechanics, and in particular the quantum harmonic oscillator, via Joyal's `combinatorial species', and a new generalization called `stuff types' described by Baez and Dolan, which are a special case of Kelly's `clubs'. Operators between stuff types be represented as rudimentary Feynman diagrams for the oscillator. In quantum mechanics, we want to represent states in an algebra over the complex numbers, and also want our Feynman diagrams to carry more structure than these `stuff operators' can do, and these turn out to be closely related. We will describe a categorification of the quantum harmonic oscillator in which the group of `phases' - that is, U(1), the circle group - plays a special role. We describe a general notion of `M-stuff types' for any monoid M, and see that the case M = U(1) provides an interpretation of time evolution in the combinatorial setting, as well as recovering the usual Feynman rules for the quantum harmonic oscillator.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>permutation representations</keyword>
      <keyword>limits and colimits</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>Mackey functors</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="216">
        <givenname locale="en">Jeffrey</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Morton</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="233"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>16</volume>
      <year>2006</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>785-854</pages>
  </publication>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="234" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-30.pdf</name>
    <file id="234" filesize="355954" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/30/16-30.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A cohomological description of connections and curvature over posets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;What remains of a geometrical notion like that of a principal bundle when the base space is not a manifold but a coarse graining of it, like the poset formed by a base for the topology ordered under inclusion? Motivated by the search for a geometrical framework for developing gauge theories in algebraic quantum field theory, we give, in the present paper, a first answer to this question. The notions of transition function, connection form and curvature form find a nice description in terms of cohomology, in general non-Abelian, of a poset with values in a group G. Interpreting a 1-cocycle as a principal bundle, a connection turns out to be a 1-cochain associated in a suitable way with this 1-cocycle; the curvature of a connection turns out to be its 2-coboundary. We show the existence of nonflat connections, and relate flat connections to homomorphisms of the fundamental group of the poset into G. We discuss holonomy and prove an analogue of the Ambrose-Singer theorem.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>permutation representations</keyword>
      <keyword>limits and colimits</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>Mackey functors</keyword>
    </keywords>

      </author>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="235" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">16-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="235" filesize="309704" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/16/31/16-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Generating families in a topos</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A <i> generating family,</i> in a category C is a collection of objects $\{A_i|i\in I\}$ such that if for any subobject Y >--> X, every $f: A_i \rightarrow X$ factors through m, then m is an isomorphism - i.e. the functors $C(A_i, - )$ are collectively conservative. In this paper, we examine some circumstances under which subobjects of 1 form a generating family. Objects for which subobjects of 1 do form a generating family are called <i>partially well-pointed</i>. For a Grothendieck topos, it is well known that subobjects of 1 form a generating family if and only if the topos is localic. For the elementary case, little more is known. The problem is studied by Borceux, where it is shown that the result is internally true, an equivalent condition is found in the boolean case, and certain preservation properties are shown. We look at two different approaches to the problem, one based on a generalization of projectivity, and the other based on looking at the most extreme sorts of counterexamples.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Topoi</keyword>
      <keyword>generating families</keyword>
      <keyword>cogenerators</keyword>
      <keyword>semiprojective objects</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="219">
        <givenname locale="en">Toby</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kenney</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Copower objects and their applications to finiteness in topoi</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we examine a new approach to topos theory - rather than considering subobjects, look at quotients. This leads to the notion of a copower object, which is the object of quotients of a given object. We study some properties of copower objects, many of which are similar to the properties of power objects. Given enough categorical structure (i.e. in a pretopos) it is possible to get power objects from copower objects, and vice versa.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
