    <title locale="en">Coherence of the Double Involution on *-Autonomous Categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that any free *-autonomous category is equivalent (in a strict sense) to a free *-autonomous category in which the double-involution $(-)^{**}$ is the identity functor and the canonical isomorphism $A\simeq A^{**}$ is an identity arrow for all $A$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">A Parigot-style linear $\lambda$-calculus for full intuitionistic linear logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper describes a natural deduction formulation for Full Intuitionistic Linear Logic (FILL), an intriguing variation of multiplicative linear logic, due to Hyland and de Paiva. The system FILL resembles intuitionistic logic, in that all its connectives are independent, but resembles classical logic in that its sequent-calculus formulation has intrinsic multiple conclusions. From the intrinsic multiple conclusions comes the inspiration to modify Parigot's natural deduction systems for classical logic, to produce a natural deduction formulation and a term assignment system for FILL.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="240" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">17-04.pdf</name>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Dialectica interpretation of first-order classical affine logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give a Dialectica-style interpretation of first-order classical affine logic. By moving to a contraction-free logic, the translation (a.k.a. D-translation) of a first-order formula into a higher-type $\exists\forall$-formula can be made symmetric with respect to duality, including exponentials. It turned out that the propositional part of our D-translation uses the same construction as de Paiva's dialectica category GC and we show how our D-translation extends GC to the first-order setting in terms of an indexed category. Furthermore the combination of Girard's ?!-translation and our D-translation results in the essentially equivalent $\exists\forall$-formulas as the double-negation translation and Godel's original D-translation.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #241:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="241" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">17-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="241" filesize="235021" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/17/5/17-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Approximable Concepts, Chu spaces, and information systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper serves to bring three independent but important areas of computer science to a common meeting point: Formal Concept Analysis (FCA), Chu Spaces, and Domain Theory (DT). Each area is given a perspective or reformulation that is conducive to the flow of ideas and to the exploration of cross-disciplinary connections. Among other results, we show that the notion of state in Scott's information system corresponds precisely to that of formal concepts in FCA with respect to all finite Chu spaces, and the entailment relation corresponds to ``association rules". We introduce, moreover, the notion of <i>approximable concept</i> and show that approximable concepts represent algebraic lattices which are identical to Scott domains except the inclusion of a top element. This notion serves as a stepping stone in recent work in which a new notion of morphism on formal contexts results in a category equivalent to (a) the category of complete algebraic lattices and Scott continuous functions, and (b) a category of information systems and approximable mappings.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Formal concept analysis</keyword>
      <keyword>domain theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Chu spaces</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="224">
        <givenname locale="en">Guo-Qiang</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Zhang</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #242:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="242" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">17-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="242" filesize="341381" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/17/6/17-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">An extended view of the Chu-construction</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The cyclic Chu-construction for closed bicategories with pullbacks, which generalizes the original Chu-construction for symmetric monoidal closed categories, turns out to have a non-cyclic counterpart. Both use so-called Chu-spans as new 1-cells between 1-cells of the underlying bicategory, which form the new objects. Chu-spans may be seen as a natural generalization of 2-cell-spans in the base bicategory that no longer are confined to a single hom-category. This view helps to clarify the composition of Chu-spans. <p> We consider various approaches of linking the underlying bicategory with the newly constructed ones, e.g. by means of two-dimensional generalizations of bifibrations. In the quest for a better connection, we investigate, whether Chu-spans form a double category. While this turns out not to be the case, we are led to considering a generalization of the construction to paths of 1-cells in the base, leading to two hierarchies of closed bicategories, one for linear paths and one for loops. The possibility of moving beyond paths, respectively, loops of the same length is indicated. <p> Finally, Chu-spans in <i>rel</i> are identified as bipartite state transition systems. Even though their composition may fail here due to the lack of pullbacks in <i>rel</i>, basic game-theoretic constructions can be performed on cyclic Chu-spans. These are available in all symmetric monoidal closed categories with finite products. If pullbacks exist as well, the bicategory of cyclic Chu-spans inherits a monoidal structure that on objects coincides with the categorical product.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>closed bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>Chu-spans</keyword>
      <keyword>games</keyword>
      <keyword>bipartite state transition systems</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="34">
        <givenname locale="en">Jurgen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Koslowski</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="242"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>17</volume>
      <year>2006</year>
      <title locale="en">Chu spaces</title>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>103-126</pages>
  </publication>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Dialectica and Chu Constructions: Cousins?</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This note investigates two generic constructions used to produce categorical models of linear logic, the Chu construction and the Dialectica construction, in parallel. The constructions have the same objects, but are rather different in other ways. We discuss similarities and differences and prove that the Dialectica construction can be done over a symmetric monoidal closed basis. We also point out interesting open problems concerning the Dialectica construction.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2006</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Bicat is not triequivalent to Gray</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Bicat is the tricategory of bicategories, homomorphisms, pseudonatural transformations, and modifications. Gray is the subtricategory of 2-categories, 2-functors, pseudonatural transformations, and modifications. We show that these two tricategories are not triequivalent.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Polarized category theory, modules, and game semantics</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Motivated by an analysis of Abramsky-Jagadeesan games, the paper considers a categorical semantics for a polarized notion of two-player games, a semantics which has close connections with the logic of (finite cartesian) sums and products, as well as with the multiplicative structure of linear logic. In each case, the structure is polarized, in the sense that it will be modelled by two categories, one for each of two polarities, with a module structure connecting them. These are studied in considerable detail, and a comparison is made with a different notion of polarization due to Olivier Laurent: there is an adjoint connection between the two notions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>polarized categories</keyword>
      <keyword>polarized linear logic</keyword>
      <keyword>game semantics</keyword>
      <keyword>theory of communication</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Functional analysis on normed spaces: the Banach space comparison</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is the aim of this paper to compute the category of Eilenberg-Moore algebras for the monad arising from the dual unit-ball functor on the category of (semi)normed spaces. FILE #247:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="247" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="247" filesize="317767" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/4/18-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On Yetter's Invariant and an Extension of the Dijkgraaf-Witten Invariant to Categorical Groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give an interpretation of Yetter's Invariant of manifolds <i>M</i> in terms of the homotopy type of the function space TOP(<i>M,B(\cal G)</i>)$, where <i>\cal G</i> is a crossed module and <i>B(\cal G)</i> is its classifying space. From this formulation, there follows that Yetter's invariant depends only on the homotopy type of <i>M</i>, and the weak homotopy type of the crossed module <i>\cal G</i>. We use this interpretation to define a twisting of Yetter's Invariant by cohomology classes of crossed modules, defined as cohomology classes of their classifying spaces, in the form of a state sum invariant. In particular, we obtain an extension of the Dijkgraaf-Witten Invariant of manifolds to categorical groups. The straightforward extension to crossed complexes is also considered.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Categorical Groups</keyword>
      <keyword>Crossed Modules</keyword>
      <keyword>Cohomology of Crossed Modules</keyword>
      <keyword>State Sum Invariants of Manifolds</keyword>
      <keyword>Dijkgraaf-Witten Invariant</keyword>
      <keyword>Yetter s Invariant</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="228">
        <givenname locale="en">Joao Faria</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Martins</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monad compositions I: general constructions and recursive distributive laws</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;New techniques for constructing a distributive law of a monad over another are studied using submonads, quotient monads, product monads, recursively-defined distributive laws, and linear equations. Sequel papers will consider distributive laws in closed categories and will construct monad approximations for compositions which fail to be a monad.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #252:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="252" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="252" filesize="321789" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/8/18-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Quasi locally connected toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We have shown that complete spreads (with a locally connected domain) over a bounded topos <b>E</b> (relative to <b>S</b>) are `comprehensive' in the sense that they are precisely the second factor of a factorization associated with an instance of the comprehension scheme involving <b>S</b>-valued distributions on <b>E</b>. Lawvere has asked whether the `Michael coverings' (or complete spreads with a definable dominance domain) are comprehensive in a similar fashion. We give here a positive answer to this question. In order to deal effectively with the comprehension scheme in this context, we introduce a notion of an `extensive topos doctrine,' where the extensive quantities (or distributions) have values in a suitable subcategory of what we call `locally discrete' locales. In the process we define what we mean by a quasi locally connected topos, a notion that we feel may be of interest in its own right.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>complete spreads</keyword>
      <keyword>distributions</keyword>
      <keyword>zero-dimensional locales</keyword>
      <keyword>comprehensive factorization</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="233">
        <givenname locale="en">Marta</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bunge</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="74">
        <givenname locale="en">Jonathon</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Funk</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </article_galley>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">More morphisms between bundle gerbes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;1-morphisms, called stable isomorphisms, are all invertible. I introduce new 1-morphisms which include stable isomorphisms, trivializations and bundle gerbe modules. They fit into the structure of a 2-category of bundle gerbes, and lead to natural definitions of surface holonomy for closed surfaces, surfaces with boundary, and unoriented closed surfaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>

FILE #254:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <name locale="en">18-10.pdf</name>

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/10/18-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Towards an $n$-category of cobordisms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We discuss an approach to constructing a weak n-category of cobordisms. First we present a generalisation of Trimble's definition of n-category which seems most appropriate for this construction; in this definition composition is parametrised by a contractible operad. Then we show how to use this definition to define the n-category <b>nCob</b>, whose k-cells are k-cobordisms, possibly with corners. We follow Baez and Langford in using ``manifolds embedded in cubes'' rather than general manifolds. We make the construction for 1-manifolds embedded in 2- and 3-cubes. For general dimensions k and n we indicate what the construction should be.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>n-category</keyword>
      <keyword>operad</keyword>
      <keyword>topological quantum field theory</keyword>
      <keyword>cobordism</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="150">

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The theory of core algebras: its completeness</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The core of a category (first defined in ``Core algebra revisited'' <i>Theoretical Computer Science</i>, Vol 375, Issues 1-3, pp 193-200) has the structure of an abstract core algebra (first defined in the same place). A question was left open: is there more structure yet to be defined? The answer is no: it is shown that any operation on an object arising from the fact that the object is the core of its category can be defined using only the constant and two binary operations that appear in the definition of abstract core algebra. In the process a number of facts about abstract core algebras must be developed.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>core</keyword>

      <keyword>abstract core algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>critical lemma</keyword>
      <keyword>no-lost-variables</keyword>
      <keyword>base cancellation</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #256:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="256" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="256" filesize="312011" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/12/18-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Higher cospans and weak cubical categories (Cospans in algebraic topology, I)</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a notion of <i> weak cubical category</i>, abstracted from the structure of n-cubical cospans $x : \wedge^n \to X$ in a category $X$ where $\wedge$ is the `formal cospan' category. These diagrams form a cubical set with compositions $x +_i y$ in all directions, which are computed using pushouts and behave `categorically' in a weak sense, up to suitable comparisons. Actually, we work with a `symmetric cubical structure', which includes the transposition symmetries, because this allows for a strong simplification of the coherence conditions. These notions will be used in subsequent papers to study topological cospans and their use in Algebraic Topology, from tangles to cobordisms of manifolds.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>weak cubical category</keyword>
      <keyword>multiple category</keyword>
      <keyword>double category</keyword>
      <keyword>cubical sets</keyword>
      <keyword>spans</keyword>
      <keyword>cospans</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

        <givenname locale="en">Marco</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Grandis</familyname>

FILE #257:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="257" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="257" filesize="238038" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/13/18-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Coherent unit actions on regular operads and Hopf algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;J.-L. Loday introduced the concept of coherent unit actions on a regular operad and showed that such actions give Hopf algebra structures on the free algebras. Hopf algebras obtained this way include the Hopf algebras of shuffles, quasi-shuffles and planar rooted trees. We characterize coherent unit actions on binary quadratic regular operads in terms of linear equations of the generators of the operads. We then use these equations to classify operads with coherent unit actions. We further show that coherent unit actions are preserved under taking products and thus yield Hopf algebras on the free object of the product operads when the factor operads have coherent unit actions. On the other hand, coherent unit actions are never preserved under taking the dual in the operadic sense except for the operad of associative algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>dendriform algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>coherent unit actions</keyword>
      <keyword>regular operads</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf algebras</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="236">
        <givenname locale="en">Kurusch</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Ebrahimi-Fard</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">Guo</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #258:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="258" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="258" filesize="328383" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/14/18-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Dense morphisms of monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given an arbitrary locally finitely presentable category $K$ and finitary monads $T$ and $S$ on $K$, we characterize monad morphisms $\alpha: S\to T$ with the property that the induced functor $\alpha_*: K^T \to K^ S$ between the categories of Eilenberg-Moore algebras is fully faithful. We call such monad morphisms dense and give a characterization of them in the spirit of Beth's definability theorem: $\alpha$ is a dense monad morphism if and only if every $T$-operation is explicitly defined using $S$-operations. We also give a characterization in terms of epimorphic property of $\alpha$ and clarify the connection between various notions of epimorphisms between monads.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Definable operation</keyword>
      <keyword>monad morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>locally finitely presentable category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="116">
        <givenname locale="en">Panagis</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Karazeris</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="112">
        <givenname locale="en">Jiri</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Velebil</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Enriched model categories and an application to additive endomorphism spectra</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define the notion of an additive model category and prove that any stable, additive, combinatorial model category $\cal M$ has a model enrichment over $Sp^\Sigma(sAb)$ (symmetric spectra based on simplicial abelian groups). So to any object $X$ in $\cal M$ one can attach an endomorphism ring object, denoted $hEnd_ad(X)$, in the category $Sp^\Sigma(sAb)$. We establish some useful properties of these endomorphism rings.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Exploring the gap between linear and classical logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The Medial rule was first devised as a deduction rule in the Calculus of Structures. In this paper we explore it from the point of view of category theory, as additional structure on a *-autonomous category. This gives us some insights on the denotational semantics of classical propositional logic, and allows us to construct new models for it, based on suitable generalizations of the theory of coherence spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>denotational semantics</keyword>
      <keyword>linear logic</keyword>
      <keyword>classical logic</keyword>
      <keyword>deep inference</keyword>
      <keyword>Medial rule</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #262:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="262" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-18.pdf</name>
    <file id="262" filesize="673754" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/18/18-18.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the axiomatisation of Boolean categories with and without medial</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The term ``Boolean category'' should be used for describing an object that is to categories what a Boolean algebra is to posets. More specifically, a Boolean category should provide the abstract algebraic structure underlying the proofs in Boolean Logic, in the same sense as a Cartesian closed category captures the proofs in intuitionistic logic and a *-autonomous category captures the proofs in linear logic. However, recent work has shown that there is no canonical axiomatisation of a Boolean category. In this work, we will see a series (with increasing strength) of possible such axiomatisations, all based on the notion of *-autonomous category. We will particularly focus on the medial map, which has its origin in an inference rule in KS, a cut-free deductive system for Boolean logic in the calculus of structures. Finally, we will present a category of proof nets as a particularly well-behaved example of a Boolean category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Boolean category</keyword>
      <keyword>*-autonomous category</keyword>
      <keyword>proof theory</keyword>
      <keyword>classical logic</keyword>
      <keyword>proof nets</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="241">
        <givenname locale="en">Lutz</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Strassburger</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="262"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>18</volume>

  </publication>

    <title locale="en">Collared cospans, cohomotopy and TQFT (cospans in algebraic topology, II)</title>

FILE #266:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="266" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">18-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="266" filesize="611045" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/18/22/18-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Familial 2-functors and parametric right adjoints</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define and study familial 2-functors primarily with a view to the development of the 2-categorical approach to operads of [Weber, 2005]. Also included in this paper is a result in which the well-known characterisation of a category as a simplicial set via the Segal condition, is generalised to a result about nice monads on cocomplete categories. Instances of this general result can be found in [Leinster, 2004], [Berger, 2002] and [Moerdijk-Weiss, 2007b]. Aspects of this general theory are then used to show that the composite 2-monads of [Weber, 2005] that describe symmetric and braided analogues of the $\omega$-operads of [Batanin, 1998], are cartesian 2-monads and their underlying endo-2-functor is familial. Intricately linked to the notion of familial 2-functor is the theory of fibrations in a finitely complete 2-category [Street, 1974] [Street, 1980], and those aspects of that theory that we require, that weren't discussed in [Weber, 2007], are reviewed here.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>nerves</keyword>
      <keyword>parametric right adjoints</keyword>
      <keyword>operads</keyword>
      <keyword>familial 2-functors</keyword>
      <keyword>fibrations</keyword>
      <keyword>2-categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="170">
        <givenname locale="en">Mark</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Weber</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <title locale="en">Exponentiability in Homotopy Slices of $\bf Top$ and Pseudo-Slices of $\bf Cat$</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove a general theorem relating pseudo-exponentiable objects of a bicategory K to those of the Kleisli bicategory of a pseudo-monad on K. This theorem is applied to obtain pseudo-exponentiable objects of the homotopy slices <b>Top</b>//B of the category of topological spaces and the pseudo-slices <b>Cat</b>//B of the category of small categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Components, complements and the reflection formula</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We illustrate the formula $ (\downarrow p)x = \Gamma_!(x/p) $, which gives the reflection $\downarrow p$ of a category $p : P \to X$ over $X$ in discrete fibrations. One of its proofs is based on a ``complement operator" which takes a discrete fibration $A$ to the functor $\neg A$, right adjoint to $\Gamma_!(A\times-):Cat/X \to Set$ and valued in discrete opfibrations. Some consequences and applications are presented.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>

FILE #269:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="269" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">19-03.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Axiomatic Cohesion</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The nature of the spatial background for classical analysis and for modern theories of continuum physics requires more than the partial invariants of locales and cohomology rings for its description. As Maxwell emphasized, this description has various levels of precision depending on the needs of investigation. These levels correspond to different categories of space, all of which have intuitively the feature of cohesion. Our aim here is to continue the axiomatic study of such categories, which involves the following aspects:<br> I. Categories of space as cohesive backgrounds<br> II. Cohesion versus non-cohesion; quality types<br> III. Extensive quality; intensive quality in its rarefied and condensed aspects; the canonical qualities form and substance<br> IV. Non-cohesion within cohesion via constancy on infinitesimals<br> V. The example of reflexive graphs and their atomic numbers<br> VI. Sufficient cohesion and the Grothendieck condition<br> VII. Weak generation of a subtopos by a quotient topos<br> I look forward to further work on each of these aspects, as well as development of categories of dynamical laws, constitutive relations, and other mathematical structures that naturally live in cohesive categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Cohesion</keyword>
      <keyword>qualities</keyword>
      <keyword>graphs</keyword>
      <keyword>nature of space</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="169">
        <givenname locale="en">F. William</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lawvere</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #270:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="270" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">19-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="270" filesize="224552" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/19/4/19-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Q-modules are Q-suplattices</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is well known that the internal suplattices in the topos of sheaves on a locale are precisely the modules on that locale. Using enriched category theory and a lemma on KZ doctrines we prove (the generalization of) this fact in the case of ordered sheaves on a small quantaloid. Comparing module-equivalence with sheaf-equivalence for quantaloids and using the notion of centre of a quantaloid, we refine a result of F. Borceux and E. Vitale.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2007</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quantaloid</keyword>
      <keyword>quantale</keyword>
      <keyword>locale</keyword>
      <keyword>ordered sheaf</keyword>
      <keyword>module</keyword>
      <keyword>centre</keyword>
      <keyword>KZ doctrine</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Iterative Algebras: How Iterative are They?</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Iterative algebras, defined by the property that every guarded system of recursive equations has a unique solution, are proved to have a much stronger property: every system of recursive equations has a unique strict solution. Those systems that have a unique solution in every iterative algebra are characterized.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The notion of <i>cartesian bicategory</i>, introduced by Carboni and Walters for locally ordered bicategories, is extended to general bicategories. It is shown that a cartesian bicategory is a symmetric monoidal bicategory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Frobenius objects in Cartesian bicategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Maps (left adjoint arrows) between Frobenius objects in a cartesian bicategory <b>B</b> are precisely comonoid homomorphisms and, for A Frobenius and any T in <b>B</b>, map(<b>B</b>)(T,A) is a groupoid.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #276:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="276" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="276" filesize="321003" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/4/20-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Abelian groupoids and non-pointed additive categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that, in any Mal'tsev (and a fortiori protomodular) category <b>E</b>, not only the fibre <i>Grd</i>_X <b>E</b> of internal groupoids above the object <i>X</i> is a naturally Mal'tsev category, but moreover it shares with the category <i>Ab</i> of abelian groups the property following which the domain of any split epimorphism is isomorphic with the direct sum of its codomain with its kernel. This allows us to point at a new class of ``non-pointed additive'' categories which is necessarily protomodular. Actually this even gives rise to a larger classification table of non-pointed additive categories which gradually take place between the class of naturally Mal'tsev categories and the one of essentially affine categories. As an application, when furthermore the ground category <b>E</b> is efficiently regular, we get a new way to produce Baer sums in the fibres <i>Grd</i>_X <b>E</b> and, more generally, in the fibres <i>n-Grd</i>_X <b>E</b>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Mal tsev</keyword>
      <keyword>protomodular</keyword>
      <keyword>naturally Mal tsev categories</keyword>
      <keyword>internal group</keyword>
      <keyword>Baer sum</keyword>
      <keyword>long cohomology sequence</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="82">
        <givenname locale="en">Dominique</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bourn</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #278:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="278" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="278" filesize="339191" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/6/20-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Balanced category theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Some aspects of basic category theory are developed in a finitely complete category $\cal C$, endowed with two factorization systems which determine the same discrete objects and are linked by a simple reciprocal stability law. Resting on this axiomatization of final and initial functors and discrete (op)fibrations, concepts such as components, slices and coslices, colimits and limits, left and right adjunctible maps, dense maps and arrow intervals, can be naturally defined in $\cal C$, and several classical properties concerning them can be effectively proved. For any object $X$ of $\cal C$, by restricting $\cal C/X$ to the slices or to the coslices of $X$, two dual ``underlying categories" are obtained. These can be enriched over internal sets (discrete objects) of $\cal C$: internal hom-sets are given by the components of the pullback of the corresponding slice and coslice of $X$. The construction extends to give functors $\cal C \to Cat$, which preserve (or reverse) slices and adjunctible maps and which can be enriched over internal sets too.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>factorization systems</keyword>
      <keyword>final maps and discrete fibrations</keyword>
      <keyword>initial maps and discrete opfibrations</keyword>
      <keyword>reflections</keyword>
      <keyword>internal sets and components</keyword>
      <keyword>slices and coslices</keyword>
      <keyword>colimiting cones</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunctible maps</keyword>
      <keyword>dense maps</keyword>
      <keyword>cylinders and homotopy</keyword>
      <keyword>arrow intervals</keyword>
      <keyword>enrichment</keyword>
      <keyword>complements</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="55">
        <givenname locale="en">Claudio</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Pisani</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="278"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>20</volume>
      <year>2008</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>85-115</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #279:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="279" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="279" filesize="361074" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/7/20-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Category-theoretic models of Linear Abadi and Plotkin Logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper presents a sound and complete category-theoretic notion of models for Linear Abadi and Plotkin Logic, a logic suitable for reasoning about parametricity in combination with recursion. A subclass of these called <i>parametric LAPL structures</i> can be seen as an axiomatization of domain theoretic models of parametric polymorphism, and we show how to solve general (nested) recursive domain equations in these. Parametric LAPL structures constitute a general notion of model of parametricity in a setting with recursion. In future papers we will demonstrate this by showing how many different models of parametricity and recursion give rise to parametric LAPL structures, including Simpson and Rosolini's set theoretic models, a syntactic model based on Lily and a model based on admissible pers over a reflexive domain.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Parametric polymorphism</keyword>
      <keyword>categorical semantics</keyword>
      <keyword>axiomatic domain theory</keyword>
      <keyword>recursive types</keyword>
      <keyword>fibrations</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="249">
        <givenname locale="en">Lars</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Birkedal</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">Petersen</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    <title locale="en">Kan extensions in double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper deals with Kan extensions in a weak double category. <i> Absolute</i> Kan extensions are closely related to the orthogonal adjunctions introduced in a previous paper. The <i>pointwise</i> case is treated by introducing internal comma objects, which can be defined in an arbitrary double category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #281:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="281" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-09.pdf</name>
    <file id="281" filesize="325305" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/9/20-09.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Fundamental pushout toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The author introduced and employed certain `fundamental pushout toposes' in the construction of the coverings fundamental groupoid of a locally connected topos. Our main purpose in this paper is to generalize this construction without the local connectedness assumption. We replace connected components by constructively complemented, or definable, monomorphisms. Unlike the locally connected case, where the fundamental groupoid is localic prodiscrete and its classifying topos is a Galois topos, in the general case our version of the fundamental groupoid is a locally discrete progroupoid and there is no intrinsic Galois theory in the sense of Janelidze. We also discuss covering projections, locally trivial, and branched coverings without local connectedness by analogy with, but also necessarily departing from, the locally connected case. Throughout, we work abstractly in a setting given axiomatically by a category <b>V</b> of locally discrete locales that has as examples the categories <b>D</b> of discrete locales, and <b>Z</b> of zero-dimensional locales. In this fashion we are led to give unified and often simpler proofs of old theorems in the locally connected case, as well as new ones without that assumption.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>fundamental progroupoid</keyword>
      <keyword>spreads</keyword>
      <keyword>zero dimensional locales</keyword>
      <keyword>covering projections</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="233">
        <givenname locale="en">Marta</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bunge</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>20</volume>
      <year>2008</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>186-214</pages>
  </publication>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Star-autonomous functor categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We construct a star-autonomous structure on the functor category $K^J$, where $J$ is small, $K$ is small-complete, and both are star-autonomous. A weaker result, that $K^J$ admits a linear distributive structure, is also shown under weaker hypotheses. The latter leads to a deeper understanding of the notion of linear functor.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Linear distributive categories</keyword>

      <keyword>functor categories</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Colimits of representable algebra-valued functors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;If C and D are varieties of algebras in the sense of general algebra, then by a representable functor C --> D we understand a functor which, when composed with the forgetful functor D --> Set, gives a representable functor in the classical sense; Freyd showed that these functors are determined by D-coalgebra objects of C. Let Rep(C, D) denote the category of all such functors, a full subcategory of Cat(C, D, opposite to the category of D-coalgebras in C.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>representable functor among varieties of algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>initial representable functor</keyword>

      <keyword>final coalgebra</keyword>
      <keyword>limit of coalgebras</keyword>
      <keyword>binar (set with one binary operation)</keyword>
      <keyword>semigroup</keyword>
      <keyword>monoid</keyword>
      <keyword>group</keyword>
      <keyword>ring</keyword>
      <keyword>Boolean ring</keyword>
      <keyword>Stone topological algebra</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #285:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="285" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="285" filesize="774842" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/13/20-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Quotients of unital $A_\infty$-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Assuming that $B$ is a full $A_\infty$-subcategory of a unital $A_\infty$-category $\cc$ we construct the quotient unital $A_\infty$-category $\cd=$`$\cc/\cb$'. It represents the $A_\infty^u$-2-functor $A \mapsto A_\infty^u(C,A)_{mod B}$, which associates with a given unital $A_\infty$-category $A$ the $A_\infty$-category of unital $A_\infty$-functors $C \to A$, whose restriction to $B$ is contractible. Namely, there is a unital $A_\infty$-functor $e: C \to D$ such that the composition $B \hookrightarrow C \to^e D$ is contractible, and for an arbitrary unital $A_\infty$-category $A$ the restriction $A_\infty$-functor $(e\boxtimes 1)M : A_\infty^u(D,A)\to A_\infty^u(C,A)_{mod B}$ is an equivalence.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>$A_\infty$-categories</keyword>
      <keyword>$A_\infty$-categories</keyword>
      <keyword>$A_\infty$-functors</keyword>
      <keyword>$A_\infty$-transformations</keyword>
      <keyword>2-categories</keyword>
      <keyword>2-functors</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="200">
        <givenname locale="en">Volodymyr</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lyubashenko</familyname>

      </author>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Core varieties, extensivity, and rig geometry</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The role of the Frobenius operations in analyzing finite spaces, as well as the extended algebraic geometry over rigs, depend partly on varieties (Birkhoffian inclusions of algebraic categories) that have coreflections as well as reflections and whose dual category of affine spaces is extensive. Even within the category of those rigs where 1 + 1 = 1, not only distributive lattices but also the function algebras of tropical geometry (where x + 1 = 1) and the dimension rigs of separable prextensive categories (where x + x^2 = x^2) enjoy those features. (Talk given at CT08, Calais.)MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius</keyword>
      <keyword>dimension rigs</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="169">
        <givenname locale="en">F. William</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lawvere</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #288:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="288" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="288" filesize="1142583" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/16/20-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Cohomology theory in 2-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Recently, symmetric categorical groups are used for the study of the Brauer groups of symmetric monoidal categories. As a part of these efforts, some algebraic structures of the 2-category of symmetric categorical groups SCG are being investigated. In this paper, we consider a 2-categorical analogue of an abelian category, in such a way that it contains SCG as an example. As a main theorem, we construct a long cohomology 2-exact sequence from any extension of complexes in such a 2-category. Our axiomatic and self-dual definition will enable us to simplify the proofs, by analogy with abelian categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>symmetric categorical group</keyword>
      <keyword>2-category</keyword>
      <keyword>cohomology</keyword>
      <keyword>exact sequence</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="254">

        <familyname locale="en">Nakaoka</familyname>

FILE #289:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="289" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-17.pdf</name>

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/17/20-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Proprietes universelles et extensions de Kan derivees</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove that, given any small category A$=, the derivator <b>HOT</b>_A, corresponding to the homotopy theory of presheaves of homotopy types on A, is characterized by a natural universal property. In particular, the theory of Kan extensions extends to the setting of Grothendieck derivators.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>derivator</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy theory</keyword>
      <keyword>derived Kan extension</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy limit</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="255">
        <givenname locale="en">Denis-Charles</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cisinski</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #290:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="290" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">20-18.pdf</name>
    <file id="290" filesize="735055" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/18/20-18.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Framed bicategories and monoidal fibrations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In some bicategories, the 1-cells are `morphisms' between the 0-cells, such as functors between categories, but in others they are `objects' over the 0-cells, such as bimodules, spans, distributors, or parametrized spectra. Many bicategorical notions do not work well in these cases, because the `morphisms between 0-cells', such as ring homomorphisms, are missing. We can include them by using a pseudo double category, but usually these morphisms also induce base change functors acting on the 1-cells. We avoid complicated coherence problems by describing base change `nonalgebraically', using categorical fibrations. The resulting `framed bicategories' assemble into 2-categories, with attendant notions of equivalence, adjunction, and so on which are more appropriate for our examples than are the usual bicategorical ones.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>derivator</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy theory</keyword>
      <keyword>derived Kan extension</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy limit</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="256">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shulman</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">A convenient category for directed homotopy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We propose a convenient category for directed homotopy consisting of "directed'' topological spaces generated by "directed'' cubes. Its main advantage is that, like the category of topological spaces generated by simplices suggested by J. H. Smith, it is locally presentable.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Limit preserving full embeddings</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove that every small strongly connected category <i>k</i> has a full embedding preserving all limits existing in <i>k</i> into a category of unary universal algebras. The number of unary operations can be restricted to |mor <i>k</i>| in case when <i>k</i> has a terminal object and only preservation of limits over finitely many objects is desired. And all limits existing in such a category <i>k</i> are preserved by a full embedding of <i>k</i> into the category of all algebraic systems with |mor <i>k</i>| unary operation and one unary relation.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Protolocalisations of exact Mal'cev categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A protolocalisation of a regular category is a full reflective regular subcategory, whose reflection preserves pullbacks of regular epimorphisms along arbitrary morphisms. We devote special attention to the epireflective protolocalisations of an exact Mal'cev category; we characterise them in terms of a corresponding closure operator on equivalence relations. We give some examples in algebra and in topos theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #294:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="294" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">21-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="294" filesize="223362" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/21/4/21-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Doubles for monoidal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In a recent paper, Daisuke Tambara defined two-sided actions on an endomodule (= endodistributor) of a monoidal <i>V</i>-category <i>A</i>. When <i>A</i> is autonomous (= rigid = compact), he showed that the <i>V</i>-category (that we call Tamb(<i>A</i>)) of so-equipped endomodules (that we call Tambara modules) is equivalent to the monoidal centre <i>Z</i>[<i>A,V</i>] of the convolution monoidal <i>V</i>-category [<i>A, V</i>]. Our paper extends these ideas somewhat. For general <i>A</i>, we construct a promonoidal <i>V</i>-category <i>DA</i> (which we suggest should be called the double of <i>A</i>) with an equivalence of [<i>DA, V</i>] with Tamb(<i>A</i>). When <i>A</i> is closed, we define strong (respectively, left strong) Tambara modules and show that these constitute a <i>V</i>-category Tamb_s(<i>A</i>) (respectively, Tamb_{ls}(<i>A</i>)) which is equivalent to the centre (respectively, lax centre) of [<i>A, V</i>]. We construct localizations <i>D_sA</i> and <i>D_{ls}A</i> of <i>DA</i> such that there are equivalences of Tamb_s(<i>A</i>) with [<i>D_sA, V</i>] and of Tamb_{ls}(<i>A</i>) with [<i>D_{ls}A, V</i>]. When <i>A</i> is autonomous, every Tambara module is strong; this implies an equivalence of <i>Z</i>[<i>A, V</i>] with [<i>DA,V</i>].MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>monoidal centre</keyword>
      <keyword>Drinfeld double</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>Day convolution</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="261">
        <givenname locale="en">Craig</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Pastro</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="6">
        <givenname locale="en">Ross</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Street</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Weakly Mal'cev categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce a notion of <i>weakly Mal'cev category</i>, and show that: (a) every internal reflexive graph in a weakly Mal'tsev category admits at most one multiplicative graph structure in the sense of Janelidze, and such a structure always makes it an internal category; (b) (unlike the special case of Mal'tsev categories) there are weakly Mal'tsev categories in which not every internal category is an internal groupoid. We also give a simplified characterization of internal groupoids among internal categories in this context.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Extensions in the theory of lax algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Recent investigations of lax algebras - in generalization of Barr's relational algebras -make an essential use of lax extensions of monad functors on Set to the category Rel(V) of sets and V-relations (where V is a unital quantale). For a given monad there may be many such lax extensions, and different constructions appear in the literature. The aim of this article is to shed a unifying light on these lax extensions, and present a symptomatic situation in which distinct monads yield isomorphic categories of lax algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #298:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="298" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">21-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="298" filesize="287364" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/21/8/21-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Approximate Mal'tsev operations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let $X$ and $A$ be sets and $\alpha:X\to A$ a map between them. We call a map $\mu:X\times X\times X\to A$ an <i>approximate Mal'tsev operation with approximation $\alpha$</i>, if it satisfies $\mu(x,y,y) = \alpha(x) = \mu(y,y,x)$ for all $x,y\in X$. Note that if $A = X$ and the approximation $\alpha$ is an identity map, then $\mu$ becomes an ordinary Mal'tsev operation. We prove the following two characterization theorems: a category $\mathbb{X}$ is a Mal'tsev category if and only if in the functor category $\mathbf{Set}^{\mathbb{X}^\mathrm{op}\times\mathbb{X}}$ there exists an internal approximate Mal'tsev operation $\mathrm{hom}_{\mathbb{X}}\times \mathrm{hom}_{\mathbb{X}}\times \mathrm{hom}_{\mathbb{X}}\rightarrow A$ whose approximation $\alpha$ satisfies a suitable condition; a regular category $\mathbb{X}$ with finite coproducts is a Mal'tsev category, if and only if in the functor category $\mathbb{X}^\mathbb{X}$ there exists an internal approximate Mal'tsev co-operation $A\rightarrow 1_\mathbb{X}+1_\mathbb{X}+1_\mathbb{X}$ whose approximation $\alpha$ is a natural transformation with every component a regular epimorphism in $\mathbb{X}$. Note that in both of these characterization theorems, if require further the approximation $\alpha$ to be an identity morphism, then the conditions there involving $\alpha$ become equivalent to $\mathbb{X}$ being a naturally Mal'tsev category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Mal tsev category</keyword>

    <title locale="en">Notes on effective descent and projectivity in quasivarieties of universal algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present sufficient conditions under which effective descent morphisms in a quasivariety of universal algebras are the same as regular epimorphisms and examples for which they are the same as regular epimorphisms satisfying projectivity.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Descent for compact 0-dimensional spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Using the reflection of the category C of compact 0-dimensional topological spaces into the category of Stone spaces we introduce a concept of a fibration in C. We show that: (i) effective descent morphisms in C are the same as the surjective fibrations; (ii) effective descent morphisms in C with respect to the fibrations are all surjections.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #301:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="301" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">21-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="301" filesize="250379" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/21/11/21-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Analytic functors and weak pullbacks</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For accessible set-valued functors it is well known that weak preservation of limits is equivalent to representability, and weak preservation of connected limits to familial representability. In contrast, preservation of weak wide pullbacks is equivalent to being a coproduct of quotients of $\hom$-functors modulo groups of automorphisms. For finitary functors this was proved by Andr\'e Joyal who called these functors analytic. We introduce a generalization of Joyal's concept from endofunctors of <b>Set</b> to endofunctors of a symmetric monoidal category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>analytic functor</keyword>
      <keyword>weak limit</keyword>
      <keyword>weak pullback</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="91">
        <givenname locale="en">J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Adamek</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="246">
        <givenname locale="en">J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Velebil</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #302:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="302" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">21-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="302" filesize="295471" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/21/12/21-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Relative injectivity as cocompleteness for a class of distributors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Notions and techniques of enriched category theory can be used to study topological structures, like metric spaces, topological spaces and approach spaces, in the context of topological theories. Recently in [D. Hofmann, Injective spaces via adjunction, arXiv:math.CT/0804.0326] the construction of a Yoneda embedding allowed to identify injectivity of spaces as cocompleteness and to show monadicity of the category of injective spaces and left adjoints over SET. In this paper we generalise these results, studying cocompleteness with respect to a given class of distributors. We show in particular that the description of several semantic domains presented in [M. Escardo and B. Flagg, Semantic domains, injective spaces and monads, Electronic Notes in Theoretical Computer Science 20 (1999)] can be translated into the V-enriched setting.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2008</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>distributor</keyword>
      <keyword>Yoneda lemma</keyword>
      <keyword>weighted colimit</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">On deformations of pasting diagrams</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We adapt the work of Power to describe general, not-necessarily composable, not-necessarily commutative 2-categorical pasting diagrams and their composable and commutative parts. We provide a deformation theory for pasting diagrams valued in the 2-category of k-linear categories, paralleling that provided for diagrams of algebras by Gerstenhaber and Schack, proving the standard results. Along the way, the construction gives rise to a bicategorical analog of the homotopy G-algebras of Gerstenhaber and Voronov.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
