<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="364" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="364" filesize="345256" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/5/25-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monoidal functor categories and graphic Fourier transforms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This article represents a preliminary attempt to link Kan extensions, and some of their further developments, to Fourier theory and quantum algebra through *-autonomous monoidal categories and related structures. There is a close resemblance to convolution products and the Wiener algebra (of transforms) in functional analysis. The analysis term ``kernel'' (of a distribution) has also been adapted below in connection with certain special types of ``distributors'' (in the terminology of J. Benabou) or ``modules'' (in the terminology of R. Street) in category theory. In using the term ``graphic'', in a very broad sense, we are clearly distinguishing the categorical methods employed in this article from standard Fourier and wavelet mathematics. The term ``graphic'' also applies to promultiplicative graphs, and related concepts, which can feature prominently in the theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>promonoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>convolution</keyword>
      <keyword>Fourier transform</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="313">
        <givenname locale="en">Brian J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Day</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>

    </article_galley>

      <volume>25</volume>
      <year>2011</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>118-141</pages>
  </publication>

    <title locale="en">Reflective-coreflective equivalence</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We explore a curious type of equivalence between certain pairs of reflective and coreflective subcategories. We illustrate with examples involving noncommutative duality for $C^*$-dynamical systems and compact quantum groups, as well as examples where the subcategories are actually isomorphic.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #366:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="366" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="366" filesize="249940" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/7/25-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">An embedding theorem for adhesive categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Adhesive categories are categories which have pushouts with one leg a monomorphism, all pullbacks, and certain exactness conditions relating these pushouts and pullbacks. We give a new proof of the fact that every topos is adhesive. We also prove a converse: every small adhesive category has a fully faithful functor in a topos, with the functor preserving the all the structure. Combining these two results, we see that the exactness conditions in the definition of adhesive category are exactly the relationship between pushouts along monomorphisms and pullbacks which hold in any topos.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>adhesive category</keyword>
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>embedding theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="35">
        <givenname locale="en">Stephen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lack</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Model-categories of coalgebras over operads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper constructs model structures on the categories of coalgebras and pointed irreducible coalgebras over an operad whose components are projective, finitely generated in each dimension, and satisfy a condition that allows one to take tensor products with a unit interval. The underlying chain-complex is assumed to be unbounded and the results for bounded coalgebras over an operad are derived from the unbounded case.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">A small observation on co-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Various concerns suggest looking for internal co-categories in categories with strong logical structure. It turns out that in any coherent category E, all co-categories are co-equivalence relations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Higher categorified algebras versus bounded homotopy algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define Lie 3-algebras and prove that these are in 1-to-1 correspondence with the 3-term Lie infinity algebras whose bilinear and trilinear maps vanish in degree (1,1) and in total degree 1, respectively. Further, we give an answer to a question of Roytenberg pertaining to the use of the nerve and normalization functors in the study of the relationship between categorified algebras and truncated sh algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #370:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="370" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="370" filesize="182885" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/11/25-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Symmetry and Cauchy completion of quantaloid-enriched categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We formulate an elementary condition on an involutive quantaloid $Q$ under which there is a distributive law from the Cauchy completion monad over the symmetrisation comonad on the category of $Q$-enriched categories. For such quantaloids, which we call Cauchy-bilateral quantaloids, it follows that the Cauchy completion of any symmetric $Q$-enriched category is again symmetric. Examples include Lawvere's quantale of non-negative real numbers and Walters' small quantaloids of closed cribles.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quantaloid</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetry</keyword>
      <keyword>Cauchy completion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="322">

FILE #371:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="371" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="371" filesize="315494" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/13/25-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Covariant presheaves and subalgebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For small involutive and integral quantaloids ${\cal Q}$ it is shown that covariant presheaves on symmetric ${\cal Q}$-categories are equivalent to certain subalgebras of a specific monad on the category of symmetric ${\cal Q}$-categories. This construction is related to a weakening of the subobject classifier axiom which does not require the classification of all subalgebras, but only guarantees that classifiable subalgebras are uniquely classifiable. As an application the identification of closed left ideals of non-commutative $C^*$-algebras with certain "open", subalgebras of freely generated algebras is given.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Involutive quantale</keyword>
      <keyword>involutive quantaloid</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric ${\cal Q}$-category</keyword>
      <keyword>covariant presheaf</keyword>
      <keyword>monad of weak singletons</keyword>
      <keyword>classifiable subalgebra</keyword>
      <keyword>closed left ideal</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On involutive monoidal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we consider a non-posetal analogue of the notion of <i>involutive quantale</i>; specifically, a (planar) monoidal category equipped with a covariant involution that reverses the order of tensoring. We study the coherence issues that inevitably result when passing from posets to categories; we also link our subject with other notions already in the literature, such as <i>balanced monoidal categories</i> and <i>dagger pivotal categories</i>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

      <keyword>coherence theorems</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #373:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="373" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="373" filesize="458133" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/15/25-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Faa di Bruno construction</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In the context of Cartesian differential categories, the structure of the first-order chain rule gives rise to a fibration, the ``bundle category''. In the present paper we generalise this to the higher-order chain rule (originally developed in the traditional setting by Fa&agrave; di Bruno in the nineteenth century); given any Cartesian differential category X, there is a ``higher-order chain rule fibration'' Faa(X) --> X over it. In fact, Faa is a comonad (over the category of Cartesian left (semi-)additive categories). Our main theorem is that the coalgebras for this comonad are precisely the Cartesian differential categories. In a sense, this result affirms the ``correctness'' of the notion of Cartesian differential categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Higher-order chain rule</keyword>
      <keyword>Cartesian differential categories</keyword>
      <keyword>bundle fibration</keyword>
      <keyword>coalgebras</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="29">
        <givenname locale="en">J. R. B.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cockett</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="30">
        <givenname locale="en">R. A. G.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Seely</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="373"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>25</volume>
      <year>2011</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>393-425</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #374:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="374" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="374" filesize="331359" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/16/25-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Semidirect products and crossed modules in varieties of right $\Omega$-loops</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present a new explicit construction of categorical semidirect products in an arbitrary variety <b>V</b> of right $\Omega$-loops and use it to obtain simplified descriptions of internal precrossed and crossed modules in <b>V</b>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Yoneda theory for double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Representables for double categories are defined to be lax morphisms into a certain double category of sets. We show that horizontal transformations from representables into lax morphisms correspond to elements of that lax morphism. Vertical arrows give rise to modules between representables. We establish that the Yoneda embedding is a strong morphism of lax double categories which is horizontally full and faithful and dense.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Flows: cocyclic and almost cocyclic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A flow on a compact Hausdorff space is an automorphism. Using the closed structure on the category of uniform spaces, a flow gives rise, by iteration, to an action of the integers on the topological group of automorphisms of the object. We study special classes of flows: periodic, cocyclic, and almost cocyclic, mainly in term of the possibility of extending this action continuously to various compactifications of the integers.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Countable meets in coherent spaces with applications to the cyclic spectrum</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper reviews the basic properties of coherent spaces, characterizes them, and proves a theorem about countable meets of open sets. A number of examples of coherent spaces are given, including the set of all congruences (equipped with the Zariski topology) of a model of a theory based on a set of partial operations. We also give two alternate proofs of the main theorem, one using a theorem of Isbell's and a second using an unpublished theorem of Makkai's. Finally, we apply these results to the Boolean cyclic spectrum and give some relevant examples.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">Differential restriction categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We combine two recent ideas: cartesian differential categories, and restriction categories. The result is a new structure which axiomatizes the category of smooth maps defined on open subsets of $R^n$ in a way that is completely algebraic. We also give other models for the resulting structure, discuss what it means for a partial map to be additive or linear, and show that differential restriction structure can be lifted through various completion operations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #380:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="380" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="380" filesize="197486" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/22/25-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Symbolic dynamics and the category of graphs</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Symbolic dynamics is partly the study of walks in a directed graph. By a walk, here we mean a morphism to the graph from the Cayley graph of the monoid of non-negative integers. Sets of these walks are also important in other areas, such as stochastic processes, automata, combinatorial group theory, $C^*$-algebras, etc. We put a Quillen model structure on the category of directed graphs, for which the weak equivalences are those graph morphisms which induce bijections on the set of walks. We determine the resulting homotopy category. We also introduce a "finite-level" homotopy category which respects the natural topology on the set of walks. To each graph we associate a basal graph, well defined up to isomorphism. We show that the basal graph is a homotopy invariant for our model structure, and that it is a finer invariant than the zeta series of a finite graph. We also show that, for finite walkable graphs, if $B$ is basal and separated then the walk spaces for $X$ and $B$ are topologically conjugate if and only if $X$ and $B$ are homotopically equivalent for our model structure.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2011</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>category of graphs</keyword>
      <keyword>Quillen model structure</keyword>
      <keyword>walks</keyword>
      <keyword>symbolic dynamics</keyword>
      <keyword>coverings</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="326">
        <givenname locale="en">Terrence</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bisson</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="327">
        <givenname locale="en">Aristide</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Tsemo</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

      <seq>MEOW</seq>

    <title locale="en">Kan extensions and lax idempotent pseudomonads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that colax idempotent pseudomonads and their algebras can be presented in terms of right Kan extensions. Dually, lax idempotent pseudomonads and their algebras can be presented in terms of left Kan extensions. We also show that a distributive law of a colax idempotent pseudomonad over a lax idempotent pseudomonad has a presentation in terms of Kan extensions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #382:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="382" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-02.pdf</name>
    <file id="382" filesize="593075" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/2/26-02.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the iteration of weak wreath products</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Based on a study of the 2-category of weak distributive laws, we describe a method of iterating Street's weak wreath product construction. That is, for any 2-category $cal K$ and for any non-negative integer $n$, we introduce 2-categories $\Wdl^{(n)}(\cal K)$, of $(n+1)$-tuples of monads in $\cal K$ pairwise related by weak distributive laws obeying the Yang-Baxter equation. The first instance $\Wdl^{(0)}(\cal K)$ coincides with $\Mnd(\cal K)$, the usual 2-category of monads in $\cal K$, and for other values of $n$, $\Wdl^{(n)}(\cal K)$ contains $\Mnd^{n+1}(\cK)$ as a full 2-subcategory. For the local idempotent closure $\overline \cal K$ of $\cal K$, extending the multiplication of the 2-monad $\Mnd$, we equip these 2-categories with $n$ possible `weak wreath product' 2-functors $\Wdl^{(n)}(\ocK)\to \Wdl^{(n-1)}(\overline \cal K)$, such that all of their possible $n$-fold composites $\Wdl^{(n)}(\overline \cal K)\to \Wdl^{(0)}(\overline \cal K)$ are equal; that is, such that the weak wreath product is `associative'. Whenever idempotent 2-cells in $\cal K$ split, this leads to pseudofunctors $\Wdl^{(n)}(\cal K)\to \Wdl^{(n-1)}(\cal K)$ obeying the associativity property up-to isomorphism. We present a practically important occurrence of an iterated weak wreath product: the algebra of observable quantities in an Ising type quantum spin chain where the spins take their values in a dual pair of finite weak Hopf algebras. We also construct a fully faithful embedding of $\Wdl^{(n)}(\overline \cal K)$ into the 2-category of commutative $n+1$ dimensional cubes in $\Mnd(\overline \cal K)$ (hence into the 2-category of commutative $n+1$ dimensional cubes in $\cal K$ whenever $\cal K$ has Eilenberg-Moore objects and its idempotent 2-cells split). Finally we give a sufficient and necessary condition on a monad in $\overline \cal K$ to be isomorphic to an $n$-ary weak wreath product.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>monad</keyword>
      <keyword>weak distributive law</keyword>
      <keyword>n-ary weak wreath product</keyword>
      <keyword>Yang-Baxter equation</keyword>
      <keyword>quantum spin chain</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="328">
        <givenname locale="en">Gabriella</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">B&ouml;hm</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="382"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>26</volume>
      <year>2012</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>30-59</pages>
  </publication>
</article>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On diagram-chasing in double complexes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We construct, for any double complex in an abelian category, certain ``short-distance'' maps, and an exact sequence involving these, instances of which can be pieced together to give the ``long-distance'' maps and exact sequences of results such as the Snake Lemma. Further applications are given. We also note what the building blocks of an analogous study of triple complexes would be.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>double complex</keyword>
      <keyword>exact sequence</keyword>
      <keyword>diagram-chasing</keyword>
      <keyword>Salamander Lemma</keyword>
      <keyword>total homology</keyword>
      <keyword>triple complex</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Commutative monads as a theory of distributions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is shown how the theory of commutative monads provides an axiomatic framework for several aspects of distribution theory in a broad sense, including probability distributions, physical extensive quantities, and Schwartz distributions of compact support. Among the particular aspects considered here are the notions of convolution, density, expectation, and conditional probability.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">A characterization of representable intervals</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this note we provide a characterization, in terms of additional algebraic structure, of those strict intervals (certain cocategory objects) in a symmetric monoidal closed category $\cal E$ that are representable in the sense of inducing on $\cal E$ the structure of a finitely bicomplete 2-category. Several examples and connections with the homotopy theory of 2-categories are also discussed.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #389:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="389" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-09.pdf</name>
    <file id="389" filesize="3735522" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/9/26-09.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Graphical Methods for Tannaka duality]{Graphical Methods for Tannaka duality of weak bialgebras and weak Hopf algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Tannaka duality describes the relationship between algebraic objects in a given category and functors into that category; an important case is that of Hopf algebras and their categories of representations; these have strong monoidal forgetful ``fibre functors'' to the category of vector spaces. We simultaneously generalize the theory of Tannaka duality in two ways: first, we replace Hopf algebras with <i>weak Hopf algebras</i> and strong monoidal functors with <i>separable Frobenius monoidal functors</i>; second, we replace the category of vector spaces with an arbitrary braided monoidal category. To accomplish this goal, we make use of a graphical notation for functors between monoidal categories, using string diagrams with <i>coloured regions</i>. Not only does this notation extend our capacity to give simple proofs of complicated calculations, it makes plain some of the connections between Frobenius monoidal or separable Frobenius monoidal functors and the topology of the axioms defining certain algebraic structures. Finally, having generalized Tannaka duality to an arbitrary base category, we briefly discuss the functoriality of the construction as this base is varied.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Tannaka duality</keyword>
      <keyword>Tannaka reconstruction</keyword>
      <keyword>bialgebras</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>weak bialgebras</keyword>
      <keyword>weak Hopf algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>separable Frobenius monoidal functors</keyword>
      <keyword>graphical methods</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="330">
        <givenname locale="en">Micah Blake</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">McCurdy</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    </article_galley>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="390" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-10.pdf</name>
    <file id="390" filesize="208600" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/10/26-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Notes on Bimonads and Hopf Monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a generalisation of the classical theory of Hopf algebra over fields, A. Brugui&egrave;eres and A. Virelizier study opmonoidal monads on monoidal categories (which they called <i>bimonads,</i>). In a recent joint paper with S. Lack the same authors define the notion of a <i>pre-Hopf monad</i> by requiring only a special form of the fusion operator to be invertible. In previous papers it was observed by the present authors that bimonads yield a special case of an entwining of a pair of functors (on arbitrary categories). The purpose of this note is to show that in this setting the pre-Hopf monads are a special case of Galois entwinings. As a byproduct some new properties are detected which make a (general) bimonad on a Cauchy complete category to a Hopf monad. In the final section applications to cartesian monoidal categories are considered.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Opmonoidal functors</keyword>
      <keyword>bimonads</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf monads</keyword>
      <keyword>Galois entwinings</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="76">
        <givenname locale="en">Bachuki</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Mesablishvili</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="331">
        <givenname locale="en">Robert</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Wisbauer</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="391" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="391" filesize="494813" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/11/26-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The coalgebraic structure of cell complexes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The relative cell complexes with respect to a generating set of cofibrations are an important class of morphisms in any model structure. In the particular case of the standard (algebraic) model structure on <b>Top</b>, we give a new expression of these morphisms by defining a category of relative cell complexes, which has a forgetful functor to the arrow category. This allows us to prove a conjecture of Richard Garner: considering the algebraic weak factorisation system given in that algebraic model structure between cofibrations and trivial fibrations, we show that the category of relative cell complexes is equivalent to the category of coalgebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>relative cell complexes</keyword>
      <keyword>algebraic weak factorisation systems</keyword>
      <keyword>small object argument</keyword>
    </keywords>

        <familyname locale="en">Athorne</familyname>

FILE #393:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="393" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="393" filesize="299652" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/13/26-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Injective hulls of partially ordered monoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We find the injective hulls of partially ordered monoids in the category whose objects are po-monoids and submultiplicative order-preserving functions. These injective hulls are with respect to a special class of monics called ``embeddings''. We show as well that the injective objects with respect to these embeddings are precisely the quantales.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>partially ordered monoids</keyword>
      <keyword>injectives</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="334">

      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="84">

        <familyname locale="en">Kennison</familyname>

    <title locale="en">Biequivalences in tricategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that every internal biequivalence in a tricategory $T$ is part of a biadjoint biequivalence. We give two applications of this result, one for transporting monoidal structures and one for equipping a monoidal bicategory with invertible objects with a coherent choice of those inverses.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #395:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="395" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="395" filesize="393043" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/15/26-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Skew monoidales, skew warpings and quantum categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Kornel Szlachanyi recently used the term skew-monoidal category for a particular laxified version of monoidal category. He showed that bialgebroids $H$ with base ring $R$ could be characterized in terms of skew-monoidal structures on the category of one-sided $R$-modules for which the lax unit was $R$ itself. We define skew monoidales (or skew pseudo-monoids) in any monoidal bicategory $\cal M$. These are skew-monoidal categories when $\cal M$ is $Cat$. Our main results are presented at the level of monoidal bicategories. However, a consequence is that quantum categories with base comonoid $C$ in a suitably complete braided monoidal category $\CV$ are precisely skew monoidales in $Comod (\cal V)$ with unit coming from the counit of $C$. Quantum groupoids (in the sense of Chikhladze et al rather than Day and Street) are those skew monoidales with invertible associativity constraint. In fact, we provide some very general results connecting opmonoidal monads and skew monoidales. We use a lax version of the concept of warping defined by Booker and Street to modify monoidal structures. <p> Keywords: bialgebroid; fusion operator; quantum category; monoidal bicategory; monoidale; skew-monoidal category; comonoid; Hopf monadMEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>bialgebroid</keyword>
      <keyword>fusion operator</keyword>
      <keyword>quantum category</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidale</keyword>
      <keyword>skew-monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>comonoid</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf monad</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="35">
        <givenname locale="en">Stephen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lack</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="6">
        <givenname locale="en">Ross</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Street</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>

    <title locale="en">A presheaf interpretation of the generalized Freyd conjecture</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give a generalized version of the Freyd conjecture and a way to think about a possible proof. The essential point is to describe an elementary formal reduction of the question that holds in any triangulated category. There are no new results, but at least one known example drops out very easily.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #397:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="397" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="397" filesize="332168" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/17/26-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Range Categories I: General Theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this two-part paper, we undertake a systematic study of abstract partial map categories in which every map has both a restriction (domain of definition) and a range (image). In this first part, we explore connections with related structures such as inverse categories and allegories, and establish two representational results. The first of these explains how every range category can be fully and faithfully embedded into a category of partial maps equipped with a suitable factorization system. The second is a generalization of a result from semigroup theory by Boris Schein, and says that every small range category satisfying the additional condition that every map is an epimorphism onto its range can be faithfully embedded into the category of sets and partial functions with the usual notion of range. Finally, we give an explicit construction of the free range category on a partial map category in terms of certain types of labeled trees.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Categories of partial maps</keyword>
      <keyword>restriction category</keyword>
      <keyword>factorization systems</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="29">
        <givenname locale="en">J. R. B.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cockett</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Range categories II: Towards regularity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, which is the second part of a study of partial map categories with images, we investigate the interaction between images and various other kinds of categorical structure and properties. In particular, we consider images in the context of partial products, meets and discreteness and survey a taxonomy of structures leading towards the partial map categories of regular categories. We also present a term logic for cartesian partial map categories with images and prove a soundness and completeness theorem for this logic. Finally, we exhibit several free constructions relating the different classes of categories under consideration.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Opetopes and chain complexes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give a simple algebraic description of opetopes in terms of chain complexes, and we show how this description is related to combinatorial descriptions in terms of treelike structures. More generally, we show that the chain complexes associated to higher categories generate graphlike structures. The algebraic description gives a relationship between the opetopic approach and other approaches to higher category theory. It also gives an easy way to calculate the sources and targets of opetopes.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #400:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="400" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-20.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Modeling Stable One-Types</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Classification of homotopy $n$-types has focused on developing algebraic categories which are equivalent to categories of $n$-types. We expand this theory by providing algebraic models of homotopy-theoretic constructions for stable one-types. These include a model for the Postnikov one-truncation of the sphere spectrum, and for its action on the model of a stable one-type. We show that a bicategorical cokernel introduced by Vitale models the cofiber of a map between stable one-types, and apply this to develop an algebraic model for the Postnikov data of a stable one-type.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>stable homotopy one-type</keyword>
      <keyword>Picard groupoid</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #401:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Yoneda representations of flat functors and classifying toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We obtain semantic characterizations, holding for any Grothendieck site $(C, J)$, for the models of a theory classified by a topos of the form $Sh(C,J)$ in terms of the models of a theory classified by a topos $[C^{op}, Set]$. These characterizations arise from an appropriate representation of flat functors into Grothendieck toposes based on an application of the Yoneda Lemma in conjunction with ideas from indexed category theory, and turn out to be relevant also in different contexts, in particular for addressing questions in classical Model Theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Bimonadicity and the explicit basis property</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let ${L\dashv R:\cal X \rightarrow\cal Y}$ be an adjunction with $R$ monadic and $L$ comonadic. Denote the induced monad on $\cal Y$ by $M$ and the induced comonad on $\calX$ by $C$. We characterize those $C$ such that $M$ satisfies the Explicit Basis property. We also discuss some new examples and results motivated by this characterization.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #403:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="403" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-23.pdf</name>
    <file id="403" filesize="887076" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/23/26-23.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Duality and traces for indexed monoidal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;By the Lefschetz fixed point theorem, if an endomorphism of a topological space is fixed-point-free, then its Lefschetz number vanishes. This necessary condition is not usually sufficient, however; for that we need a refinement of the Lefschetz number called the Reidemeister trace. Abstractly, the Lefschetz number is a trace in a symmetric monoidal category, while the Reidemeister trace is a trace in a bicategory; in this paper we relate these contexts using indexed symmetric monoidal categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>duality</keyword>
      <keyword>trace</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>indexed category</keyword>
      <keyword>fiberwise duality</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="338">
        <givenname locale="en">Kate</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Ponto</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="256">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shulman</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Isotropy and Crossed Toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Motivated by constructions in the theory of inverse semigroups and etale groupoids, we define and investigate the concept of isotropy from a topos-theoretic perspective. Our main conceptual tool is a monad on the category of grouped toposes. Its algebras correspond to a generalized notion of crossed module, which we call a crossed topos. As an application, we present a topos-theoretic characterization and generalization of the `Clifford, fundamental' sequence associated with an inverse semigroup.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">Site characterizations for geometric invariants of toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We discuss the problem of characterizing the property of a Grothendieck topos to satisfy a given `geometric' invariant as a property of its sites of definition, and indicate a set of general techniques for establishing such criteria. We then apply our methodologies to specific invariants, notably including the property of a Grothendieck topos to be localic (resp. atomic, locally connected, equivalent to a presheaf topos), obtaining explicit site characterizations for them.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #406:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="406" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-26.pdf</name>
    <file id="406" filesize="302969" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/26/26-26.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Span, cospan, and other double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a double category $\mathbb D$ such that $\mathbb D_0$ has pushouts, we characterize oplax/lax adjunctions between $\mathbb D$ and $Cospan(\mathbb D_0)$ for which the right adjoint is normal and restricts to the identity on $\mathbb D_0$, where $Cospan(\mathbb D_0)$ is the double category on $\mathbb D_0$ whose vertical morphisms are cospans. We show that such a pair exists if and only if $\mathbb D$ has companions, conjoints, and 1-cotabulators. The right adjoints are induced by the companions and conjoints, and the left adjoints by the 1-cotabulators. The notion of a 1-cotabulator is a common generalization of the symmetric algebra of a module and Artin-Wraith glueing of toposes, locales, and topological spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>(co)span</keyword>
      <keyword>(co)tabulator</keyword>
      <keyword>companion</keyword>
      <keyword>conjoint</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric algebra</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Tangled circuits</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider <i>commutative Frobenius algebras in braided strict monoidal categories</i> in the study of the circuits and communicating systems which occur in Computer Science, including circuits in which the wires are tangled. We indicate also some possible novel geometric interest in such algebras. For example, we show how Armstrong's description of knot colourings and knot groups fit into this context.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #408:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="408" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">26-28.pdf</name>
    <file id="408" filesize="354913" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/26/28/26-28.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">D&eacute;calage and Kan's simplicial loop group functor</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a bisimplicial set, there are two ways to extract from it a simplicial set: the diagonal simplicial set and the less well known total simplicial set of Artin and Mazur. There is a natural comparison map between these simplicial sets, and it is a theorem due to Cegarra and Remedios and independently Joyal and Tierney, that this comparison map is a weak homotopy equivalence for any bisimplicial set. In this paper we will give a new, elementary proof of this result. As an application, we will revisit Kan's simplicial loop group functor $G$. We will give a simple formula for this functor, which is based on a factorization, due to Duskin, of Eilenberg and Mac Lane's classifying complex functor $\overline{W}$. We will give a new, short, proof of Kan's result that the unit map for the adjunction $G\dashv \overline{W}$ is a weak homotopy equivalence for reduced simplicial sets.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>simplicial loop group</keyword>
      <keyword>d\ {e}calage</keyword>
      <keyword>Artin-Mazur total simplicial set</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="340">
        <givenname locale="en">Danny</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Stevenson</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <title locale="en">Internal categories, anafunctors and localisations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this article we review the theory of anafunctors introduced by Makkai and Bartels, and show that given a subcanonical site $S$, one can form a bicategorical localisation of various 2-categories of internal categories or groupoids at weak equivalences using anafunctors as 1-arrows. This unifies a number of proofs throughout the literature, using the fewest assumptions possible on $S$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #410:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="410" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-01.pdf</name>
    <file id="410" filesize="287512" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/1/27-01.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Remarks on exactness notions pertaining to pushouts</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We call a finitely complete category <i>diexact</i> if every difunctional relation admits a pushout which is stable under pullback and itself a pullback. We prove three results relating to diexact categories: firstly, that a category is a pretopos if and only if it is diexact with a strict initial object; secondly, that a category is diexact if and only if it is Barr-exact, and every pair of monomorphisms admits a pushout which is stable and a pullback; and thirdly, that a small category with finite limits and pushouts of difunctional relations is diexact if and only if it admits a full structure-preserving embedding into a Grothendieck topos.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Exactness</keyword>
      <keyword>pushouts</keyword>
      <keyword>difunctional relation</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="342">
        <givenname locale="en">Richard</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Garner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #411:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="411" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-02.pdf</name>
    <file id="411" filesize="162270" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/2/27-02.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Exponentiability via double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a small category $B$ and a double category $\mathbb D$, let ${\rm Lax}_N(B,\mathbb D)$ denote the category whose objects are vertical normal lax functors $B\to\mathbb D$ and morphisms are horizontal lax transformations. It is well known that $Lax_N(B, \mathbb Cat) \simeq Cat/B$, where $\mathbb Cat$ is the double category of small categories, functors, and profunctors. We generalized this equivalence to certain double categories, in the case where $B$ is a finite poset. Street showed that $Y\to B$ is exponentiable in $Cat/B$ if and only if the corresponding normal lax functor $B\to \mathbb Cat$ is a pseudo-functor. Using our generalized equivalence, we show that a morphism $Y\to B$ is exponentiable in $ {\mathbb D}_0/B$ if and only if the corresponding normal lax functor $B\to\mathbb D$ is a pseudo-functor <i>plus</i> an additional condition that holds for all $X\to !B$ in $Cat$. Thus, we obtain a single theorem which yields characterizations of certain exponentiable morphisms of small categories, topological spaces, locales, and posets.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>exponentiable space</keyword>
      <keyword>function space</keyword>
      <keyword>lax slice</keyword>
      <keyword>specialization order</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="90">
        <givenname locale="en">Susan</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Niefield</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="411"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>27</volume>
      <year>2012</year>
      <title locale="en">CT2011</title>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>10-26</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #412:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="412" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-03.pdf</name>
    <file id="412" filesize="330361" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/3/27-03.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the axioms for adhesive and quasiadhesive categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A category is adhesive if it has all pullbacks, all push-outs along monomorphisms, and all exactness conditions between pullbacks and pushouts along monomorphisms which hold in a topos. This condition can be modified by considering only pushouts along regular monomorphisms, or by asking only for the exactness conditions which hold in a quasitopos. We prove four characterization theorems dealing with adhesive categories and their variants.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>adhesive category</keyword>
      <keyword>quasiadhesive category</keyword>
      <keyword>pushout</keyword>
      <keyword>exactness condition</keyword>
      <keyword>embedding theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="342">
        <givenname locale="en">Richard</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Garner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="35">
        <givenname locale="en">Stephen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lack</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The core of adjoint functors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;There is a lot of redundancy in the usual definition of adjoint functors. We define and prove the core of what is required. First we do this in the hom-enriched context. Then we do it in the cocompletion of a bicategory with respect to Kleisli objects, which we then apply to internal categories. Finally, we describe a doctrinal setting.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #414:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="414" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="414" filesize="381069" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/5/27-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Weakly Mal'tsev categories and strong relations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a <i>strong relation</i> in a category $\mathbb{C}$ to be a span which is ``orthogonal'' to the class of jointly epimorphic pairs of morphisms. Under the presence of finite limits, a strong relation is simply a strong monomorphism $R\rightarrow X\times Y$. We show that a category $\mathbb{C}$ with pullbacks and equalizers is a weakly Mal'tsev category if and only if every reflexive strong relation in $\mathbb{C}$ is an equivalence relation. In fact, we obtain a more general result which includes, as its another particular instance, a similar well-known characterization of Mal'tsev categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>weakly Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>difunctional relation</keyword>
      <keyword>factorization system</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="142">

        <familyname locale="en">Janelidze</familyname>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Symmetry of regular diamonds, the Goursat property, and subtractivity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We investigate $3$-permutability, in the sense of universal algebra, in an abstract categorical setting which unifies the pointed and the non-pointed contexts in categorical algebra. This leads to a unified treatment of regular subtractive categories and of regular Goursat categories, as well as of $E$-subtractive varieties (where $E$ is the set of constants in a variety) recently introduced by the fourth author. As an application, we show that ``ideals'' coincide with ``clots'' in any regular subtractive category, which can be considered as a pointed analogue of a known result for regular Goursat categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    </file>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Exact completions and small sheaves</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove a general theorem which includes most notions of &quot;exact completion&quot; as special cases. The theorem is that &quot;&kappa;-ary exact categories&quot; are a reflective sub-2-category of &quot;&kappa;-ary sites&quot;, for any regular cardinal &kappa;. A &kappa;-ary exact category is an exact category with disjoint and universal &kappa;-small coproducts, and a &kappa;-ary site is a site whose covering sieves are generated by &kappa;-small families and which satisfies a solution-set condition for finite limits relative to &kappa;.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>exact completion</keyword>
      <keyword>site</keyword>

      <keyword>exact category</keyword>
      <keyword>pretopos</keyword>
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="417" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-08.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Ursini commutator as normalized Smith-Pedicchio commutator</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce an intrinsic description of the Ursini commutator in any ideal determined category and we compare it with the Higgins and Huq commutators. After describing also the Smith-Pedicchio commutator by means of canonical arrows from a coproduct, we compare the two notions, showing that in any exact Mal'tsev normal category the Ursini commutator $[H,K]_{U}$ of two subobjects $H, K$ of $A$ is the normalization of the Smith-Pedicchio commutator of the equivalence relations generated by $H$ and $K$, extending the result valid for ideal determined varieties given by Ursini and Gumm.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>ideal determined category</keyword>
      <keyword>exact Mal tsev category</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #418:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="418" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-09.pdf</name>
    <file id="418" filesize="422704" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/9/27-09.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Higher central extensions via commutators</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove that all semi-abelian categories with the the <i>Smith is Huq</i> property satisfy the <i>Commutator Condition</i>(CC): higher central extensions may be characterised in terms of binary (Huq or Smith) commutators. In fact, even Higgins commutators suffice. As a consequence, in the presence of enough projectives we obtain explicit Hopf formulae for homology with coefficients in the abelianisation functor, and an interpretation of cohomology with coefficients in an abelian object in terms of equivalence classes of higher central extensions. We also give a counterexample against (CC) in the semi-abelian category of (commutative) loops.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Higgins</keyword>
      <keyword>Huq</keyword>
      <keyword>Smith commutator</keyword>
      <keyword>higher central extension</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-abelian</keyword>
      <keyword>exact Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf formula</keyword>
      <keyword>(co)homology</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="156">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Descent in monoidal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider a symmetric monoidal closed category $V = (V, \otimes, I, [-,-])$ together with a regular injective object $Q$ such that the functor $[-, Q] : \to V^{op}$ is comonadic and prove that in such a category, as in the monoidal category of abelian groups, a morphism of commutative monoids is an effective descent morphism for modules if and only if it is a pure monomorphism. Examples of this kind of monoidal categories are elementary toposes considered as cartesian closed monoidal categories, the module categories over a commutative ring object in a Grothendieck topos and Barr's star-autonomous categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal categories</keyword>
      <keyword>effective descent morphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>pure morphisms</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Lawvere completeness as a topological property</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Lawvere's notion of completeness for quantale-enriched categories has been extended to the theory of lax algebras under the name of L-completeness. In this paper we introduce the corresponding morphism concept and examine its properties. We explore some important relativized topological concepts like separatedness, denseness, compactness and compactification with respect to L-complete morphisms. Moreover, we show that separated L-complete morphisms belong to a factorization system.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

FILE #422:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Generalized Hopf modules for bimonads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Brugui&egrave;res, Lack and Virelizier have recently obtained a vast generalization of Sweedler's <i>Fundamental Theorem of Hopf modules</i>, in which the role of the Hopf algebra is played by a bimonad. We present an extension of this result which involves, in addition to the bimonad, a comodule-monad and a algebra-comonoid over it. As an application we obtain a generalization of another classical theorem from the Hopf algebra literature, due to Schneider, which itself is an extension of Sweedler's result (to the setting of Hopf Galois extensions).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

    <title locale="en">Proper maps for lax algebras and the Kuratowski-Mr&oacute;wka theorem</title>

FILE #424:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="424" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">27-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="424" filesize="554177" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/27/15/27-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On actions and strict actions in homological categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let $G$ be an object of a finitely cocomplete homological category $\mathbb C$. We study actions of $G$ on objects $A$ of $\mathbb C$ (defined by Bourn and Janelidze as being algebras over a certain monad $\mathbb T_G$), with two objectives: investigating to which extent actions can be described in terms of smaller data, called action cores; and to single out those abstract action cores which extend to actions corresponding to semi-direct products of $A$ and $G$ (in a non-exact setting, not every action does). This amounts to exhibiting a subcategory of the category of the actions of $G$ on objects $A$ which is equivalent with the category of points in $\mathbb C$ over $G$, and to describing it in terms of action cores. This notion and its study are based on a preliminary investigation of co-smash products, in which cross-effects of functors in a general categorical context turn out to be a useful tool. The co-smash products also allow us to define higher categorical commutators, different from the ones of Huq, which are not generally expressible in terms of nested binary ones. We use strict action cores to show that any normal subobject of an object $E$ (i.e., the equivalence class of $0$ for some equivalence relation on $E$ in $\mathbb C$) admits a strict conjugation action of $E$. If $\mathbb C$ is semi-abelian, we show that for subobjects $X$, $Y$ of some object $A$, $X$ is proper in the supremum of $X$ and $Y$ if and only if $X$ is stable under the restriction to $Y$ of the conjugation action of $A$ on itself. This also amounts to an alternative proof of Bourn and Janelidze's category equivalence between points over $G$ in $\mathbb C$ and actions of $G$ in the semi-abelian context. Finally, we show that the two axioms of an algebra which characterize $G$-actions are equivalent with three others ones, in terms of action cores. These axioms are commutative squares involving only co-smash products. Two of them are associativity type conditions which generalize the usual properties of an action of one group on another, while the third is kind of a higher coherence condition which is a consequence of the other two in the category of groups, but probably not in general. As an application, we characterize abelian action cores, that is, action cores corresponding to Beck modules; here also the coherence condition follows from the others.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>action</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-direct product</keyword>
      <keyword>conjugation</keyword>
      <keyword>normal subobject</keyword>
      <keyword>ideal</keyword>
      <keyword>commutator</keyword>
      <keyword>homological category</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-abelian category</keyword>
      <keyword>algebra over monad</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="348">
        <givenname locale="en">Manfred</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Hartl</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="349">
        <givenname locale="en">Bruno</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Loiseau</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Composition of Modules for Lax Functors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the composition of modules between lax functors of weak double categories. We adapt the bicategorical notion of local cocompleteness to weak double categories, which the codomain of our lax functors will be assumed to satisfy. We introduce a notion of factorization of cells, which most weak double categories of interest possess, and which is sufficient to guarantee the strong representability of composites of modules between lax functors whose domain satisfies it.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Elementary quotient completion</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We extend the notion of exact completion on a category with weak finite limits to Lawvere's elementary doctrines. We show how any such doctrine admits an elementary quotient completion, which is the universal solution to adding certain quotients. We note that the elementary quotient completion can be obtained as the composite of two other universal constructions: one adds effective quotients, the other forces extensionality of morphisms. We also prove that each construction preserves comprehension.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
