    <title locale="en">An equational metalogic for monadic equational systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The paper presents algebraic and logical developments. From the algebraic viewpoint, we introduce Monadic Equational Systems as an abstract enriched notion of equational presentation. From the logical viewpoint, we provide Equational Metalogic as a general formal deductive system for the derivability of equational consequences. Relating the two, a canonical model theory for Monadic Equational Systems is given and for it the soundness of Equational Metalogic is established. This development involves a study of clone and double-dualization structures. We also show that in the presence of free algebras %constructions the model theory of Monadic Equational Systems satisfies an internal strong-completeness property.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Free products of higher operad algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;One of the open problems in higher category theory is the systematic construction of the higher dimensional analogues of the Gray tensor product of 2-categories. In this paper we continue the developments of [Batanin-Weber, 2011], [Weber, 2011] and [Batanin-Cisinski-Weber, 2011] by understanding the natural generalisations of Gray's little brother, the funny tensor product of categories. In fact we exhibit for any higher categorical structure definable by a normalised n-operad in the sense of Batanin, an analogous tensor product which forms a symmetric monoidal closed structure on the category of algebras of the operad.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>higher categories</keyword>

    </keywords>

FILE #430:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="430" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-03.pdf</name>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Duality for distributive spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The main source of inspiration for the present paper is the work of R. Rosebrugh and R.J. Wood on constructively completely distributive lattices where the authors elegantly employ the concepts of adjunction and module. Both notions (suitably adapted) are available in topology too, which permits us to investigate topological, metric and other kinds of spaces in a similar spirit. We introduce here the notion of distributive space and algebraic space and show in particular that the category of distributive spaces and colimit preserving maps is dually equivalent to the idempotent split completion of a category of spaces and convergence relations between them. We explain the connection of this result to the well-known duality between topological spaces and frames, and deduce further duality theorems.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>approach space</keyword>
      <keyword>ultrafilter monad</keyword>

      <keyword>module</keyword>
      <keyword>cocompleteness</keyword>
      <keyword>distributivity</keyword>
      <keyword>duality theory</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Semiunital semimonoidal categories (Applications to semirings and semicorings)</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The category $_{A}\mathbb{S}_{A}$ of bisemimodules over a semialgebra $A,$ with the so called <i>Takahashi's tensor-like product</i> $-\boxtimes _{A}-,$ is semimonoidal but <i>not</i> monoidal. Although not a unit in $_{A}\mathbb{S}% _{A},$ the base semialgebra $A$ has properties of a <i>semiunit</i> (in a sense which we clarify in this note). Motivated by this interesting example, we investigate <i>semiunital semimonoidal categories</i> $(\mathcal{V}% ,\bullet ,\mathbf{I})$ as a framework for studying notions like <i>semimonoids (semicomonoids)</i> as well as a notion of monads (comonads) which we call $\mathbb{J}$-<i>monads</i> ($\mathbb{J}$-<i>comonads</i>) with respect to the endo-functor $\mathbb{J}:=\mathbf{I}\bullet -\simeq -\bullet \mathbf{I}:\mathcal{V}\longrightarrow \mathcal{V}.$ This motivated also introducing a more generalized notion of monads (comonads) in arbitrary categories with respect to arbitrary endo-functors. Applications to the semiunital semimonoidal variety $(_{A}\mathbb{S}_{A},\boxtimes _{A},A) $ provide us with examples of semiunital $A$-semirings (semicounital $A$-semicorings) and semiunitary semimodules (semicounitary semicomodules) which extend the classical notions of unital rings (counital corings) and unitary modules (counitary comodules).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Semimonoidal Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Semiunits</keyword>
      <keyword>Monads</keyword>
      <keyword>Comonads</keyword>
      <keyword>Semirings</keyword>
      <keyword>Semimodules</keyword>
      <keyword>Semicorings</keyword>
      <keyword>Semicomodules</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="351">
        <givenname locale="en">Jawad</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Abuhlail</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">On the monad of internal groupoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We deeply analyse the structural organisation of the fibration of points and of the monad of internal groupoids. From that we derive: 1) a new characterization of internal groupoids among reflexive graphs in the Mal'cev context; 2) a setting in which a Mal'cev category is necessarily a protomodular category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #433:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="433" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="433" filesize="541346" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/6/28-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tannaka duality and convolution for duoidal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a horizontal monoid $M$ in a duoidal category $\cal F$, we examine the relationship between bimonoid structures on $M$ and monoidal structures on the category $\cal F^{\ast M}$ of right $M$-modules which lift the vertical monoidal structure of $\cal F$. We obtain our result using a variant of the so-called Tannaka adjunction; that is, an adjunction inducing the equivalence which expresses Tannaka duality. The approach taken utilizes hom-enriched categories rather than categories on which a monoidal category acts (``actegories''). The requirement of enrichment in $\cal F$ itself demands the existence of some internal homs, leading to the consideration of convolution for duoidal categories. Proving that certain hom-functors are monoidal, and so take monoids to monoids, unifies classical convolution in algebra and Day convolution for categories. Hopf bimonoids are defined leading to a lifting of closed structures on $\cal F$ to $\cal F^{\ast M}$. We introduce the concept of warping monoidal structures and this permits the construction of new duoidal categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>duoidal</keyword>
      <keyword>duoid</keyword>
      <keyword>bimonoid</keyword>
      <keyword>Tannaka duality</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>closed category</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf monoid</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="352">

FILE #435:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="435" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="435" filesize="419881" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/8/28-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tightly Bounded Completions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;By a `completion' on a 2-category K we mean here an idempotent pseudomonad on K. We are particularly interested in pseudomonads that arise from KZ-doctrines. Motivated by a question of Lawvere, we compare the Cauchy completion, defined in the setting of V-Cat for V a symmetric monoidal closed category, with the Grothendieck completion, defined in the setting of S-Indexed Cat for S a topos. To this end we introduce a unified setting (`indexed enriched category theory') in which to formulate and study certain properties of KZ-doctrines. We find that, whereas all of the KZ-doctrines that are relevant to this discussion (Karoubi, Cauchy, Stack, Grothendieck) may be regarded as `bounded', only the Cauchy and the Grothendieck completions are `tightly bounded' - two notions that we introduce and study in this paper. Tightly bounded KZ-doctrines are shown to be idempotent. We also show, in a different approach to answering the motivating question, that the Cauchy completion (defined using `distributors') and the Grothendieck completion (defined using `generalized functors') are actually equivalent constructions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>2-categories</keyword>
      <keyword>KZ-doctrines</keyword>
      <keyword>completions</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category theory</keyword>
      <keyword>indexed categories</keyword>
      <keyword>distributors</keyword>
      <keyword>generalized functors</keyword>
      <keyword>Karoubi envelope</keyword>
      <keyword>Stack completion</keyword>
      <keyword>Cauchy completion</keyword>
      <keyword>Grothendieck completion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="233">
        <givenname locale="en">Marta</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bunge</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en"></title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that every geometric morphism between realizability toposes satisfies the condition that its inverse image commutes with the `constant object' functors, which was assumed by John Longley in his pioneering study of such morphisms. We also provide the answer to something which was stated as an open problem on Jaap van Oosten's book on realizability toposes: if a subtopos of a realizability topos is (co)complete, it must be either the topos of sets or the degenerate topos. And we present a new and simpler condition equivalent to the notion of computational density for applicative morphisms of Schonfinkel algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en"></title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The category of bisimplicial presheaves carries a model structure for which the weak equivalences are defined by the diagonal functor and the cofibrations are monomorphisms. This model structure has the most cofibrations of a large family of model structures with weak equivalences defined by the diagonal. The diagonal structure for bisimplicial presheaves specializes to a diagonal model structure for bisimplicial sets, for which the fibrations are the Kan fibrations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Homotopy theories of diagrams</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Suppose that S is a space. There is an injective and a projective model structure for the resulting category of spaces with S-action, and both are easily derived. These model structures are special cases of model structures for presheaf-valued diagrams $X$ defined on a fixed presheaf of categories E which is enriched in simplicial sets.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">n-tuple groupoids and optimally coupled factorizations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we prove that the category of vacant $n$-tuple groupoids is equivalent to the category of factorizations of groupoids by $n$ factors that satisfy some Yang-Baxter type equation. Moreover we extend this equivalence to the category of maximally exclusive $n$-tuple groupoids, which we define, by dropping one assumption. The paper concludes by a note on how these results could tell us more about some Lie groups of interest.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #440:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="440" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-13.pdf</name>
    <file id="440" filesize="562470" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/13/28-13.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Codensity and the ultrafilter monad</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Even a functor without an adjoint induces a monad, namely, its codensity monad; this is subject only to the existence of certain limits. We clarify the sense in which codensity monads act as substitutes for monads induced by adjunctions. We also expand on an undeservedly ignored theorem of Kennison and Gildenhuys: that the codensity monad of the inclusion of (finite sets) into (sets) is the ultrafilter monad. This result is analogous to the correspondence between measures and integrals. So, for example, we can speak of integration against an ultrafilter. Using this language, we show that the codensity monad of the inclusion of (finite-dimensional vector spaces) into (vector spaces) is double dualization. From this it follows that compact Hausdorff spaces have a linear analogue: linearly compact vector spaces. Finally, we show that ultra<i>products</i> are categorically inevitable: the codensity monad of the inclusion of (finite families of sets) into (families of sets) is the ultraproduct monad.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>density</keyword>
      <keyword>codensity</keyword>
      <keyword>monad</keyword>
      <keyword>ultrafilter</keyword>
      <keyword>ultraproduct</keyword>
      <keyword>integration</keyword>
      <keyword>compact Hausdorff space</keyword>
      <keyword>double dual</keyword>
      <keyword>linearly compact vector space</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="119">
        <givenname locale="en">Tom</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Leinster</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #441:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="441" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="441" filesize="465087" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/14/28-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">No-iteration pseudomonads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present the no-iteration version of the coherence conditions necessary to define a pseudomonad, and a description of the algebras for it in a similar fashion. We show that every no-iteration pseudomonad induces a pseudomonad, and that the corresponding algebras are equivalent. We also show that every pseudomonad induces a no-iteration pseudomonad, and again, that the corresponding algebras are equivalent. We conclude with an analysis of the algebras for the 2-monad $(-)^{\mathbf{2}}$ on <b>Cat</b> in the light of the no-iteration description of the algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

    <title locale="en">Tensors, monads and actions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We exhibit sufficient conditions for a monoidal monad $T$ on a monoidal category $C$ to induce a monoidal structure on the Eilenberg--Moore category $C^T$ that represents bimorphisms. The category of actions in $C^T$ is then shown to be monadic over the base category $C$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #443:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="443" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="443" filesize="517744" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/16/28-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Bounded Archimedean l-algebras and Gelfand-Neumark-Stone duality</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;By Gelfand-Neumark duality, the category $C^*Alg$ of commutative $C^*$-algebras is dually equivalent to the category of compact Hausdorff spaces, which by Stone duality, is also dually equivalent to the category $ubal$ of uniformly complete bounded Archimedean $\ell$-algebras. Consequently, $C^*Alg$ is equivalent to $ubal$, and this equivalence can be described through complexification. <p> In this article we study $ubal$ within the larger category $bal$ of bounded Archimedean $\ell$-algebras. We show that $ubal$ is the smallest nontrivial reflective subcategory of $bal$, and that $ubal$ consists of exactly those objects in $bal$ that are epicomplete, a fact that includes a categorical formulation of the Stone-Weierstrass theorem for $bal$. It follows that $ubal$ is the unique nontrivial reflective epicomplete subcategory of $bal$. We also show that each nontrivial reflective subcategory of $bal$ is both monoreflective and epireflective, and exhibit two other interesting reflective subcategories of $bal$ involving Gelfand rings and square closed rings. <p> Dually, we show that Specker ${\mathbb R}$-algebras are precisely the co-epicomplete objects in $bal$. We prove that the category $spec$ of Specker $\mathbb R$-algebras is a mono-coreflective subcategory of $bal$ that is co-epireflective in a mono-coreflective subcategory of $bal$ consisting of what we term $\ell$-clean rings, a version of clean rings adapted to the order-theoretic setting of $bal$. <p> We conclude the article by discussing the import of our results in the setting of complex $*$-algebras through complexification.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Ring of continuous real-valued functions</keyword>
      <keyword>l-ring</keyword>
      <keyword>l-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>uniform completeness</keyword>
      <keyword>Stone-Weierstrass theorem</keyword>
      <keyword>commutative $C^*$-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>compact Hausdorff space</keyword>
      <keyword>Gelfand-Neumark-Stone duality</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="356">
        <givenname locale="en">Guram</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Bezhanishvili</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="357">
        <givenname locale="en">Patrick J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Morandi</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="358">
        <givenname locale="en">Bruce</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Olberding</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #444:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="444" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="444" filesize="630058" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/17/28-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Connections on non-Abelian gerbes and their holonomy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce an axiomatic framework for the parallel transport of connections on gerbes. It incorporates parallel transport along curves and along surfaces, and is formulated in terms of gluing axioms and smoothness conditions. The smoothness conditions are imposed with respect to a strict Lie 2-group, which plays the role of a band, or structure 2-group. Upon choosing certain examples of Lie 2-groups, our axiomatic framework reproduces in a systematical way several known concepts of gerbes with connection: non-abelian differential cocycles, Breen-Messing gerbes, abelian and non-abelian bundle gerbes. These relationships convey a well-defined notion of surface holonomy from our axiomatic framework to each of these concrete models. Till now, holonomy was only known for abelian gerbes; our approach reproduces that known concept and extends it to non-abelian gerbes. Several new features of surface holonomy are exposed under its extension to non-abelian gerbes; for example, it carries an action of the mapping class group of the surface.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Parallel transport</keyword>
      <keyword>surface holonomy</keyword>
      <keyword>path 2-groupoid</keyword>
      <keyword>gerbes</keyword>
      <keyword>2-bundles</keyword>
      <keyword>2-groups</keyword>
      <keyword>non-abelian differential cohomology</keyword>
      <keyword>non-abelian bundle gerbes</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="359">

        <familyname locale="en">Schreiber</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Subgroupoids and Quotient Theories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Moerdijk's site description for equivariant sheaf toposes on open topological groupoids is used to give a proof for the (known, but apparently unpublished) proposition that if $H$ is a subgroupoid of an open topological groupoid $G$, then the topos of equivariant sheaves on $H$ is a subtopos of the topos of equivariant sheaves on $G$. This proposition is then applied to the study of quotient geometric theories and subtoposes. In particular, an intrinsic characterization is given of those subgroupoids that are definable by quotient theories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Sur les types d'homotopie mod&eacute;lis&eacute;s par les $\infty$-groupoides stricts</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;which are modelized by strict $\infty$-groupoids. We show that the homotopy category of simply connected strict $\infty$-groupoids is equivalent to the derived category in homological degree $d \ge 2$ of abelian groups. We deduce that the simply connected homotopy types modelized by strict $\infty$-groupoids are precisely the products of Eilenberg-Mac Lane spaces. We also briefly study 3-categories with weak inverses. We finish by two questions about the problem suggested by the title of this text.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #447:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <name locale="en">28-20.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categories enriched over a quantaloid: Isbell adjunctions and Kan adjunctions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Each distributor between categories enriched over a small quantaloid Q gives rise to two adjunctions between the categories of contravariant and covariant presheaves, and hence to two monads. These two adjunctions are respectively generalizations of Isbell adjunctions and Kan extensions in category theory. It is proved that these two processes are functorial with infomorphisms playing as morphisms between distributors; and that the free cocompletion functor of Q-categories factors through both of these functors.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>Isbell adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan adjunction</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #448:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="448" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Enriched indexed categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We develop a theory of categories which are simultaneously (1) indexed over a base category $S$ with finite products, and (2) enriched over an $S$-indexed monoidal category $V$. This includes classical enriched categories, indexed and fibered categories, and internal categories as special cases. We then describe the appropriate notion of ``limit'' for such enriched indexed categories, and show that they admit ``free cocompletions'' constructed as usual with a Yoneda embedding.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #449:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="449" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="449" filesize="528102" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/22/28-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tight spans, Isbell completions and semi-tropical modules</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we consider generalized metric spaces in the sense of Lawvere and the categorical Isbell completion construction. We show that this is an analogue of the tight span construction of classical metric spaces, and that the Isbell completion coincides with the directed tight span of Hirai and Koichi. The notions of categorical completion and cocompletion are related to the existence of semi-tropical module structure, and it is shown that the Isbell completion (hence the directed tight span) has two different semi-tropical module structures.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>Metric spaces</keyword>
      <keyword>tropical algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>injective hull</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #450:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="450" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-23.pdf</name>
    <file id="450" filesize="418131" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/23/28-23.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The algebra of the nerves of omega-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the nerve of a strict omega-category can be described algebraically as a simplicial set with additional operations subject to certain identities. The resulting structures are called sets with complicial identities. We also construct an equivalence between the categories of strict omega-categories and of sets with complical identities.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>complicial identities</keyword>
      <keyword>omega-category</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/24/28-24.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Complicial structures in the nerves of omega-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is known that strict omega-categories are equivalent through the nerve functor to complicial sets and to sets with complicial identities. It follows that complicial sets are equivalent to sets with complicial identities. We discuss these equivalences. In particular we give a conceptual proof that the nerves of omega-categories are complicial sets, and a direct proof that complicial sets are sets with complicial identities.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>complicial set</keyword>
      <keyword>complicial identities</keyword>
      <keyword>omega-category</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #452:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="452" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-25.pdf</name>
    <file id="452" filesize="588896" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/25/28-25.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Multitensor lifting and strictly unital higher category theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this article we extend the theory of lax monoidal structures, also known as multitensors, and the monads on categories of enriched graphs that they give rise to. Our first principal result - the lifting theorem for multitensors - enables us to see the Gray tensor product of 2-categories and the Crans tensor product of Gray categories as part of this framework. We define weak $n$-categories with strict units by means of a notion of reduced higher operad, using the theory of algebraic weak factorisation systems. Our second principal result is to establish a lax tensor product on the category of weak $n$-categories with strict units, so that enriched categories with respect to this tensor product are exactly weak (n+1)-categories with strict units.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>multitensors</keyword>
      <keyword>strictly unital higher categories</keyword>
      <keyword>higher operads</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Multitensors as monads on categories of enriched graphs</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we unify the developments of Batanin [1998], Batanin-Weber [2011] and Cheng [2011] into a single framework in which the interplay between multitensors on a category $V$, and monads on the category $\cal G V$ of graphs enriched in $V$, is taken as fundamental. The material presented here is the conceptual background for subsequent work: in Batanin-Cisinski-Weber [2013] the Gray tensor product of 2-categories and the Crans [1999] tensor product of Gray categories are exhibited as existing within our framework, and in Weber [2013] the explicit construction of the funny tensor product of categories is generalised to a large class of Batanin operads.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">A double categorical model of weak 2-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce the notion of weakly globular double categories, a particular class of strict double categories, as a way to model weak 2-categories. We show that this model is suitably equivalent to bicategories and give an explicit description of the functors involved in this biequivalence. As an application we show that groupoidal weakly globular double categories model homotopy 2-types.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Forms and exterior differentiation in Cartesian differential categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Cartesian differential categories abstractly capture the notion of a differentiation operation. In this paper, we develop some of the theory of such categories by defining differential forms and exterior differentiation in this setting. We show that this exterior derivative, as expected, produces a cochain complex.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Relative Mal'tsev categories</title>

FILE #457:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="457" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-30.pdf</name>
    <file id="457" filesize="743432" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/30/28-30.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On theories of superalgebras of differentiable functions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This is the first in a series of papers laying the foundations for a differential graded approach to derived differential geometry (and other geometries in characteristic zero). In this paper, we study theories of supercommutative algebras for which infinitely differentiable functions can be evaluated on elements. Such a theory is called a <i>super Fermat theory.</i> Any category of superspaces and smooth functions has an associated such theory. This includes both real and complex supermanifolds, as well as algebraic superschemes. In particular, there is a super Fermat theory of <i>$C^\infty$-superalgebras.</i> $C^\infty$-superalgebras are the appropriate notion of supercommutative algebras in the world of $C^\infty$-rings, the latter being of central importance both to synthetic differential geometry and to all existing models of derived smooth manifolds. A super Fermat theory is a natural generalization of the concept of a Fermat theory introduced by E. Dubuc and A. Kock. We show that any Fermat theory admits a canonical <i>superization,</i> however not every super Fermat theory arises in this way. For a fixed super Fermat theory, we go on to study a special subcategory of algebras called near-point determined algebras, and derive many of their algebraic properties.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>$C^\infty$-ring</keyword>
      <keyword>Lawvere theory</keyword>
      <keyword>superalgebra</keyword>
      <keyword>supergeometry</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="369">
        <givenname locale="en">David</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Carchedi</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="370">
        <givenname locale="en">Dmitry</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Roytenberg</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="458" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="458" filesize="482296" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/31/28-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tannaka--Krein duality for compact quantum homogeneous spaces. I. General theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;An ergodic action of a compact quantum group $G$ on an operator algebra $A$ can be interpreted as a quantum homogeneous space for $G$. Such an action gives rise to the category of finite equivariant Hilbert modules over $A$, which has a module structure over the tensor category $Rep(G)$ of finite-dimensional representations of $G$. We show that there is a one-to-one correspondence between the quantum $G$-homogeneous spaces up to equivariant Morita equivalence, and indecomposable module $C^*$-categories over $Rep(G)$ up to natural equivalence. This gives a global approach to the duality theory for ergodic actions as developed by C. Pinzari and J. Roberts.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>compact quantum groups</keyword>
      <keyword>$C^*$-algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>Hilbert modules</keyword>
      <keyword>ergodic actions</keyword>
      <keyword>module categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

        <familyname locale="en">Commer</familyname>

FILE #459:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="459" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">28-32.pdf</name>
    <file id="459" filesize="334173" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/28/32/28-32.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Gleason cover of a realizability topos</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Recently Benno~van~den~Berg introduced a new class of realizability toposes which he christened Herbrand toposes. These toposes have strikingly different properties from ordinary realizability toposes, notably the (related) properties that the `constant object' functor from the topos of sets preserves finite coproducts, and that De Morgan's law is satisfied. In this paper we show that these properties are no accident: for any Schonfinkel algebra $\Lambda$, the Herbrand realizability topos over $\Lambda$ may be obtained as the Gleason cover (in the sense of Johnstone (1980)) of the ordinary realizability topos over $\Lambda$. As a corollary, we obtain the functoriality of the Herbrand realizability construction on the category of Schonfinkel algebras and computationally dense applicative morphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2013</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>realizability topos</keyword>
      <keyword>De Morgan topos</keyword>
      <keyword>Gleason cover</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="51">
        <givenname locale="en">Peter</givenname>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Galois theories of commutative semigroups via semilattices</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The classes of stably-vertical, normal, separable, inseparable, purely inseparable and covering morphisms, defined in categorical Galois theory, are characterized for the reflection of the variety of commutative semigroups into its subvariety of semilattices. It is also shown that there is an inseparable-separable factorization, but there is no monotone-light factorization.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #461:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="461" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-01.pdf</name>
    <file id="461" filesize="317072" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/1/29-01.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Some stability properties of epimorphism classes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is proved that in any pointed category with pullbacks, coequalizers and regular epi-mono factorizations, the class of regular epimorphisms is stable under pullback along the so-called balanced effective descent morphisms. Here ``balanced'' can be omitted if the category is additive. A balanced effective descent morphism is defined as an effective descent morphism $p:E\rightarrow B$ such that any subobject of $E$ is a pullback of some morphism along $p$. It is shown that, in any category with pullbacks and coequalizers, the class of effective descent morphisms is stable under pushout if and only if any regular epimorphism is an effective descent morphism. Moreover, it is shown that the class of descent morphisms is stable under pushout if and only if the class of regular epimorphisms is stable under pullback.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>(effective) descent morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>balanced morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>factorization system</keyword>
      <keyword>stability under pullback/pushout</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="152">
        <givenname locale="en">Dali</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Zangurashvili</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #462:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="462" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">25-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="462" filesize="308412" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/25/12/25-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Towards a homotopy theory of higher dimensional transition systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We proved in a previous work that Cattani-Sassone's higher dimensional transition systems can be interpreted as a small-orthogonality class of a topological locally finitely presentable category of weak higher dimensional transition systems. In this paper, we turn our attention to the full subcategory of weak higher dimensional transition systems which are unions of cubes. It is proved that there exists a left proper combinatorial model structure such that two objects are weakly equivalent if and only if they have the same cubes after simplification of the labelling. This model structure is obtained by Bousfield localizing a model structure which is left determined with respect to a class of maps which is not the class of monomorphisms. We prove that the higher dimensional transition systems corresponding to two process algebras are weakly equivalent if and only if they are isomorphic. We also construct a second Bousfield localization in which two bisimilar cubical transition systems are weakly equivalent. The appendix contains a technical lemma about smallness of weak factorization systems in coreflective subcategories which can be of independent interest. This paper is a first step towards a homotopical interpretation of bisimulation for higher dimensional transition systems.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2012</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>higher dimensional transition system</keyword>
      <keyword>locally presentable category</keyword>
      <keyword>topological category</keyword>
      <keyword>combinatorial model category</keyword>
      <keyword>left determined model category</keyword>
      <keyword>Bousfield localization</keyword>
      <keyword>bisimulation</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="100">
        <givenname locale="en">Philippe</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Gaucher</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Erratum to `Towards a homotopy theory of higher dimensional transition systems'</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Counterexamples for Proposition~8.1 and Proposition~8.2 in the article <i>Theor. Appl. Categ. 25(2011), pp 295-341</i> are given. They are used in the paper only to prove Corollary~8.3. A proof of this corollary is given without them. The proof of the fibrancy of some cubical transition systems is fixed.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the image of the almost strict Morse n-category under almost strict n-functors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In an earlier work, we constructed the almost strict Morse n-category $\mathcal X$ which extends Cohen and Jones and Segal's flow category. In this article, we define two other almost strict n-categories $\mathcal V$ and $\mathcal W$ where $\mathcal V$ is based on homomorphisms between real vector spaces and $\mathcal W$ consists of tuples of positive integers. The Morse index and the dimension of the Morse moduli spaces give rise to almost strict n-category functors $\mathcal F : \mathcal X \to \mathcal V$ and $\mathcal G : \mathcal X \to \mathcal W$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #465:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="465" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-04.pdf</name>
    <file id="465" filesize="1100104" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/4/29-04.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Obvious natural morphisms of sheaves are unique</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove that a large class of natural transformations (consisting roughly of those constructed via composition from the ``functorial'' or ``base change'' transformations) between two functors of the form $... f^* g_* ...$ actually has only one element, and thus that any diagram of such maps necessarily commutes. We identify the precise axioms defining what we call a ``geofibered category'' that ensure that such a coherence theorem exists. Our results apply to all the usual sheaf-theoretic contexts of algebraic geometry. The analogous result that would include any other of the six functors remains unknown.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>commutative diagrams</keyword>
      <keyword>coherence theorem</keyword>
      <keyword>string diagrams</keyword>
      <keyword>pullback</keyword>
      <keyword>pushforward</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="375">
        <givenname locale="en">Ryan Cohen</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Reich</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Mapping Spaces of Gray-Categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a mapping space for Gray-enriched categories adapted to higher gauge theory. Our construction differs significantly from the canonical mapping space of enriched categories in that it is much less rigid. The two essential ingredients are a path space construction for Gray-categories and a kind of comonadic resolution of the 1-dimensional structure of a given Gray-category obtained by lifting the resolution of ordinary categories along the canonical fibration of GrayCat over Cat.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Analytic spectrum of rig categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define the analytic spectrum of a rig category $(A,\oplus,\otimes)$, and equip it with a sheaf of categories of rational functions. If the category is additive, we define a sheaf of categories of analytic functions. We relate this construction to Berkovich's analytic spaces, to Durov's generalized schemes and to Haran's F-schemes. We use these relations to define analytic versions of Arakelov compactifications of affine arithmetic varieties.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">A Galois theory for monoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the adjunction between monoids and groups obtained via the Grothendieck group construction is admissible, relatively to surjective homomorphisms, in the sense of categorical Galois theory. The central extensions with respect to this Galois structure turn out to be the so-called <i>special homogeneous surjections.</i>MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #469:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="469" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="469" filesize="410992" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/8/29-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Twisted actions of categorical groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We develop a theory of twisted actions of categorical groups using a notion of semidirect product of categories. We work through numerous examples to demonstrate the power of these notions. Turning to representations, which are actions that respect vector space structures, we establish an analog of Schur's lemma in this context. Keeping new terminology to a minimum, we concentrate on examples exploring the essential new notions introduced.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Representations</keyword>
      <keyword>Double Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Categorical Groups</keyword>
      <keyword>2-Groups</keyword>
      <keyword>Semidirect Products</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="470" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-09.pdf</name>
    <file id="470" filesize="656696" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/9/29-09.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The theory and practice of Reedy categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The goal of this paper is to demystify the role played by the Reedy category axioms in homotopy theory. With no assumed prerequisites beyond a healthy appetite for category theoretic arguments, we present streamlined proofs of a number of useful technical results, which are well known to folklore but difficult to find in the literature. While the results presented here are not new, our approach to their proofs is somewhat novel. Specifically, we reduce much of the hard work involved to simpler computations involving <i>weighted colimits</i> and <i>Leibniz (pushout-product) constructions</i>. The general theory is developed in parallel with examples, which we use to prove that familiar formulae for homotopy limits and colimits indeed have the desired properties.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>homotopy limits and colimits</keyword>
      <keyword>weighted limits and colimits</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Duality in non-abelian algebra I. From cover relations to Grandis ex2-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The aim of this series of papers is to develop a self-dual categorical approach to some topics in non-abelian algebra, which is based on replacing the framework of a category with that of a category equipped with a functor to it. The present paper gives some preliminary steps in this direction, where several known structures on a category, which arise in the categorical treatment of these topics, are viewed as such functors; as a result, we obtain some new conceptual links between these structures.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="473" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="473" filesize="523464" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/12/29-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the infinity category of homotopy Leibniz algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We discuss various concepts of $\infty$-homotopies, as well as the relations between them (focussing on the Leibniz type). In particular $\infty$-$n$-homotopies appear as the $n$-simplices of the nerve of a complete Lie ${\infty}$-algebra. In the nilpotent case, this nerve is known to be a Kan complex. We argue that there is a quasi-category of $\infty$-algebras and show that for truncated $\infty$-algebras, i.e. categorified algebras, this $\infty$-categorical structure projects to a strict 2-categorical one. The paper contains a shortcut to $(\infty,1)$-categories, as well as a review of Getzler's proof of the Kan property. We make the latter concrete by applying it to the 2-term $\infty$-algebra case, thus recovering the concept of homotopy of Baez and Crans, as well as the corresponding composition rule \cite{SS07}. We also answer a question of Shoikhet about composition of $\infty$-homotopies of $\infty$-algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Homotopy algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>categorified algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>higher category</keyword>
      <keyword>quasi-category</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan complex</keyword>
      <keyword>Maurer-Cartan equation</keyword>
      <keyword>composition of homotopies</keyword>
      <keyword>Leibniz algebra</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Toward categorical risk measure theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce a category that represents varying risk as well as ambiguity. We give a generalized conditional expectation as a presheaf for this category, which not only works as a traditional conditional expectation given a $\sigma$-field but also is compatible with change of measure. Then, we reformulate dynamic monetary value measures as a presheaf for the category. We show how some axioms of dynamic monetary value measures in the classical setting are deduced as theorems in the new formulation, which is evidence that the axioms are correct. Finally, we point out the possibility of giving a theoretical criteria with which we can pick up appropriate sets of axioms required for monetary value measures to be good, using a topology-as-axioms paradigm.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #476:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="476" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="476" filesize="395633" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/15/29-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Topological functors as total categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A notion of central importance in categorical topology is that of topological functor. A faithful functor $\cal E \to \cal B$ is called topological if it admits cartesian liftings of all (possibly large) families of arrows; the basic example is the forgetful functor $Top \to Set$. A topological functor $\cal E \to 1$ is the same thing as a (large) complete preorder, and the general topological functor $\cal E \to \cal B$ is intuitively thought of as a "complete preorder relative to $\cal B$". We make this intuition precise by considering an enrichment base $\cal Q_\cal B$ such that $\cal Q_\cal B$-enriched categories are faithful functors into $\cal B$, and show that, in this context, a faithful functor is topological if and only if it is total (=totally cocomplete) in the sense of Street-Walters. We also consider the MacNeille completion of a faithful functor to a topological one, first described by Herrlich, and show that it may be obtained as an instance of Isbell's generalised notion of MacNeille completion for enriched categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Topological functors</keyword>
      <keyword>total categories</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched categories</keyword>
      <keyword>quantaloids</keyword>
      <keyword>MacNeille completion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="342">
        <givenname locale="en">Richard</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Garner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    </article_galley>

FILE #477:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="477" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="477" filesize="560900" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/16/29-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Bayesian characterization of relative entropy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give a new characterization of relative entropy, also known as the Kullback--Leibler divergence. We use a number of interesting categories related to probability theory. In particular, we consider a category FinStat where an object is a finite set equipped with a probability distribution, while a morphism is a measure-preserving function $f \maps X \to Y$ together with a stochastic right inverse $s \maps Y \to X$. The function $f$ can be thought of as a measurement process, while $s$ provides a hypothesis about the state of the measured system given the result of a measurement. Given this data we can define the entropy of the probability distribution on $X$ relative to the `prior' given by pushing the probability distribution on $Y$ forwards along $s$. We say that $s$ is `optimal' if these distributions agree. We show that any convex linear, lower semicontinuous functor from FinStat to the additive monoid $[0,\infty]$ which vanishes when $s$ is optimal must be a scalar multiple of this relative entropy. Our proof is independent of all earlier characterizations, but inspired by the work of Petz.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>relative entropy</keyword>
      <keyword>Kullback-Leibler divergence</keyword>
      <keyword>measures of information</keyword>
      <keyword>categorical probability theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="160">
        <givenname locale="en">John C.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Baez</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="387">
        <givenname locale="en">Tobias</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Fritz</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="477"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>29</volume>
      <year>2014</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>421-456</pages>

FILE #478:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="478" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="478" filesize="325636" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/17/29-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Extending obstructions to noncommutative functorial spectra</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Any functor from the category of C*-algebras to the category of locales that assigns to each commutative C*-algebra its Gelfand spectrum must be trivial on algebras of $n$-by-$n$ matrices for $n \geq 3$. This obstruction also applies to other spectra such as those named after Zariski, Stone, and Pierce. We extend these no-go results to functors with values in (ringed) topological spaces, (ringed) toposes, schemes, and quantales. The possibility of spectra in other categories is discussed.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Ring spectra</keyword>
      <keyword>Kochen-Specker Theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="388">
        <givenname locale="en">Benno van den</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Berg</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="278">

FILE #479:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="479" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-18.pdf</name>
    <file id="479" filesize="419639" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/18/29-18.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Enriched factorization systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In a paper of 1974, Brian Day employed a notion of factorization system in the context of enriched category theory, replacing the usual diagonal lifting property with a corresponding criterion phrased in terms of hom-objects. We set forth the basic theory of such enriched factorization systems. In particular, we establish stability properties for enriched prefactorization systems, we examine the relation of enriched to ordinary factorization systems, and we provide general results for obtaining enriched factorizations by means of wide (co)intersections. As a special case, we prove results on the existence of enriched factorization systems involving enriched strong monomorphisms or strong epimorphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>factorization systems</keyword>
      <keyword>factorisation systems</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched categories</keyword>
      <keyword>strong monomorphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>strong epimorphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal categories</keyword>
      <keyword>closed categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="389">
        <givenname locale="en">Rory B. B.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lucyshyn-Wright</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Sequential multicategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the monoidal closed category of symmetric multicategories, especially in relation with its cartesian structure and with sequential multicategories (whose arrows are sequences of concurrent arrows in a given category). Then we consider cartesian multicategories in a similar perspective and develop some peculiar items such as algebraic products. Several classical facts arise as a consequence of this analysis when some of the multicategories involved are representable.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #481:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="481" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-20.pdf</name>
    <file id="481" filesize="421176" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/20/29-20.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Continuous cohesion over sets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A pre-cohesive geometric morphism $p:\cal E \rightarrow \cal S$ satisfies <i>Continuity</i> if the canonical $p_! (X^{p^* S}) \rightarrow (p_! X)^S$ is an iso for every $X$ in $\cal E$ and $S$ in $\cal S$. We show that if $\cal S = Set$ and $\cal E$ is a presheaf topos then, $p$ satisfies Continuity if and only if it is a quality type. Our proof of this characterization rests on a related result showing that Continuity and Sufficient Cohesion are incompatible for presheaf toposes. This incompatibility raises the question whether Continuity and Sufficient Cohesion are ever compatible for Grothendieck toposes. We show that the answer is positive by building some examples.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
      <keyword>Axiomatic Cohesion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="113">
        <givenname locale="en">Matias</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Menni</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <file id="482" filesize="429364" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/21/29-21.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On deformations of pasting diagrams, II</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We continue the development of the infinitesimal deformation theory of pasting diagrams of $k$-linear categories begun in TAC, Vol 22, #2. In that article the standard result that all obstructions are cocycles was established only for the elementary, composition-free parts of pasting diagrams. In the present work we give a proof for pasting diagrams in general. As tools we use the method developed by Shrestha of simultaneously representing formulas for obstructions, along with the corresponding cocycle and cobounding conditions by suitably labeled polygons, giving a rigorous exposition of the previously heuristic method; and deformations of pasting diagrams in which some cells are required to be deformed trivially.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>pasting diagrams</keyword>
      <keyword>pasting schemes</keyword>
      <keyword>deformation theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="390">
        <givenname locale="en">Tej</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shrestha</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #483:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="483" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="483" filesize="466627" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/22/29-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Realizable homotopy colimits</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the composition of a homotopically meaningful `geometric realization' (or simple functor) with the simplicial replacement produces all homotopy colimits and Kan extensions in a relative category which is closed under coproducts. Examples (and its duals) include model categories, $\Delta$-closed classes and other concrete examples such as complexes on (AB4) abelian categories, (filtered) commutative dg algebras and mixed Hodge complexes. The resulting homotopy colimits satisfy the expected properties as cofinality and Fubini, and are moreover colimits in a suitable 2-category of relative categories. Conversely, the existence of homotopy colimits satisfying these properties guarantees that $hocolim_{\Delta^o}$ is a simple functor.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Homotopy colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>Simplicial descent category</keyword>
      <keyword>Grothendieck derivator</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="391">
        <givenname locale="en">Beatriz Rodriguez</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Gonzalez</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
