    <title locale="en">Constructing model categories with prescribed fibrant objects</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present a weak form of a recognition principle for Quillen model categories due to J.H. Smith. We use it to put a model category structure on the category of small categories enriched over a suitable monoidal simplicial model category. The proof uses a part of the model structure on small simplicial categories due to J. Bergner. We give an application of the weak form of Smith's result to left Bousfield localizations of categories of monoids in a suitable monoidal model category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Stacks and sheaves of categories as fibrant objects, I</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the category of categories fibred over a site is a generalized Quillen model category in which the weak equivalences are the local equivalences and the fibrant objects are the stacks, as they were defined by J. Giraud. The generalized model category restricts to one on the full subcategory whose objects are the categories fibred in groupoids. We show that the category of sheaves of categories is a model category that is Quillen equivalent to the generalized model category for stacks and to the model category for strong stacks due to A. Joyal and M. Tierney.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>fibred category</keyword>
      <keyword>model category</keyword>
      <keyword>stack</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="392">
        <givenname locale="en">Alexandru E.</givenname>

    <file id="489" filesize="328507" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/28/29-28.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Serre-Swan theorem for gerbe modules on &ecute;tale Lie groupoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a torsion bundle gerbe on a compact smooth manifold or, more generally, on a compact &eacute;tale Lie groupoid M, we show that the corresponding category of gerbe modules is equivalent to the category of finitely generated projective modules over an Azumaya algebra on M. This result can be seen as an equivariant Serre-Swan theorem for twisted vector bundles.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>

FILE #490:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="490" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-29.pdf</name>
    <file id="490" filesize="467299" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/29/29-29.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Bicategorical fibration structures and stacks</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we introduce two notions - systems of fibrant objects and fibration structures--- which will allow us to associate to a bicategory $B$ a homotopy bicategory $Ho(B)$ in such a way that $Ho(B)$ is the universal way to add pseudo-inverses to weak equivalences in $B$. Furthermore, $Ho(B)$ is locally small when $B$ is and $Ho(B)$ is a 2-category when $B$ is. We thereby resolve two of the problems with known approaches to bicategorical localization. <p> As an important example, we describe a fibration structure on the 2-category of prestacks on a site and prove that the resulting homotopy bicategory is the 2-category of stacks. We also show how this example can be restricted to obtain algebraic, differentiable and topological (respectively) stacks as homotopy categories of algebraic, differential and topological (respectively) prestacks.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>stacks</keyword>
      <keyword>fibrant objects</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>bicategories of fractions</keyword>
      <keyword>algebraic stacks</keyword>
      <keyword>differentiable stacks</keyword>
      <keyword>topological stacks</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="396">

    <title locale="en">More on geometric morphisms between realizability toposes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Geometric morphisms between realizability toposes are studied in terms of morphisms between partial combinatory algebras (pcas). The morphisms inducing geometric morphisms (the <i>computationally dense</i> ones) are seen to be the ones whose `lifts' to a kind of completion have right adjoints. We characterize topos inclusions corresponding to a general form of relative computability. We characterize pcas whose realizability topos admits a geometric morphism to the effective topos.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #492:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="492" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="492" filesize="558931" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/29/31/29-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Completion, closure, and density relative to a monad, with examples in functional analysis and sheaf theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a monad $T$ on a suitable enriched category $B$ equipped with a proper factorization system $(E,M)$, we define notions of <i>$T$-completion, $T$-closure</i>, and <i>$T$-density</i>. We show that not only the familiar notions of completion, closure, and density in normed vector spaces, but also the notions of sheafification, closure, and density with respect to a Lawvere-Tierney topology, are instances of the given abstract notions. The process of $T$-completion is equally the enriched idempotent monad associated to $T$ (which we call the <i>idempotent core of $T$)</i>, and we show that it exists as soon as every morphism in $B$ factors as a $T$-dense morphism followed by a $T$-closed $M$-embedding. The latter hypothesis is satisfied as soon as $B$ has certain pullbacks as well as wide intersections of $M$-embeddings. Hence the resulting theorem on the existence of the idempotent core of an enriched monad entails Fakir's existence result in the non-enriched case, as well as adjoint functor factorization results of Applegate-Tierney and Day.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>completion</keyword>
      <keyword>closure</keyword>
      <keyword>density</keyword>
      <keyword>monad</keyword>
      <keyword>idempotent monad</keyword>
      <keyword>idempotent core</keyword>
      <keyword>idempotent approximation</keyword>
      <keyword>normed vector space</keyword>
      <keyword>adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>reflective subcategory</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>factorization system</keyword>
      <keyword>orthogonal subcategory</keyword>
      <keyword>sheaf</keyword>
      <keyword>sheafification</keyword>
      <keyword>Lawvere-Tierney topology</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>closed category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="493" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">29-32.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Iterated icons</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the totality of categories weakly enriched in a monoidal bicategory using a notion of enriched icon as 2-cells. We show that when the monoidal bicategory in question is symmetric then this process can be iterated. We show that starting from the symmetric monoidal bicategory <b>Cat</b> and performing the construction twice yields a convenient symmetric monoidal bicategory of partially strict tricategories. We show that restricting to the doubly degenerate ones immediately gives the correct bicategory of `2-tuply monoidal categories' missing from our earlier studies of the Periodic Table. We propose a generalisation to all $k$-tuply monoidal $n$-categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2014</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>icon</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On strong homotopy for quasi-schemoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A quasi-schemoid is a small category with a particular partition of the set of morphisms. We define a homotopy relation on the category of quasi-schemoids and study its fundamental properties. The homotopy set of self-homotopy equivalences on a quasi-schemoid is used as a homotopy invariant in the study. The main theorem enables us to deduce that the homotopy invariant for the quasi-schemoid induced by a finite group is isomorphic to the automorphism group of the given group. %These considerations are the first step to develop homotopy theory for quasi-schemoids.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Association scheme</keyword>
      <keyword>small category</keyword>
      <keyword>schemoids</keyword>
      <keyword>homotopy</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Model categories with simple homotopy categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In the present article we describe constructions of model structures on general bicomplete categories. We are motivated by the following question: given a category C with a suitable subcategory wC, when is there a model structure on C with wC as the subcategory of weak equivalences? We begin exploring this question in the case where wC = F^{-1}(iso D) for some functor F : C --> D. We also prove properness of our constructions under minor assumptions and examine an application to the category of infinite graphs.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>model category</keyword>
      <keyword>graph</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Weak braided monoidal categories and their homotopy colimits</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the homotopy colimit construction for diagrams of categories with an operad action, recently introduced by Fiedorowicz, Stelzer and Vogt, has the desired homotopy type for diagrams of weak braided monoidal categories. This provides a more flexible way to realize $E_2$ spaces categorically.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Un th&eacute;or&egrave;me A de Quillen pour les 2-foncteurs lax</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We generalize Quillen's Theorem A to triangles of lax 2-functors which commute up to transformation. It follows from a special case of this result that 2-categories are models for homotopy types.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #498:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="498" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="498" filesize="770657" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/5/30-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Algebraic Kan extensions in double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study Kan extensions in three weakenings of the Eilenberg-Moore double category associated to a double monad, that was introduced by Grandis and Paré. To be precise, given a normal oplax double monad T on a double category K, we consider the double categories consisting of pseudo T-algebras, `weak' vertical T-morphisms, horizontal T-morphisms and T-cells, where `weak' means either `lax', `colax' or `pseudo'. Denoting these double categories by Alg_w(T), where w = l, c or ps accordingly, our main result gives, in each of these cases, conditions ensuring that (pointwise) Kan extensions can be lifted along the forgetful double functor Alg_w(T) --> K. As an application we recover and generalise a result by Getzler, on the lifting of pointwise left Kan extensions along symmetric monoidal enriched functors. As an application of Getzler's result we prove, in suitable symmetric monoidal categories, the existence of bicommutative Hopf monoids that are freely generated by cocommutative comonoids.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>double monad</keyword>
      <keyword>algebraic Kan extension</keyword>
      <keyword>free bicommutative Hopf monoid</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="393">
        <givenname locale="en">Seerp Roald</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Koudenburg</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <file id="499" filesize="690349" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/6/30-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Bicategorical homotopy pullbacks</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The homotopy theory of higher categorical structures has become a relevant part of the machinery of algebraic topology and algebraic K-theory, and this paper contains contributions to the study of the relationship between Benabou's bicategories and the homotopy types of their classifying spaces. Mainly, we state and prove an extension of Quillen's Theorem B by showing, under reasonable necessary conditions, a bicategory-theoretical interpretation of the homotopy-fibre product of the continuous maps induced on classifying spaces by a diagram of bicategories $A\to B \leftarrow A'$. Applications are given for the study of homotopy pullbacks of monoidal categories and of crossed modules.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">Characteristic subobjects in semi-abelian categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We extend to semi-abelian categories the notion of characteristic subobject, which is widely used in group theory and in the theory of Lie algebras. Moreover, we show that many of the classical properties of characteristic subgroups of a group hold in the general semi-abelian context, or in stronger ones.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Partial-sup lattices</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The study of sup lattices teaches us the important distinction between the algebraic part of the structure (in this case suprema) and the coincidental part of the structure (in this case infima). While a sup lattice happens to have all infima, only the suprema are part of the algebraic structure.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Lax formal theory of monads, monoidal approach to bicategorical structures and generalized operads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Generalized operads, also called generalized multicategories and $T$-monoids, are defined as monads within a Kleisli bicategory. With or without emphasizing their monoidal nature, generalized operads have been considered by numerous authors in different contexts, with examples including symmetric multicategories, topological spaces, globular operads and Lawvere theories. In this paper we study functoriality of the Kleisli construction, and correspondingly that of generalized operads. Motivated by this problem we develop a lax version of the formal theory of monads, and study its connection to bicategorical structures.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>formal theory of monads</keyword>
      <keyword>generalized multicategories</keyword>
      <keyword>lax categorification</keyword>
      <keyword>tricategories}</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A cocategorical obstruction to tensor products of Gray-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It was argued by Crans that it is too much to ask that the category of Gray-categories admit a well behaved monoidal biclosed structure. We make this precise by establishing undesirable properties that any such monoidal biclosed structure must have. In particular we show that there does not exist any tensor product making the model category of Gray-categories into a monoidal model category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #505:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="505" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="505" filesize="341993" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/12/30-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Normalizers, centralizers and action accessibility</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give several reformulations of action accessibility in the sense of D. Bourn and G. Janelidze. In particular we prove that a pointed exact protomodular category is action accessible if and only if for each normal monomorphism $\kappa:X\to A$ the normalizer of $< \kappa,\kappa>: X\to A\times A$ exists. This clarifies the connection between normalizers and action accessible categories established in a joint paper of D. Bourn and the author, in which it is proved that for pointed exact protomodular categories the existence of normalizers implies action accessibility. In addition we prove a pointed exact protomodular category with coequalizers is action accessible if centralizers of normal monomorphisms exist, and the normality of unions holds.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>action accessible</keyword>
      <keyword>protomodular</keyword>
      <keyword>Barr exact</keyword>
      <keyword>normality</keyword>
      <keyword>centrality</keyword>
      <keyword>normalizer</keyword>
      <keyword>centralizer</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="408">
        <givenname locale="en">J. R. A.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Gray</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #507:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="507" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="507" filesize="582920" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/14/30-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Slicing sites and semireplete factorization systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A factorization system (E, M) on a category A gives rise to the covariant category-valued pseudofunctor P of A sending each object to its slice category over M. This article characterizes the P so obtained as follows: their object images have terminal objects, and they admit bicategorically cartesian liftings, up to equivalence, of slice-category projections. It is clear that, and how, (E, M) can be recovered from such a P. The correspondence thus described is actually the second of three similar ones between certain (E, M) and certain P that the article presents. In the first one the characterization of the P has all ultimately bicategorical ingredients replaced with their categorical analogues. A category A with such a P is precisely what the author has called a `slicing site'. In the article's terms the associated (E, M) are again factorization systems - but the concept conveyed extends the standard one by not obliging isomorphisms to belong to either factor class -, namely those that are `right semireplete' (isomorphisms do belong to M and `left semistrict' (morphisms in M are monic relative to E). The third correspondence subsumes the other two; here the (E, M) are all right-semireplete factorization systems.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>factorization system</keyword>
      <keyword>slice categories</keyword>
      <keyword>cartesian morphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>slicing site</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="268">
        <givenname locale="en">Thorsten</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Palm</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="507"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>30</volume>
      <year>2015</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>489-526</pages>
  </publication>
</article>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

FILE #508:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="508" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="508" filesize="248586" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/15/30-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Notes on commutation of limits and colimits</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that there are infinitely many distinct closed classes of colimits (in the sense of the Galois connection induced by commutation of limits and colimits in <b>Set</b>) which are intermediate between the class of pseudo-filtered colimits and that of all (small) colimits. On the other hand, if the corresponding class of limits contains either pullbacks or equalizers, then the class of colimits is contained in that of pseudo-filtered colimits.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Limit</keyword>
      <keyword>colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>filtered colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>group action</keyword>
      <keyword>simple group</keyword>
      <keyword>Galois connection</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Polynomials in categories with pullbacks</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The theory developed by Gambino and Kock, of polynomials over a locally cartesian closed category E, is generalised for E just having pullbacks. The 2-categorical analogue of the theory of polynomials and polynomial functors is given, and its relationship with Street's theory of fibrations within 2-categories is explored. Johnstone's notion of "bagdomain data" is adapted to the present framework to make it easier to completely exhibit examples of polynomial monads.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">Extensive categories and the size of an orbit</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is well known how to compute the number of orbits of a group action. A related problem, apparently not in the literature, is to determine the number of elements in an orbit. The theory that addresses this question leads to orbital extensive categories and to combinatorial aspects of such categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Cartesian differential storage categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Monoidal differential categories provide the framework for categorical models of differential linear logic. The coKleisli category of any monoidal differential category is always a Cartesian differential category. Cartesian differential categories, besides arising in this manner as coKleisli categories, occur in many different and quite independent ways. Thus, it was not obvious how to pass from Cartesian differential categories back to monoidal differential categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">The accessibility rank of weak equivalences</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the accessibility properties of trivial cofibrations and weak equivalences in a combinatorial model category and prove an estimate for the accessibility rank of weak equivalences. In particular, we show that the class of weak equivalences between simplicial sets is finitely accessible.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A model structure on internal categories in simplicial sets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We put a model structure on the category of categories internal to simplicial sets. The weak equivalences in this model structure are preserved and reflected by the nerve functor to bisimplicial sets with the complete Segal space model structure. This model structure is shown to be a model for the homotopy theory of infinity categories. We also study the homotopy theory of internal presheaves over an internal category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">An algebraic definition of ($\infty$,n)-categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we define a sequence of monads $T^{(\infty,n)} (n\in\mathbb{N})$ on the category $\infty-Gr$ of $\infty$-graphs. We conjecture that algebras for $\T^{(\infty,0)}$, which are defined in a purely algebraic setting, are models of $\infty$-groupoids. More generally, we conjecture that $T^{(\infty,n)}$-algebras are models for $(\infty,n)$-categories. We prove that our $(\infty,0)$-categories are bigroupoids when truncated at level 2.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #516:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="516" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-23.pdf</name>
    <file id="516" filesize="484240" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/23/30-23.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Reflexivity and dualizability in categorified linear algebra</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The "linear dual" of a cocomplete linear category $C$ is the category of all cocontinuous linear functors $C \to Vect$. We study the questions of when a cocomplete linear category is reflexive (equivalent to its double dual) or dualizable (the pairing with its dual comes with a corresponding copairing). Our main results are that the category of comodules for a countable-dimensional coassociative coalgebra is always reflexive, but (without any dimension hypothesis) dualizable if and only if it has enough projectives, which rarely happens. Along the way, we prove that the category $QCoh(X)$ of quasi-coherent sheaves on a stack $X$ is not dualizable if $X$ is the classifying stack of a semisimple algebraic group in positive characteristic or if $X$ is a scheme containing a closed projective subscheme of positive dimension, but is dualizable if $X$ is the quotient of an affine scheme by a virtually linearly reductive group. Finally we prove tensoriality (a type of Tannakian duality) for affine ind-schemes with countable indexing poset.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>locally presentable</keyword>
      <keyword>dualizable</keyword>
      <keyword>cocomplete</keyword>
      <keyword>cocontinuous</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="418">
        <givenname locale="en">Martin</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Brandenburg</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="419">
        <givenname locale="en">Alexandru</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Chirvasitu</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="420">
        <givenname locale="en">Theo</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Johnson-Freyd</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="516"/>

FILE #517:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="517" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-24.pdf</name>
    <file id="517" filesize="542170" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/24/30-24.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categories in control</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Control theory uses `signal-flow diagrams' to describe processes where real-valued functions of time are added, multiplied by scalars, differentiated and integrated, duplicated and deleted. These diagrams can be seen as string diagrams for the symmetric monoidal category FinVectk of finite-dimensional vector spaces over the field of rational functions k = R(s), where the variable s acts as differentiation and the monoidal structure is direct sum rather than the usual tensor product of vector spaces. For any field k we give a presentation of FinVectk in terms of the generators used in signal-flow diagrams. A broader class of signal-flow diagrams also includes `caps' and `cups' to model feedback. We show these diagrams can be seen as string diagrams for the symmetric monoidal category FinRelk, where objects are still finite-dimensional vector spaces but the morphisms are linear relations. We also give a presentation for FinRelk. The relations say, among other things, that the 1-dimensional vector space k has two special commutative dagger-Frobenius structures, such that the multiplication and unit of either one and the comultiplication and counit of the other fit together to form a bimonoid. This sort of structure, but with tensor product replacing direct sum, is familiar from the `ZX-calculus' obeyed by a finite-dimensional Hilbert space with two mutually unbiased bases.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>control theory</keyword>
      <keyword>graphical calculus</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>bialgebra</keyword>
      <keyword>dagger-compact category</keyword>
      <keyword>signal-flow diagram</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="160">
        <givenname locale="en">John C.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Baez</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="421">
        <givenname locale="en">Jason</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Erbele</familyname>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <name locale="en">30-25.pdf</name>
    <file id="518" filesize="430245" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/25/30-25.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Actions in modified categories of interest with application to crossed modules</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The existence of the split extension classifier of a crossed module in the category of associative algebras is investigated. According to the equivalence of categories $XAss \simeq Cat^1-Ass$ we consider this problem in $Cat^1-Ass$. This category is not a category of interest, it satisfies its all axioms except one. The action theory developed in the category of interest is adapted to the new type of category, which will be called modified category of interest. Applying the results obtained in this direction and the equivalence of categories we find a condition under which there exists the split extension classifier of a crossed module and give the corresponding construction.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Internal choice holds in the discrete part of any cohesive topos satisfying stable connected codiscreteness</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce an apparent strengthening of Sufficient Cohesion that we call Stable Connected Codiscreteness (SCC) and show that if $p: E --> S$ is cohesive and satisfies SCC then the internal axiom of choice holds in $S$. Moreover, in this case, $p^!: S --> E$ is equivalent to the inclusion $E_{\neg\neg} --> E$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">On the second cohomology categorical group and a Hochschild-Serre 2-exact sequence</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce the second cohomology categorical group of a categorical group G with coefficients in a symmetric G-categorical group and we show that it classifies extensions of G with symmetric kernel and a functorial section. Moreover, from an essentially surjective homomorphism of categorical groups we get 2-exact sequences a la Hochschild-Serre connecting the categorical groups of derivations and the first and the second cohomology categorical groups.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #523:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="523" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-30.pdf</name>
    <file id="523" filesize="313746" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/30/30-30.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Finite categories with pushouts</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let C be a finite category. For an object X of C one has the hom-functor Hom(-,X) of C to Set. If G is a subgroup of Aut(X), one has the quotient functor Hom(-,X)/G. We show that any finite product of hom-functors of C is a sum of hom-functors if and only if C has pushouts and coequalizers and that any finite product of hom-functors of C is a sum of functors of the form \Hom(-,X)/G if and only if C has pushouts. These are variations of the fact that a finite category has products if and only if it has coproducts.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>pushout</keyword>
      <keyword>coequalizer</keyword>
      <keyword>hom-functor</keyword>
      <keyword>familially representable functor</keyword>
      <keyword>nearly representable functor</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="430">
        <givenname locale="en">D.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Tambara</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #524:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="524" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="524" filesize="650366" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/31/30-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Reduced smooth stacks?</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;An arbitrary Lie groupoid gives rise to a groupoid of germs of local diffeomorphisms over its base manifold, known as its <i>effect</i>. The effect of any bundle of Lie groups is trivial. All quotients of a given Lie groupoid determine the same effect. It is natural to regard the effects of any two Morita equivalent Lie groupoids as being ``equivalent''. In this paper we shall describe a systematic way of comparing the effects of different Lie groupoids. In particular, we shall rigorously define what it means for two arbitrary Lie groupoids to give rise to ``equivalent'' effects. For effective orbifold groupoids, the new notion of equivalence turns out to coincide with the traditional notion of Morita equivalence. Our analysis is relevant to the presentation theory of proper smooth stacks.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Lie groupoids</keyword>
      <keyword>effective orbifolds</keyword>
      <keyword>categories of fractions</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="431">
        <givenname locale="en">Giorgio</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Trentinaglia</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="524"/>
    </article_galley>

FILE #525:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="525" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-32.pdf</name>
    <file id="525" filesize="526278" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/32/30-32.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Cyclic homology arising from adjunctions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a monad and a comonad, one obtains a distributive law between them from lifts of one through an adjunction for the other. In particular, this yields for any bialgebroid the Yetter-Drinfel'd distributive law between the comonad given by a module coalgebra and the monad given by a comodule algebra. It is this self-dual setting that reproduces the cyclic homology of associative and of Hopf algebras in the monadic framework of B&ouml;hm and Stefan. In fact, their approach generates two duplicial objects and morphisms between them which are mutual inverses if and only if the duplicial objects are cyclic. A 2-categorical perspective on the process of twisting coefficients is provided and the role of the two notions of bimonad studied in the literature is clarified.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>cyclic homology</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf algebroids</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf monads</keyword>
      <keyword>distributive laws</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="432">
        <givenname locale="en">Niels</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kowalzig</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="433">
        <givenname locale="en">Ulrich</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kr&auml;hmer</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">Slevin</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

FILE #526:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="526" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-33.pdf</name>
    <file id="526" filesize="445282" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/33/30-33.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Decorated cospans</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let $C$ be a category with finite colimits, writing its coproduct +, and let $(D, \otimes)$ be a braided monoidal category. We describe a method of producing a symmetric monoidal category from a lax braided monoidal functor $F : (C,+) \to (D, \otimes)$, and of producing a strong monoidal functor between such categories from a monoidal natural transformation between such functors. The objects of these categories, our so-called `decorated cospan categories', are simply the objects of $C$, while the morphisms are pairs comprising a cospan $X \rightarrow N \leftarrow Y$ in $C$ together with an element $1 \to FN$ in $D$. Moreover, decorated cospan categories are hypergraph categories - each object is equipped with a special commutative Frobenius monoid - and their functors preserve this structure.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>cospan</keyword>
      <keyword>decorated cospan</keyword>
      <keyword>hypergraph category</keyword>
      <keyword>well-supported compact closed category</keyword>
      <keyword>separable algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius monoid</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="435">
        <givenname locale="en">Brendan</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Fong</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="526"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>30</volume>
      <year>2015</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>1096-1120</pages>

    <title locale="en">A note on transport of algebraic structures</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study transport of algebraic structures and prove a theorem which subsumes results of Comfort and Ross on topological group structures on Stone-Cech compactifications, of Chevalley and of Gil de Lamadrid and Jans on topological group and ring structures on universal covering spaces, and of Gleason on topological group structures on universal locally connected refinements.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #528:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="528" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-35.pdf</name>
    <file id="528" filesize="554745" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/35/30-35.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Generalized covering space theories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we unify various approaches to generalized covering space theory by introducing a categorical framework in which coverings are defined purely in terms of unique lifting properties. For each category C of path-connected spaces having the unit disk as an object, we construct a category of C-coverings over a given space X that embeds in the category of $\pi_1(X,x_0)$-sets via the usual monodromy action on fibers. When C is extended to its coreflective hull H(C), the resulting category of based H(C)-coverings is complete, has an initial object, and often characterizes more of the subgroup lattice of $\pi_1(X,x_0)$ than traditional covering spaces. We apply our results to three special coreflective subcategories: (1) The category of $\Delta$-coverings employs the convenient category of $\Delta$-generated spaces and is universal in the sense that it contains every other generalized covering category as a subcategory. (2) In the locally path-connected category, we preserve notion of generalized covering due to Fischer and Zastrow and characterize the topology of such coverings using the standard whisker topology. (3) By employing the coreflective hull <b>Fan</b> of the category of all contractible spaces, we characterize the notion of continuous lifting of paths and identify the topology of <b>Fan</b>-coverings as the natural quotient topology inherited from the path space.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Fundamental group</keyword>
      <keyword>generalized covering map</keyword>
      <keyword>coreflective hull</keyword>
      <keyword>unique path lifting property</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="437">
        <givenname locale="en">Jeremy</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Brazas</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <title locale="en">Building a Model Category out of cofibrations and fibrations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The purpose of this note is to understand the two out of three property of the model category in terms of the weak factorization systems. We will show that if a category with classes of trivial cofibrations, cofibrations, trivial fibrations, and fibrations is given a simplicial structure similar to that of the simplicial model category, then the full subcategory of cofibrant and fibrant objects has the two out of three property, and we will give a list of necessary and sufficient conditions in terms of the simplicial structure for the associated canonical "weak equivalence class" to have the two out of three property.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <name locale="en">30-37.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A C-system defined by a universe category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This is the third paper in a series. In it we construct a C-system CC(C,p) starting from a category C together with a morphism $p:\tilde{U} \to U$, a choice of pull-back squares based on $p$ for all morphisms to $U$ and a choice of a final object of C. Such a quadruple is called a universe category. We then define universe category functors and construct homomorphisms of C-systems CC(C,p) defined by universe category functors. In the sections before the last section we give, for any C-system CC, three different constructions of pairs ((C,p),H) where (C,p) is a universe category and $H : CC \to CC(C,p)$ is an isomorphism. In the last section we construct for any (set) category C with a choice of a final object and fiber products a C-system and an equivalence between C and the precategory underlying CC.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>contextual category</keyword>
      <keyword>universe category</keyword>
      <keyword>C-system</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="439">

FILE #531:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="531" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-38.pdf</name>
    <file id="531" filesize="476445" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/38/30-38.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Intercategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce a 3-dimensional categorical structure which we call intercategory. This is a kind of weak triple category with three kinds of arrows, three kinds of 2-dimensional cells and one kind of 3-dimensional cells. In one dimension, the compositions are strictly associative and unitary, whereas in the other two, these laws only hold up to coherent isomorphism. The main feature is that the interchange law between the second and third compositions does not hold, but rather there is a non-invertible comparison cell which satisfies some coherence conditions. We introduce appropriate morphisms of intercategory, of which there are three types, and cells relating these. We show that these fit together to produce a strict triple category of intercategories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>2-category</keyword>
      <keyword>double category</keyword>
      <keyword>lax and colax functor</keyword>
      <keyword>pseudocategory</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Stacks of <i>Ann</i>-Categories and their morphisms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that <i>ann</i>-categories admit a presentation by crossed bimodules, and prove that morphisms between them can be expressed by special kinds spans between the presentations. More precisely, we prove the groupoid of morphisms between two <i>ann</i>-categories is equivalent to that of bimodule butterflies between the presentations. A bimodule butterfly is a specialization of a butterfly, i.e. a special kind of span or fraction, between the underlying complexesMEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #533:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="533" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-40.pdf</name>
    <file id="533" filesize="284147" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/40/30-40.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en"></title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a model category structure on a slice category of simplicial spaces, called the "Segal group action" structure, whose fibrant-cofibrant objects may be viewed as representing spaces $X$ with an action of a fixed Segal group (i.e. a group-like, reduced Segal space). We show that this model structure is Quillen equivalent to the projective model structure on $G$-spaces, $S^BG}$, where $G$ is a simplicial group corresponding to the Segal group. One advantage of this model is that if we start with an ordinary group action $X\in S^BG$ and apply a weakly monoidal functor of spaces $L: S \to S$ (such as localization or completion) on each simplicial degree of its associated Segal group action, we get a new Segal group action of $LG$ on $LX$ which can then be rigidified via the above-mentioned Quillen equivalence.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Model category</keyword>
      <keyword>Segal space</keyword>
      <keyword>group action</keyword>
      <keyword>equivariant homotopy theory</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On reflective subcategories of locally presentable categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Are all subcategories of locally finitely presentable categories that are closed under limits and $\lambda$-filtered colimits also locally presentable? For full subcategories the answer is affirmative. Makkai and Pitts proved that in the case $\lambda = \aleph_0$ the answer is affirmative also for all iso-full subcategories, i. e., those containing with every pair of objects all isomorphisms between them. We discuss a possible generalization of this from $\aleph_0$ to an arbitrary $\lambda$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

FILE #535:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="535" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-42.pdf</name>
    <file id="535" filesize="3271719" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/42/30-42.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Gauge invariant surface holonomy and monopoles</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;There are few known computable examples of non-abelian surface holonomy. In this paper, we give several examples whose structure 2-groups are covering 2-groups and show that the surface holonomies can be computed via a simple formula in terms of paths of 1-dimensional holonomies inspired by earlier work of Chan Hong-Mo and Tsou Sheung Tsun on magnetic monopoles. As a consequence of our work and that of Schreiber and Waldorf, this formula gives a rigorous meaning to non-abelian magnetic flux for magnetic monopoles. In the process, we discuss gauge covariance of surface holonomies for spheres for any 2-group, therefore generalizing the notion of the reduced group introduced by Schreiber and Waldorf. Using these ideas, we also prove that magnetic monopoles form an abelian group.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>gauge theory</keyword>

      <keyword>gauge-invariance</keyword>
      <keyword>non-abelian 2-bundles</keyword>
      <keyword>iterated integrals</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #536:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="536" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-43.pdf</name>
    <file id="536" filesize="544201" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/43/30-43.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Transformation double categories associated to 2-group actions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Transformation groupoids associated to group actions capture the interplay between global and local symmetries of structures described in set-theoretic terms. This paper examines the analogous situation for structures described in category-theoretic terms, where symmetry is expressed as the action of a 2-group G (equivalently, a categorical group) on a category C. It describes the construction of a transformation groupoid in diagrammatic terms, and considers this construction internal to Cat, the category of categories. The result is a double category C//G which describes the local symmetries of C. We define this and describe some of its structure, with the adjoint action of G on itself as a guiding example.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <name locale="en">30-44.pdf</name>
    <file id="537" filesize="544689" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/44/30-44.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Proximity biframes and compactifications of completely regular ordered spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We generalize the concept of a strong inclusion on a biframe to that of a proximity on a biframe, which is related to the concept of a strong bi-inclusion on a frame introduced by Picado and Pultr. We also generalize the concept of a bi-compactification of a biframe to that of a compactification of a biframe, and prove that the poset of compactifications of a biframe L is isomorphic to the poset of proximities on L. As a corollary, we obtain Schauerte's characterization of bi-compactifications of a biframe. In the spatial case this yields Blatter and Seever's characterization of compactifications of completely regular ordered spaces and a characterization of bi-compactifications of completely regular bispaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">$A_\infty$-morphisms with several entries</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that morphisms from n $A_\infty$-algebras to a single one are maps over an operad module with n+1 commuting actions of the operad $A_\infty$, whose algebras are conventional $A_\infty$-algebras. The composition of $A_\infty$-morphisms with several entries is presented as a convolution of a coalgebra-like and an algebra-like structures. Under these notions lie two examples of Cat-operads: that of graded modules and of complexes.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">Homotopy unital $A_\infty$-morphisms with several entries</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that morphisms from n homotopy unital $A_\infty$-algebras to a single one are maps over an operad module with n+1 commuting actions of the operad $A_\infty^\hu$, whose algebras are homotopy unital $A_\infty$-algebras. The operad $A_\infty$ and modules over it have two useful gradings related by isomorphisms which change the degree. The composition of $A_\infty^\hu$\n-morphisms with several entries is presented as a convolution of a coalgebra-like and an algebra-like structures.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #540:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="540" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-47.pdf</name>
    <file id="540" filesize="514505" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/47/30-47.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The waves of a total category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For any <i>total</i> category $K$, with defining adjunction $\sup \ladj Y : K \rightarrow set^{K^{op}}$, the expression $W(a)(k)= set^{set^{K^{op}}}(K(a,\sup -),[k,-])$, where $[k,-]$ is evaluation at $k$, provides a well-defined functor $W : K \rightarrow \hat{K} = set^{K^{op}}$. Also, there are natural transformations $\beta : W\sup \rightarrow 1_{\hat{K}}$ and $\gamma : \sup W \rightarrow 1_K$ satisfying $\sup\beta =\gamma\sup$ and $\beta W =W\gamma$. A total $K$ is <i>totally distributive</i> if $\sup$ has a left adjoint. We show that $K$ is totally distributive iff $\gamma$ is invertible iff $W \ladj \sup$. The elements of $W(a)(k)$ are called <i>waves from $k$ to $a$.</i> <p> Write $\tilde{K}(k,a)$ for $W(a)(k)$. For any total $K$ there is an associative composition of waves. Composition becomes an arrow $\bullet : \tilde{K}\circ_{K}\tilde{K} \rightarrow \tilde{K}$. Also, there is an augmentation $\tilde{K}(-,-) \rightarrow K(-,-)$ corresponding to a natural $\delta : W \rightarrow Y$ constructed via $\beta$. We show that if $K$ is totally distributive then $\bullet$ is invertible and then $\tilde{K}$ supports an idempotent comonad structure. In fact, $\tilde{K} \circ_{K} \tilde{K} = \tilde{K} \circ_{\tilde{K}} \tilde{K}$ so that $\bullet$ is the coequalizer of $\bullet K$ and $K \bullet$, making $\tilde{K}$ a <i>taxon</i> in the sense of Koslowski. For a small taxon $T$, the category of interpolative modules $iMod(1,T)$ is totally distributive. Here we show, for any totally distributive $K$, that there is an equivalence $K \rightarrow iMod(1,\tilde{K})$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>totally cocomplete</keyword>
      <keyword>totally distributive</keyword>
      <keyword>taxon</keyword>
      <keyword>i-module</keyword>
      <keyword>proarrow equipment</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="9">
        <givenname locale="en">R. J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Wood</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="540"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>

    <pages>1624-1646</pages>

    <title locale="en">Limits of abstract elementary classes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the category of abstract elementary classes (AECs) and concrete functors is closed under constructions of ``limit type," which generalizes the approach of Mariano, Zambrano and Villaveces away from the syntactically oriented framework of institutions. Moreover, we provide a broader view of this closure phenomenon, considering a variety of categories of accessible categories with additional structure, and relaxing the assumption that the morphisms be concrete functors.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #542:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="542" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-49.pdf</name>
    <file id="542" filesize="710044" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/49/30-49.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Operads as polynomial 2-monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this article we give a construction of a polynomial 2-monad from an operad and describe the algebras of the 2-monads which then arise. This construction is different from the standard construction of a monad from an operad in that the algebras of our associated 2-monad are the categorified algebras of the original operad. Moreover it enables us to characterise operads as categorical polynomial monads in a canonical way. This point of view reveals categorical polynomial monads as a unifying environment for operads, Cat-operads and clubs. We recover the standard construction of a monad from an operad in a 2-categorical way from our associated 2-monad as a coidentifier of 2-monads, and understand the algebras of both as weak morphisms of operads into a Cat-operad of categories. Algebras of operads within general symmetric monoidal categories arise from our new associated 2-monad in a canonical way. When the operad is sigma-free, we establish a Quillen equivalence, with respect to the model structures on algebras of 2-monads found by Lack, between the strict algebras of our associated 2-monad, and those of the standard one.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>polynomial functors</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #543:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="543" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-50.pdf</name>
    <file id="543" filesize="886099" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/50/30-50.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Internal algebra classifiers as codescent objects of crossed internal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Inspired by recent work of Batanin and Berger on the homotopy theory of operads, a general monad-theoretic context for speaking about structures within structures is presented, and the problem of constructing the universal ambient structure containing the prescribed internal structure is studied. Following the work of Lack, these universal objects must be constructed from simplicial objects arising from our monad-theoretic framework, as certain 2-categorical colimits called codescent objects. We isolate the extra structure present on these simplicial objects which enable their codescent objects to be computed. These are the crossed internal categories of the title, and generalise the crossed simplicial groups of Loday and Fiedorowicz. The most general results of this article are concerned with how to compute such codescent objects in 2-categories of internal categories, and on isolating conditions on the monad-theoretic situation which enable these results to apply. Combined with earlier work of the author in which operads are seen as polynomial 2-monads, our results are then applied to the theory of non-symmetric, symmetric and braided operads. In particular, the well-known construction of a PROP from an operad is recovered, as an illustration of our techniques.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>internal algebras</keyword>
      <keyword>codescent objects</keyword>
      <keyword>crossed internal categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="170">
        <givenname locale="en">Mark</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Weber</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #544:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="544" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-51.pdf</name>
    <file id="544" filesize="516163" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/51/30-51.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Algebras of open dynamical systems on the operad of wiring diagrams</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we use the language of operads to study open dynamical systems. More specifically, we study the algebraic nature of assembling complex dynamical systems from an interconnection of simpler ones. The syntactic architecture of such interconnections is encoded using the visual language of wiring diagrams. We define the symmetric monoidal category $W$, from which we may construct an operad $OW$, whose objects are black boxes with input and output ports, and whose morphisms are wiring diagrams, thus prescribing the algebraic rules for interconnection. We then define two $W$-algebras} $G$ and $L$, which associate semantic content to the structures in $W$. Respectively, they correspond to general and to linear systems of differential equations, in which an internal state is controlled by inputs and produces outputs. As an example, we use these algebras to formalize the classical problem of systems of tanks interconnected by pipes, and hence make explicit the algebraic relationships among systems at different levels of granularity.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Operads</keyword>
      <keyword>Monoidal Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Wiring Diagrams</keyword>
      <keyword>Dynamical Systems</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="446">
        <givenname locale="en">Dmitry</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Vagner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="447">
        <givenname locale="en">David I.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Spivak</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="448">
        <givenname locale="en">Eugene</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lerman</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <submission_file_ref id="544"/>
    </article_galley>

      <volume>30</volume>

FILE #545:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="545" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-52.pdf</name>
    <file id="545" filesize="361007" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/52/30-52.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Mutation pairs and triangulated quotients</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce the notion of mutation pairs in pseudo-triangulated categories. Given such a mutation pair, we prove that the corresponding quotient category carries a natural triangulated structure under certain conditions. This result unifies many previous constructions of quotient triangulated categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
