    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Profinite topological spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is well known that profinite $T_0$-spaces are exactly the spectral spaces. We generalize this result to the category of all topological spaces by showing that the following conditions are equivalent: <br> (1) $(X,\tau)$ is a profinite topological space.<br> (2) The $T_0$-reflection of $(X,\tau)$ is a profinite $T_0$-space.<br> (3) $(X,\tau)$ is a quasi spectral space. <br> (4) $(X,\tau)$ admits a stronger Stone topology $\pi$ such that $(X, \tau,\pi)$ is a bitopological quasi spectral spaceMEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #547:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <name locale="en">30-54.pdf</name>
    <file id="547" filesize="621515" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/54/30-54.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Algebraically coherent categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We call a finitely complete category <i>algebraically coherent</i> if the change-of-base functors of its fibration of points are <i>coherent</i>, which means that they preserve finite limits and jointly strongly epimorphic pairs of arrows. We give examples of categories satisfying this condition; for instance, coherent categories and <i>categories of interest</i> in the sense of Orzech. We study equivalent conditions in the context of semi-abelian categories, as well as some of its consequences: including amongst others, strong protomodularity, and normality of Higgins commutators for normal subobjects, and in the varietal case, fibre-wise algebraic cartesian closedness.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>category of interest</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Groupoids in categories with pretopology</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We survey the general theory of groupoids, groupoid actions, groupoid principal bundles, and various kinds of morphisms between groupoids in the framework of categories with pretopology. The categories of topological spaces and finite or infinite dimensional manifolds are examples of such categories. We study extra assumptions on pretopologies that are needed for this theory. We check these extra assumptions in several categories with pretopologies.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #549:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="549" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">30-56.pdf</name>
    <file id="549" filesize="662741" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/30/56/30-56.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the 3-representations of groups and the 2-categorical traces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;To 2-categorify the theory of group representations, we introduce the notions of the 3-representation of a group in a strict 3-category and the strict 2-categorical action of a group on a strict 2-category. We also 2-categorify the concept of the trace by introducing the 2-categorical trace of a 1-endomorphism in a strict 3-category. For a 3-representation $\rho$ of a group G and an element f of G, the 2-categorical trace $Tr_2\rho_f$ is a category. Moreover, the centralizer of f in G acts categorically on this 2-categorical trace. We construct the induced strict 2-categorical action of a finite group, and show that the 2-categorical trace $Tr_2$ takes an induced strict 2-categorical action into an induced categorical action of the initia groupoid. As a corollary, we get the 3-character formula of the induced strict 2-categorical action.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2015</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>the 3-representation of a group in a 3-category</keyword>
      <keyword>the 2-categorical trace</keyword>
      <keyword>the 3-cocycle condition</keyword>
      <keyword>the induced strict 2-categorical actions</keyword>
      <keyword>the 3-character</keyword>
      <keyword>2-categorification</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="458">
        <givenname locale="en">Wei</givenname>

      </author>

FILE #550:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="550" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-01.pdf</name>
    <file id="550" filesize="454796" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/1/31-01.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Euler characteristic of an enriched category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We develop the homotopy theory of Euler characteristic (magnitude) of a category enriched in a monoidal model category. If a monoidal model category $V$ is equipped with an Euler characteristic that is compatible with weak equivalences and fibrations in $V$, then our Euler characteristic of $V$-enriched categories is also compatible with weak equivalences and fibrations in the canonical model structure on the category of $V$-enriched categories. In particular, we focus on the case of topological categories; i.e., categories enriched in the category of topological spaces. As its application, we obtain the ordinary Euler characteristic of a cellular stratified space $X$ by computing the Euler characteristic of the face category $C(X)$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Euler characteristic</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched categories</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal model categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="459">
        <givenname locale="en">Kazunori</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Noguchi</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    <title locale="en">The heart of a combinatorial model category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that every small model category that satisfies certain size conditions can be completed to yield a combinatorial model category, and conversely, every combinatorial model category arises in this way. We will also see that these constructions preserve right properness and compatibility with simplicial enrichment. Along the way, we establish some technical results on the index of accessibility of various constructions on accessible categories, which may be of independent interest.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #552:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="552" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-03.pdf</name>
    <file id="552" filesize="304078" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/3/31-03.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the magnitude of a finite dimensional algebra</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;There is a general notion of the magnitude of an enriched category, defined subject to hypotheses. In topological and geometric contexts, magnitude is already known to be closely related to classical invariants such as Euler characteristic and dimension. Here we establish its significance in an algebraic context. Specifically, in the representation theory of an associative algebra $A$, a central role is played by the indecomposable projective $A$-modules, which form a category enriched in vector spaces. We show that the magnitude of that category is a known homological invariant of the algebra: writing $\chi_A$ for the Euler form of $A$ and $S$ for the direct sum of the simple $A$-modules, it is $\chi_A(S,S)$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>magnitude</keyword>
      <keyword>indecomposable projective</keyword>
      <keyword>simple module</keyword>
      <keyword>Cartan matrix</keyword>
      <keyword>Euler form</keyword>
      <keyword>Cartan determinant conjecture</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="462">
        <givenname locale="en">Joseph</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Chuang</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">King</familyname>

    <title locale="en">A two-dimensional Birkhoff's theorem</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Birkhoff's variety theorem from universal algebra characterises equational subcategories of varieties. We give an analogue of Birkhoff's theorem in the setting of enrichment in categories. For a suitable notion of an equational subcategory we characterise these subcategories by their closure properties in the ambient algebraic category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #554:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="554" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="554" filesize="613507" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/5/31-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Enriched algebraic theories and monads for a system of arities</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Under a minimum of assumptions, we develop in generality the basic theory of universal algebra in a symmetric monoidal closed category $V$ with respect to a specified system of arities $j:J \hookrightarrow V$. Lawvere's notion of <i>algebraic theory</i> generalizes to this context, resulting in the notion of <i>single-sorted $V$-enriched $J$-cotensor theory</i>, or $J$-<i>theory</i> for short. For suitable choices of $V$ and $J$, such $J$-theories include the enriched algebraic theories of Borceux and Day, the enriched Lawvere theories of Power, the equational theories of Linton's 1965 work, and the $V$-theories of Dubuc, which are recovered by taking $J = V$ and correspond to arbitrary $V$-monads on $V$. We identify a modest condition on $j$ that entails that the $V$-category of $T$-algebras exists and is monadic over $V$ for every $J$-theory $T$, even when $T$ is not small and $V$ is neither complete nor cocomplete. We show that $j$ satisfies this condition if and only if $j$ presents $V$ as a free cocompletion of $J$ with respect to the weights for left Kan extensions along $j$, and so we call such systems of arities <i>eleutheric</i>. We show that $J$-theories for an eleutheric system may be equivalently described as (i) monads in a certain one-object bicategory of profunctors on $J$, and (ii) $V$-monads on $V$ satisfying a certain condition. We prove a characterization theorem for the categories of algebras of $J$-theories, considered as $V$-categories $A$ equipped with a specified $V$-functor $A \rightarrow V$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>algebraic theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Lawvere theory</keyword>
      <keyword>universal algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>monad</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category theory</keyword>
      <keyword>free cocompletion</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="389">
        <givenname locale="en">Rory B. B.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lucyshyn-Wright</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="554"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>31</volume>
      <year>2016</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>101-137</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #555:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="555" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="555" filesize="619178" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/6/31-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Relative symmetric monoidal closed categories I: Autoenrichment and change of base</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Symmetric monoidal closed categories may be related to one another not only by the functors between them but also by enrichment of one in another, and it was known to G. M. Kelly in the 1960s that there is a very close connection between these phenomena. In this first part of a two-part series on this subject, we show that the assignment to each symmetric monoidal closed category $V$ its associated $V$-enriched category $underline{V}$ extends to a 2-functor valued in an op-2-fibred 2-category of symmetric monoidal closed categories enriched over various bases. For a fixed $V$, we show that this induces a 2-functorial passage from symmetric monoidal closed categories <i>over</i> $V$ (i.e., equipped with a morphism to $V$) to symmetric monoidal closed $V$-categories over $underline{V}$. As a consequence, we find that the enriched adjunction determined a symmetric monoidal closed adjunction can be obtained by applying a 2-functor and, consequently, is an adjunction in the 2-category of symmetric monoidal closed $V$-categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>closed category</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal functor</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>2-category</keyword>
      <keyword>2-functor</keyword>
      <keyword>2-fibration</keyword>
      <keyword>pseudomonoid</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="389">
        <givenname locale="en">Rory B. B.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lucyshyn-Wright</familyname>

      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Transfinite limits in topos theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a coherent site we construct a canonically associated enlarged coherent site, such that cohomology of bounded below complexes is preserved by the enlargement. In the topos associated to the enlarged site transfinite compositions of epimorphisms are epimorphisms and a weak analog of the concept of the algebraic closure exists. The construction is a variant of the work of Bhatt and Scholze on the pro-etale topology.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">On biadjoint triangles</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove a biadjoint triangle theorem and its strict version, which are 2-dimensional analogues of the adjoint triangle theorem of Dubuc. Similarly to the 1-dimensional case, we demonstrate how we can apply our results to get the pseudomonadicity characterization (due to Le Creurer, Marmolejo and Vitale).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #559:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="559" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-10.pdf</name>
    <file id="559" filesize="940187" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/10/31-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Some insights on bicategories of fractions: representations and compositions of 2-morphisms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we investigate the construction of bicategories of fractions originally described by D.~Pronk: given any bicategory $C$ together with a suitable class of morphisms $W$, one can construct a bicategory $C[W^{-1}]$, where all the morphisms of $W$ are turned into internal equivalences, and that is universal with respect to this property. Most of the descriptions leading to this construction were long and heavily based on the axiom of choice. In this paper we considerably simplify the description of the equivalence relation on 2-morphisms and the constructions of associators, vertical and horizontal compositions in $C[W^{-1}]$, thus proving that the axiom of choice is not needed under certain conditions. The simplified description of associators and compositions will also play a crucial role in two forthcoming papers about pseudofunctors and equivalences between bicategories of fractions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>bicategories of fractions</keyword>
      <keyword>bicalculus of fractions</keyword>
      <keyword>pseudofunctors</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="468">
        <givenname locale="en">Matteo</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Tommasini</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Spectra of compact regular frames</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;By Isbell duality, each compact regular frame L is isomorphic to the frame of opens of a compact Hausdorff space X. In this note we study the spectrum Spec(L) of prime filters of a compact regular frame L. We prove that X is realized as the minimum of Spec(L) and the Gleason cover of X as the maximum of Spec(L). We also characterize zero-dimensional, extremally disconnected, and scattered compact regular frames by means of Spec(L).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Construction of categorical bundles from local data</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A categorical principal bundle is a structure comprised of categories that is analogous to a classical principal bundle; examples arise from geometric contexts involving bundles over path spaces. We show how a categorical principal bundle can be constructed from local data specified through transition functors and natural transformations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #565:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="565" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="565" filesize="396851" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/16/31-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Relative internal actions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a relative exact homological category (C,E), we define <i>relative points</i> over an arbitrary object in C, and show that they form an exact homological category. In particular, it follows that the full subcategory of nilpotent objects in an exact homological category is an exact homological category. These nilpotent objects are defined with respect to a Birkhoff subcategory in C as defined by T. Everaert and T. Van der Linden. In addition, we introduce <i>relative internal actions</i> and show that, just as in the classical case, there is an equivalence of categories between the category of relative points over an object and the category of relative internal actions for the same object.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>relative semi-abelian category</keyword>
      <keyword>relative homological category</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-abelian category</keyword>
      <keyword>homological category</keyword>
      <keyword>category of relative points</keyword>
      <keyword>relative internal actions</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #566:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="566" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="566" filesize="337494" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/17/31-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Right delocalization of model categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Model categories have long been a useful tool in homotopy theory, allowing many generalizations of results in topological spaces to other categories. Giving a localization of a model category provides an additional model category structure on the same base category, which alters what objects are being considered equivalent by increasing the class of weak equivalences. In some situations, a model category where the class of weak equivalences is restricted from the original one could be more desirable. In this situation we need the notion of a delocalization. In this paper, right Bousfield delocalization is defined, we provide examples of right Bousfield delocalization as well as an existence theorem. In particular, we show that given two model category structures $\MO$ and $\MT$ we can define an additional model category structure $\MO \cap \MT$ by defining the class of weak equivalences to be the intersection of the $\MO$ and $\MT$ weak equivalences. In addition we consider the model category on diagram categories over a base category (which is endowed with a model category structure) and show that delocalization is often preserved by the diagram model category structure.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>localization</keyword>
      <keyword>delocalization</keyword>
      <keyword>model categories</keyword>
      <keyword>diagram</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="473">
        <givenname locale="en">Bruce R</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Corrigan-Salter</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="566"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>31</volume>
      <year>2016</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>462-476</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #568:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="568" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-19.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The snail lemma</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The classical snake lemma produces a six terms exact sequence starting from a commutative square with one of the edge being a regular epimorphism. We establish a new diagram lemma, that we call snail lemma, removing such a condition. We also show that the snail lemma subsumes the snake lemma and we give an interpretation of the snail lemma in terms of strong homotopy kernels. Our results hold in any pointed regular protomodular category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>protomodular category</keyword>
      <keyword>strong homotopy kernel</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #569:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="569" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-20.pdf</name>
    <file id="569" filesize="564412" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/20/31-20.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Linear structures on locales</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a notion of morphism for quotient vector bundles that yields both a category $QVBun$ and a contravariant global sections functor $C:QVBun^{op} \to Vect$ whose restriction to trivial vector bundles with fiber F coincides with the contravariant functor $Top^{op} \to Vect$ of F-valued continuous functions. Based on this we obtain a linear extension of the adjunction between the categories of topological spaces and locales: (i) a linearized topological space is a <i>spectral vector bundle</i>, by which is meant a mildly restricted type of quotient vector bundle; (ii) a <i>linearized locale</i> is a locale $\Delta$ equipped with both a topological vector space A and a $\Delta$-valued <i>support map</i> for the elements of A satisfying a continuity condition relative to the spectrum of $\Delta$ and the lower Vietoris topology on $Sub A$; (iii) we obtain an adjunction between the full subcategory of spectral vector bundles $QVBun_\Sigma$ and the category of linearized locales $LinLoc$, which restricts to an equivalence of categories between sober spectral vector bundles and spatial linearized locales. The spectral vector bundles are classified by a finer topology on $Sub A$, called the open support topology, but there is no notion of universal spectral vector bundle for an arbitrary topological vector space A.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quotient vector bundles</keyword>
      <keyword>locales</keyword>
      <keyword>Banach bundles</keyword>
      <keyword>lower Vietoris topology</keyword>
      <keyword>Fell topology</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="477">
        <givenname locale="en">Pedro</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Resende</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

      </author>
    </authors>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Representation and character theory of finite categorical groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the gerbal representations of a finite group G or, equivalently, module categories over Ostrik's category $Vec_G^\alpha$ for a 3-cocycle $\alpha$. We adapt Bartlett's string diagram formalism to this situation to prove that the categorical character of a gerbal representation is a representation of the inertia groupoid of a categorical group. We interpret such a representation as a module over the twisted Drinfeld double $D^\alpha(G)$.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">Classical and relative realizability</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that every abstract Krivine structure in the sense of Streicher can be obtained, up to equivalence of the resulting tripos, from a filtered opca (A,A') and a subobject of 1 in the relative realizability topos RT(A',A); the topos is always a Boolean subtopos of RT(A',A). We exhibit a range of non-localic Boolean subtriposes of the Kleene-Vesley tripos.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #572:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="572" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-23.pdf</name>
    <file id="572" filesize="943675" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/23/31-23.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The linearity of traces in monoidal categories and bicategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that in any symmetric monoidal category, if a weight for colimits is absolute, then the resulting colimit of any diagram of dualizable objects is again dualizable. Moreover, in this case, if an endomorphism of the colimit is induced by an endomorphism of the diagram, then its trace can be calculated as a linear combination of traces on the objects in the diagram. The formal nature of this result makes it easy to generalize to traces in homotopical contexts (using derivators) and traces in bicategories. These generalizations include the familiar additivity of the Euler characteristic and Lefschetz number along cofiber sequences, as well as an analogous result for the Reidemeister trace, but also the orbit-counting theorem for sets with a group action, and a general formula for homotopy colimits over EI-categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>duality</keyword>
      <keyword>trace</keyword>
      <keyword>derivator</keyword>
      <keyword>absolute colimit</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="338">
        <givenname locale="en">Kate</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Ponto</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="256">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shulman</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #573:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="573" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    </file>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The local Joyal model structure</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The Joyal model structure on simplicial sets is extended to a model structure on the simplicial presheaves on a small site, in which the cofibrations are monomorphisms and the weak equivalences are local (or stalkwise) Joyal equivalences. The model structure is shown to be left proper.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>simplicial presheaves</keyword>
      <keyword>quasi-categories</keyword>

      <keyword>trace</keyword>
      <keyword>derivator</keyword>
      <keyword>absolute colimit</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Homotopy locally presentable enriched categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We develop a homotopy theory of categories enriched in a monoidal model category V. In particular, we deal with homotopy weighted limits and colimits, and homotopy local presentability. The main result, which was known for simplicially-enriched categories, links homotopy locally presentable V-categories with combinatorial model V-categories, in the case where all objects of V are cofibrant.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #575:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="575" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-26.pdf</name>
    <file id="575" filesize="360474" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/26/31-26.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Compact closed bicategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A compact closed bicategory is a symmetric monoidal bicategory where every object is equipped with a weak dual. The unit and counit satisfy the usual ``zig-zag'' identities of a compact closed category only up to natural isomorphism, and the isomorphism is subject to a coherence law. We give several examples of compact closed bicategories, then review previous work. In particular, Day and Street defined compact closed bicategories indirectly via Gray monoids and then appealed to a coherence theorem to extend the concept to bicategories; we restate the definition directly.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>compact</keyword>
      <keyword>closed</keyword>
      <keyword>bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>span 18D05</keyword>
      <keyword>18D15</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="483">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Stay</familyname>

    <title locale="en">The Fermat functors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we use some basic quasi-topos theory to study two functors: one adding infinitesimals of Fermat reals to diffeological spaces (which generalize smooth manifolds including singular spaces and infinite-dimensional spaces), and the other deleting infinitesimals on Fermat spaces. We study the properties of these functors, and calculate some examples. These serve as fundamentals for developing differential geometry on diffeological spaces using infinitesimals in a future paper.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">Enriched Yoneda lemma</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present a version of the enriched Yoneda lemma for conventional (not $\infty$-) categories. We do not require the base monoidal category M to be closed or symmetric monoidal. In the case M has colimits and the monoidal structure in M preserves colimits in each argument, we prove that the Yoneda embedding A to P_M(A) is a universal functor from A to a category with colimits, left-tensored over M.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en"><p> Projectivity, continuity and adjointness: quantales, Q-posets and Q-modules <p></title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, projective modules over a quantale are characterized by distributivity, continuity, and adjointness conditions. It is then shown that a morphism Q --> A of commutative quantales is coexponentiable if and only if the corresponding Q-module is projective, and hence, satisfies these equivalent conditions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #580:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="580" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="580" filesize="738551" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/31/31-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tannaka theory over sup-lattices and descent for topoi</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider locales B as algebras in the tensor category <i>sl</i> of sup-lattices. We show the equivalence between the Joyal-Tierney descent theorem for open localic surjections q : shB --> E in Galois theory and a Tannakian recognition theorem over <i>sl</i> for the <i>sl</i>-functor Rel (q^*) : Rel(E) --> Rel(shB) \cong (B-Mod)_0 into the <i>sl</i>-category of discrete B-modules. Thus, a new Tannaka recognition theorem is obtained, essentially different from those known so far. This equivalence follows from two independent results. We develop an explicit construction of the localic groupoid G associated by Joyal-Tierney to q, and do an exhaustive comparison with the Deligne Tannakian construction of the Hopf algebroid L associated to Rel(q^*), and show they are isomorphic, that is, L \cong O(G). On the other hand, we show that the <i>sl</i>-category of relations of the classifying topos of any localic groupoid G, is equivalent to the <i>sl</i>-category of L-comodules with discrete subjacent B-module, where L = O(G).}MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Tannaka</keyword>
      <keyword>Galois</keyword>
      <keyword>Sup-lattice</keyword>
      <keyword>Locale</keyword>
      <keyword>Topos</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="487">

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the representations of 2-groups in Baez-Crans 2-vector spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the theory of representations of a 2-group G in Baez-Crans 2-vector spaces over a field k of arbitrary characteristic, and the corresponding 2-vector spaces of intertwiners. We also characterize the irreducible and indecomposable representations. Finally, it is shown that when the 2-group is finite and the base field k is of characteristic zero or coprime to the orders of the homotopy groups of G, the theory essentially reduces to the theory of k-linear representations of the first homotopy group of G, the remaining homotopy invariants of G playing no role.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #582:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="582" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-33.pdf</name>
    <file id="582" filesize="779913" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/33/31-33.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Compositories and gleaves</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Sheaves are objects of a local nature: a global section is determined by how it looks locally. Hence, a sheaf cannot describe mathematical structures which contain global or nonlocal geometric information. To fill this gap, we introduce the theory of ``gleaves'', which are presheaves equipped with an additional ``gluing operation'' of compatible pairs of local sections. This generalizes the <i>conditional product</i> structures of Dawid and Studeny, which correspond to gleaves on distributive lattices. Our examples include the gleaf of metric spaces and the gleaf of joint probability distributions. A result of Johnstone shows that a category of gleaves can have a subobject classifier despite not being cartesian closed.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>sheaf theory</keyword>
      <keyword>uniqueness of gluing</keyword>
      <keyword>nerve of a category</keyword>
      <keyword>higher span</keyword>
      <keyword>conditional product distribution</keyword>
      <keyword>Lawvere metric space</keyword>
      <keyword>relational database</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="491">
        <givenname locale="en">Cecilia</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Flori</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="387">
        <givenname locale="en">Tobias</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Fritz</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="582"/>

      <volume>31</volume>
      <year>2016</year>
    </issue_identification>
    <pages>928-988</pages>
  </publication>

FILE #583:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="583" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-34.pdf</name>
    <file id="583" filesize="414928" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/34/31-34.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On Evrard's homotopy fibrant replacement of a functor</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We provide a more economical refined version of Evrard's categorical cocylinder factorization of a functor. We show that any functor between small categories can be factored into a homotopy equivalence followed by a (co)fibred functor which satisfies the (dual) assumption of Quillen's Theorem B.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Homotopy fibrant replacement of a functor</keyword>
      <keyword>Quillen theorem B</keyword>
      <keyword>Evrard s theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #584:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="584" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-35.pdf</name>
    <file id="584" filesize="469582" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/35/31-35.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monads on dagger categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The theory of monads on categories equipped with a dagger (a contravariant identity-on-objects involutive endofunctor) works best when all structure respects the dagger: the monad and adjunctions should preserve the dagger, and the monad and its algebras should satisfy the so-called Frobenius law. Then any monad resolves as an adjunction, with extremal solutions given by the categories of Kleisli and Frobenius-Eilenberg-Moore algebras, which again have a dagger. We characterize the Frobenius law as a coherence property between dagger and closure, and characterize strong such monads as being induced by Frobenius monoids.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Dagger category</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius monad</keyword>
      <keyword>Kleisli algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>Eilenberg-Moore algebra</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="278">

        <familyname locale="en">Heunen</familyname>

FILE #586:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="586" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-37.pdf</name>
    <file id="586" filesize="588881" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/37/31-37.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A functorial approach to Dedekind completions and the representation of vector lattices and l-algebras by normal functions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Unlike the uniform completion, the Dedekind completion of a vector lattice is not functorial. In order to repair the lack of functoriality of Dedekind completions, we enrich the signature of vector lattices with a proximity relation, thus arriving at the category <b>pdv</b> of proximity Dedekind vector lattices. We prove that the Dedekind completion induces a functor from the category <b>bav</b> of bounded archimedean vector lattices to <b>pdv</b>, which in fact is an equivalence. We utilize the results of Dilworth to show that every proximity Dedekind vector lattice D is represented as the normal real-valued functions on the compact Hausdorff space associated with D. This yields a contravariant adjunction between <b>pdv</b> and the category <b>KHaus</b> of compact Hausdorff spaces, which restricts to a dual equivalence between <b>KHaus</b> and the proper subcategory of <b>pdv</b> consisting of those proximity Dedekind vector lattices in which the proximity is uniformly closed. We show how to derive the classic Yosida Representation, Kakutani-Krein Duality, Stone-Gelfand-Naimark Duality, and Stone-Nakano Theorem from our approach.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Vector lattice</keyword>
      <keyword>$\ell$-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>uniform completion</keyword>
      <keyword>Dedekind completion</keyword>
      <keyword>compact Hausdorff space</keyword>
      <keyword>extremally disconnected space</keyword>
      <keyword>continuous real-valued function</keyword>
      <keyword>normal real-valued function</keyword>
      <keyword>proximity</keyword>
      <keyword>representation</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #587:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="587" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">31-38.pdf</name>
    <file id="587" filesize="590592" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/31/38/31-38.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Cosheafification</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is proved that for any small Grothendieck site X, there exists a coreflection (called \emph{cosheafification}) from the category of precosheaves on X with values in a category $K$, to the full subcategory of cosheaves, provided either $K$ or $K^{op}$ is locally presentable. If $K$ is cocomplete, such a coreflection is built explicitly for the (pre)cosheaves with values in the category $Pro(K)$ of pro-objects in $K$. In the case of precosheaves on topological spaces, it is proved that any precosheaf with values in $Pro(K)$ is <i>smooth</i>, i.e. is strongly locally isomorphic to a cosheaf. Constant cosheaves are constructed, and there are established connections with shape theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2016</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Cosheaves</keyword>
      <keyword>smooth precosheaves</keyword>
      <keyword>cosheafification</keyword>
      <keyword>pro-category</keyword>
      <keyword>cosheaf homology</keyword>
      <keyword>locally presentable categories</keyword>
      <keyword>accessible categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="495">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A structure theorem for quasi-Hopf bimodule coalgebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let H be a quasi-Hopf algebra. We show that any H-bimodule coalgebra C for which there exists an H-bimodule coalgebra morphism n : C -> H is isomorphic to what we will call a smash product coalgebra. To this end, we use an explicit monoidal equivalence between the category of two-sided two-cosided Hopf modules over H and the category of left Yetter-Drinfeld modules over H. This categorical method allows also to reobtain the structure theorem for a quasi-Hopf (bi)comodule algebra given by Panaite and Van Oystaeyen, and by Dello et al.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Simplicial Nerve of an $A_\infty$-category</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce a functor called the simplicial nerve of an $A_\infty$-category defined on the category of $A_\infty$-categories with values in simplicial sets. We show that the nerve of an $A_\infty$-category is an $(\infty,1)$-category in the sense of J. Lurie. This construction generalizes the nerve construction for differential graded categories given by Lurie. We prove that if a differential graded category is pretriangulated in the sense of A.I. Bondal and M. Kapranov then its nerve is a stable $(\infty,1)$-category in the sense of J. Lurie.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">C-systems defined by universe categories: presheaves</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The main result of this paper may be stated as a construction of "almost representations" $\mu_n$ and $\tilde{\mu}_n$ for the presheaves $\Ob_n$ and $\tilde{Ob}_n$ on the C-systems defined by locally cartesian closed universe categories with binary product structures and the study of the behavior of these "almost representations" with respect to the universe category functors. In addition, we study a number of constructions on presheaves on C-systems and on universe categories that are used in the proofs of our main results, but are expected to have other applications as well.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The $(\Pi,\lambda)$-structures on the C-systems defined by universe categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define the notion of a $(P,\tilde{P})$-structure on a universe $p$ in a locally cartesian closed category category with a binary product structure and construct a $(\Pi,\lambda)$-structure on the C-systems $CC(C,p)$ from a $(P,\tilde{P})$-structure on $p$. We then define homomorphisms of C-systems with $(\Pi,\lambda)$-structures and functors of universe categories with $(P,\tilde{P})$-structures and show that our construction is functorial relative to these definitions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #592:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="592" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="592" filesize="400113" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/5/32-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Bourn-normal monomorphisms in regular Mal'tsev categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Normal monomorphisms in the sense of Bourn describe the equivalence classes of an internal equivalence relation. Although the definition is given in the fairly general setting of a category with finite limits, later investigations on this subject often focus on protomodular settings, where normality becomes a property. This paper clarifies the connections between internal equivalence relations and Bourn-normal monomorphisms in regular Mal'tesv categories with pushouts of split monomorphisms along arbitrary morphisms, whereas a full description is achieved for quasi-pointed regular Mal'tsev categories with pushouts of split monomorphisms along arbitrary morphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>normal monomorphism</keyword>
      <keyword>Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>fibred category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="294">
        <givenname locale="en">Giuseppe</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Metere</familyname>

    <file id="593" filesize="992865" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/6/32-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Homotopy theory for algebras over polynomial monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the existence and left properness of transferred model structures for ``monoid-like'' objects in monoidal model categories. These include genuine monoids, but also all kinds of operads as for instance symmetric, cyclic, modular, higher operads, properads and PROP's. All these structures can be realised as algebras over polynomial monads. We give a general condition for a polynomial monad which ensures the existence and (relative) left properness of a transferred model structure for its algebras. This condition is of a combinatorial nature and singles out a special class of polynomial monads which we call tame polynomial. Many important monads are shown to be tame polynomial.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quillen model category</keyword>
      <keyword>polynomial monad</keyword>
      <keyword>coloured operad</keyword>
      <keyword>graph</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A note on injective hulls of posemigroups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this note, we prove the existence of $E_\leq$-injective hulls in the category $PoSgr_\leq$ of posemigroups and their submultiplicative order-preserving maps; here $E_\leq$ denotes the class of those morphisms $h : A \to B$ for which $h(a_1)...h(a_n)\leq h(a)$ always implies $a_1...a_n\leq a$. The result of this note subsumes the results given by Lambek et al. (2012) and by Zhang and Laan (2014).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>partially ordered semigroup</keyword>
      <keyword>quantale</keyword>
      <keyword>quantic nucleus</keyword>
      <keyword>injective hull</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Witt vectors and truncation posets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;One way to define Witt vectors starts with a truncation set $S \subset N$. We generalize Witt vectors to truncation posets, and show how three types of maps of truncation posets can be used to encode the following six structure maps on Witt vectors: addition, multiplication, restriction, Frobenius, Verschiebung and norm.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Witt vectors</keyword>
      <keyword>truncation posets</keyword>
      <keyword>Tambara functors</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <file id="596" filesize="612334" extension="pdf">

  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Classifying tangent structures using Weil algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;At the heart of differential geometry is the construction of the tangent bundle of a manifold. There are various abstractions of this construction, and of particular interest here is that of Tangent Structures. Tangent Structure is defined via giving an underlying category M and a tangent functor T along with a list of natural transformations satisfying a set of axioms, then detailing the behaviour of T in the category End(M). However, this axiomatic definition at first seems somewhat disjoint from other approaches in differential geometry. The aim of this paper is to present a perspective that addresses this issue. More specifically, this paper highlights a very explicit relationship between the axiomatic definition of Tangent Structure and the Weil algebras (which have a well established place in differential geometry).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Tangent Structure</keyword>
      <keyword>Weil algebra</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="504">
        <givenname locale="en">Poon</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Leung</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #597:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

    <file id="597" filesize="531376" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/10/32-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">KZ-monadic categories and their logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given an order-enriched category, it is known that all its KZ-monadic subcategories can be described by Kan-injectivity with respect to a collection of morphisms. We prove the analogous result for Kan-injectivity with respect to a collection H of commutative squares. A square is called a Kan-injective consequence of H if by adding it to H Kan-injectivity is not changed. We present a sound logic for Kan-injectivity consequences and prove that in ``reasonable" categories (such as $\Pos$ or $\Top_0$) it is also complete for every set H of squares.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>order-enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan-injectivity</keyword>
      <keyword>KZ-monad</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan-injectivity logic</keyword>
      <keyword>locally ranked category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    <name locale="en">32-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="598" filesize="381857" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/11/32-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Corelations are the prop for extraspecial commutative Frobenius monoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Just as binary relations between sets may be understood as jointly monic spans, so too may equivalence relations on the disjoint union of sets be understood as jointly epic cospans. With the ensuing notion of composition inherited from the pushout of cospans, we call these equivalence relations <i>corelations</i>. We define the category of corelations between finite sets and prove that it is equivalent to the prop for extraspecial commutative Frobenius monoids. Dually, we show that the category of relations is equivalent to the prop for special commutative bimonoids. Throughout, we emphasise how corelations model interconnection.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>corelation</keyword>
      <keyword>extra law</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius monoid</keyword>
      <keyword>prop</keyword>
      <keyword>PROP</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="505">
        <givenname locale="en">Brandon</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Coya</familyname>

FILE #599:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

    <file id="599" filesize="655322" extension="pdf">

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monoid-like definitions of cyclic operad</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Guided by the microcosm principle of Baez-Dolan and by the algebraic definitions of operads of Kelly and Fiore, we introduce two ``monoid-like'' definitions of cyclic operads, one for the original, ``exchangable-output'' characterisation of Getzler-Kapranov, and the other for the alternative ``entries-only'' characterisation, both within the category of Joyal's species of structures. Relying on a result of Lamarche on descent for species, we use these "monoid-like" definitions to prove the equivalence between the ``exchangable-output'' and ``entries-only'' points of view on cyclic operads.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>operads</keyword>
      <keyword>cyclic operads</keyword>
      <keyword>species of structures</keyword>
      <keyword>monoid</keyword>
      <keyword>microcosm principle</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Building a model category out of multiplier ideal sheaves</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We will construct a Quillen model structure out of the multiplier ideal sheaves on a smooth quasi-projective variety using earlier works of Isaksen and Barnea and Schlank. We also show that fibrant objects of this model category are made of kawamata log terminal pairs in birational geometry.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #601:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="601" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-14.pdf</name>
    <file id="601" filesize="617063" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/14/32-14.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A categorical approach to Picard-Vessiot theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Picard-Vessiot rings are present in many settings like differential Galois theory, difference Galois theory and Galois theory of Artinian simple module algebras. In this article we set up an abstract framework in which we can prove theorems on existence and uniqueness of Picard-Vessiot rings, as well as on Galois groups corresponding to the Picard-Vessiot rings. As the present approach restricts to the categorical properties which all the categories of differential modules resp.~difference modules etc.~share, it gives unified proofs for all these Galois theories (and maybe more general ones).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Tannakian categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Picard-Vessiot theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Galois theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="507">
        <givenname locale="en">Andreas</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Maurischat</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #602:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="602" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-15.pdf</name>
    <file id="602" filesize="431713" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/15/32-15.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Epireflective subcategories and formal closure operators</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;On a category $\mathscr{C}$ with a designated (well-behaved) class $\mathcal{M}$ of monomorphisms, a closure operator in the sense of D.~Dikranjan and E.~Giuli is a pointed endofunctor of $\mathcal{M}$, seen as a full subcategory of the arrow-category $\mathscr{C}^\mathbf{2}$ whose objects are morphisms from the class $\mathcal{M}$, which ``commutes'' with the codomain functor $\mathsf{cod}\colon \mathcal{M}\to \mathscr{C}$. In other words, a closure operator consists of a functor $C\colon \mathcal{M}\to\mathcal{M}$ and a natural transformation $c\colon 1_\mathcal{M}\to C$ such that $\mathsf{cod} \cdot C=C$ and $\mathsf{cod}\cdot c=1_\mathsf{cod}$. In this paper we adapt this notion to the domain functor $\mathsf{dom}\colon \mathcal{E}\to\mathscr{C}$, where $\mathcal{E}$ is a class of epimorphisms in $\mathscr{C}$, and show that such closure operators can be used to classify $\mathcal{E}$-epireflective subcategories of $\mathscr{C}$, provided $\mathcal{E}$ is closed under composition and contains isomorphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>category of morphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>category of epimorphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>category of monomorphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>cartesian lifting</keyword>
      <keyword>closure operator</keyword>
      <keyword>codomain functor</keyword>
      <keyword>cohereditary operator</keyword>
      <keyword>domain functor</keyword>
      <keyword>epimorphism</keyword>
      <keyword>epireflective subcategory</keyword>
      <keyword>form</keyword>

FILE #603:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="603" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="603" filesize="1252065" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/16/32-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Algebraic Databases</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Databases have been studied category-theoretically for decades. While mathematically elegant, previous categorical models have typically struggled withrepresenting concrete data such as integers or strings. In the present work, we propose an extension of the earlier set-valued functor model, making use of multi-sorted algebraic theories (a.k.a. Lawvere theories) to incorporate concrete data in a principled way. This approach easily handles missing information (null values), and also allows constraints and queries to make use of operations on data, such as multiplication or comparison of numbers, helping to bridge the gap between traditional databases and programming languages. We also show how all of the components of our model - including schemas, instances, change-of-schema functors, and queries fit into a single double categorical structure called a proarrow equipment (a.k.a. framed bicategory).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Databases</keyword>
      <keyword>algebraic theories</keyword>
      <keyword>proarrow equipments</keyword>
      <keyword>collage construction</keyword>
      <keyword>data migration</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="509">

FILE #604:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="604" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="604" filesize="458911" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/17/32-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The two out of three property in ind-categories and a convenient model category of spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The author and Tomer Schlank studied a much weaker homotopical structure than a model category, which we called a "weak cofibration category". We showed that a small weak cofibration category induces in a natural way a model category structure on its ind-category, provided the ind-category satisfies a certain two out of three property. The main purpose of this paper is to give sufficient intrinsic conditions on a weak cofibration category for this two out of three property to hold. We consider an application to the category of compact metrizable spaces, and thus obtain a model structure on its ind-category. This model structure is defined on a category that is closely related to a category of topological spaces and has many convenient formal properties. A more general application of these results, to the (opposite) category of separable $C^*$-algebras, appears in a paper by the author, Michael Joachim and Snigdhayan Mahanta.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Ind-categories</keyword>
      <keyword>model categories</keyword>
      <keyword>cofibration categories</keyword>
      <keyword>simplicially enriched categories</keyword>
      <keyword>compact Hausdorff spaces</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="512">
        <givenname locale="en">Ilan</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Barnea</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <title locale="en">Frobenius algebras and homotopy fixed points of group actions on bicategories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We explicitly show that symmetric Frobenius structures on a finite-dimensional, semi-simple algebra stand in bijection to homotopy fixed points of the trivial SO(2)-action on the bicategory of finite-dimensional, semi-simple algebras, bimodules and intertwiners. The results are motivated by the 2-dimensional Cobordism Hypothesis for oriented manifolds, and can hence be interpreted in the realm of Topological Quantum Field Theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
