    <title locale="en">A presentation of bases for parametrized iterativity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Finitary monads on a locally finitely presentable category A are well-known to possess a presentation by signatures and equations. Here we prove that, analogously, bases on A, i.e., finitary functors from A to the category of finitary monads on A, possess a presentation by parametrized signatures and equations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Closure operators in abelian categories and spectral spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give several new ways of constructing spectral spaces starting with objects in abelian categories satisfying certain conditions which apply, in particular, to Grothendieck categories. For this, we consider the spaces of invariants of closure operators acting on subobjects of a given object. The key to our results is a newly discovered criterion of Finocchiaro that uses ultrafilters to identify spectral spaces along with subbases of quasi-compact open sets.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Lax distributive laws for topology, II</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a small quantaloid Q we consider four fundamental 2-monads T on Q-<b>Cat</b>, given by the presheaf 2-monad P and the copresheaf 2-monad P^{\dagger}, as well as by their two composite 2-monads, and establish that they all laxly distribute over P. These four 2-monads therefore admit lax extensions to the category Q-<b>Dist</b> of Q-categories and their distributors. We characterize the corresponding (T,Q)-categories in each of the four cases, leading us to both known and novel categorical structures.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A property of effectivization and its uses in categorical logic</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that a fully faithful and covering regular functor between regular categories induces a fully faithful (and covering) functor between their respective effectivizations. Such a functor between effective categories is known to be an equivalence. We exploit this result in order to give a constructive proof of conceptual completeness for regular logic. We also use it in analyzing what it means for a morphism between effective categories to be a quotient in the 2-category of effective categories and regular functors between them.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

FILE #610:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Levi categories and graphs of groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a Levi category to be a weakly orthogonal category equipped with a suitable length functor and prove two main theorems about them. First, skeletal cancellative Levi categories are precisely the categorical versions of graphs of groups with a given orientation. Second, the universal groupoid of a skeletal cancellative Levi category is the fundamental groupoid of the corresponding graph of groups. These two results can be viewed as a co-ordinate-free refinement of a classical theorem of Philip Higgins.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Graphs of groups</keyword>
      <keyword>self-similar groupoid actions</keyword>
      <keyword>cancellative categories</keyword>
    </keywords>

      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="518">

FILE #611:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="611" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-24.pdf</name>
    <file id="611" filesize="257367" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/24/32-24.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Metric spaces and SDG</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We present an axiomatic theory, based on the notions of <i> metric space</i> and <i> space with a (first order) neighbour relation</i>. The axiomatics implies a synthetic proof of Huygens' principle of <i> wave fronts</i>, as envelopes of a family of spheres. A model of the axiomatics is presented in terms of synthetic differential geometry (SDG).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>metric spaces</keyword>
      <keyword>synthetic differential geometry</keyword>
    </keywords>

      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="20">

        <familyname locale="en">Kock</familyname>

    <title locale="en">A unifying approach to the acyclic models method and other lifting lemmas</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove a fundamental lemma of homological algebra and show how it sets a framework for many different lifting (or comparison) theorems of homological algebra and algebraic topology.     <title locale="en">Connections in tangent categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Connections are an important tool of differential geometry. This paper investigates their definition and structure in the abstract setting of tangent categories. At this level of abstraction we derive several classically important results about connections, including the Bianchi identities, identities for curvature and torsion, almost complex structure, and parallel transport.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #614:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="614" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-27.pdf</name>
    <file id="614" filesize="936629" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/27/32-27.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Biextensions, bimonoidal functors, multilinear functor calculus, and categorical rings</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We associate to a bimonoidal functor, i.e. a bifunctor which is monoidal in each variable, a nonabelian version of a biextension. We show that such a biextension satisfies additional triviality conditions which make it a bilinear analog of the kind of spans known as butterflies and, conversely, these data determine a bimonoidal functor. We extend this result to n-variables, and prove that, in a manner analogous to that of butterflies, these multi-extensions can be composed. This is phrased in terms of a multilinear functor calculus in a bicategory. As an application, we study a bimonoidal category or stack, treating the multiplicative structure as a bimonoidal functor with respect to the additive one. In the context of the multilinear functor calculus, we view the bimonoidal structure as an instance of the general notion of pseudo-monoid. We show that when the structure is ring-like, i.e. the pseudo-monoid is a stack whose fibers are categorical rings, we can recover the classification by the third Mac~Lane cohomology of a ring with values in a bimodule.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Categorical ring</keyword>
      <keyword>biextension</keyword>
      <keyword>bimonoidal</keyword>
      <keyword>ring-like stack</keyword>
      <keyword>butterfly</keyword>
      <keyword>multi-extension</keyword>
      <keyword>multi-category</keyword>
      <keyword>multi-functor</keyword>
      <keyword>Mac Lane cohomology</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="440">
        <givenname locale="en">Ettore</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Aldrovandi</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Urysohn type lemma for groupoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Starting from the observation that through groupoids we can express in a unified way the notions of fundamental system of entourages of a uniform structure on a space X, respectively the system of neighborhoods of the unity of a topological group that determines its topology, we introduce in this paper a notion of G-uniformity for a groupoid G. The topology induced by a G-uniformity turns G into a topological locally transitive groupoid. We also prove a Urysohn type lemma for groupoids and obtain metrization theorems for groupoids unifying in two ways the Alexandroff-Urysohn Theorem and Birkhoff-Kakutani Theorem.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

FILE #616:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="616" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-29.pdf</name>
    <file id="616" filesize="546013" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/29/32-29.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A bicategory of decorated cospans</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;If C is a category with pullbacks then there is a bicategory with the same objects as C, spans as morphisms, and maps of spans as 2-morphisms, as shown by Benabou. Fong has developed a theory of `decorated cospans', which are cospans in C equipped with extra structure. This extra structure arises from a symmetric lax monoidal functor F : C --> D; we use this functor to `decorate' each cospan with apex N in C with an element of F(N). Using a result of Shulman, we show that when C has finite colimits, decorated cospans are morphisms in a symmetric monoidal bicategory. We illustrate our construction with examples from electrical engineering and the theory of chemical reaction networks.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>decorated cospan</keyword>
      <keyword>network</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="522">
        <givenname locale="en">Kenny</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Courser</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The canonical 2-gerbe of a holomorphic vector bundle</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For each holomorphic vector bundle we construct a holomorphic bundle 2-gerbe that geometrically represents its second Beilinson-Chern class. Applied to the cotangent bundle, this may be regarded as a higher analogue of the canonical line bundle in complex geometry. Moreover, we exhibit the precise relationship between holomorphic and smooth gerbes. For example, we introduce an Atiyah class for gerbes and prove a Koszul-Malgrange type theorem.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>Second Chern class</keyword>
      <keyword>Complex manifolds</keyword>
      <keyword>Holomorphic vector bundles</keyword>
    </keywords>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Classifiers for monad morphisms and adjunction morphisms</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We provide an explicit model for the free 2-category containing n composable adjunction morphisms, comparable to the Schanuel and Street model for the free adjunction. We can extract from it an explicit model for the free 2-category containing n composable lax monad morphisms. A careful proof is given, which goes through presentations of the hom-categories of our model. We use one of these hom-categories as an indexing category to construct an extended Artin-Mazur codiagonal, whose underlying bisimplicial set has the classical Artin-Mazur codiagonal as its first column.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

FILE #619:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="619" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-32.pdf</name>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Free objects over posemigroups in the category PoSgr_v</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;As we all know, the complete lattice I_D(S) of all D-ideals of a meet-semilattice S is precisely the injective hull of S in the category of meet-semilattices. In this paper, we consider sm-ideals of posemigroups which can be regarded as a generalization of D-ideals of meet-semilattices. Unfortunately, the quantale R(S) of all sm-ideals of a posemigroup S is in general not an injective hull of S. However, R(S) can be seen as a new type of quantale completions of S. Further, we can see that R(S) is also a free object over S in the category PoSgr_v of posemigroups with sm-distributive join homomorphisms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>partially ordered semigroup</keyword>
      <keyword>injective hull</keyword>
      <keyword>quantale</keyword>
      <keyword>quantale completion</keyword>
      <keyword>free object</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #620:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="620" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-33.pdf</name>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Combinatorics of past-similarity in higher dimensional transition systems</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The key notion to understand the left determined Olschok model category of star-shaped Cattani-Sassone transition systems is past-similarity. Two states are past-similar if they have homotopic pasts. An object is fibrant if and only if the set of transitions is closed under past-similarity. A map is a weak equivalence if and only if it induces an isomorphism after the identification of all past-similar states. The last part of this paper is a discussion about the link between causality and homotopy.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>left determined model category</keyword>
      <keyword>combinatorial model category</keyword>
      <keyword>discrete model structure</keyword>
      <keyword>higher dimensional transition system</keyword>
      <keyword>causal structure</keyword>
      <keyword>bisimulation</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="100">
        <givenname locale="en">Philippe</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Gaucher</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #621:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="621" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-34.pdf</name>
    <file id="621" filesize="654843" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/34/32-34.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Dold-Kan theorem for simplicial Lie algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce and study <i>hypercrossed complexes of Lie algebras</i>, that is, non-negatively graded chain complexes of Lie algebras $L=(L_n,\partial_n)$ endowed with an additional structure by means of a suitable set of bilinear maps $L_r\times L_s\rightarrow L_n$. The Moore complex of any simplicial Lie algebra acquires such a structure and, in this way, we prove a Dold-Kan type equivalence between the category of simplicial Lie algebras and the category of hypercrossed complexes of Lie algebras. Several consequences of examining particular classes of hypercrossed complexes of Lie algebras are presented.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Dold-Kan theorem</keyword>
      <keyword>simplicial Lie algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>chain complex</keyword>
      <keyword>Moore complex</keyword>
      <keyword>hypercrossed complex</keyword>
    </keywords>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Localization of enriched categories and cubical sets</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The invertibility hypothesis for a monoidal model category S asks that localizing an S-enriched category with respect to an equivalence results in an weakly equivalent enriched category. This is the most technical among the axioms for S to be an <i>excellent model category</i> in the sense of Lurie, who showed that the category Cat_S of S-enriched categories then has a model structure with characterizable fibrant objects. We use a universal property of cubical sets, as a monoidal model category, to show that the invertibility hypothesis is a consequence of the other axioms.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Enriched localization</keyword>
      <keyword>invertibility hypothesis</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

        <givenname locale="en">Tyler</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lawson</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/36/32-36.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Coexponentiability and Projectivity: Rigs, Rings, and Quantales</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that a commutative monoid A is coexponentiable in CMon(V) if and only if $-\otimes A : V \to V$ has a left adjoint, when V is a cocomplete symmetric monoidal closed category with finite biproducts and in which every object is a quotient of a free. Using a general characterization of the latter, we show that an algebra over a rig or ring R is coexponentiable if and only if it is finitely generated and projective as an R-module. Omitting the finiteness condition, the same result (and proof) is obtained for algebras over a quantale.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/37/32-37.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Hopf polyads, Hopf categories and Hopf group monoids viewed as Hopf monads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We associate, in a functorial way, a monoidal bicategory Span|V to any monoidal bicategory V. Two examples of this construction are of particular interest: <i>Hopf polyads</i> of Bruguieres can be seen as Hopf monads in Span|Cat while <i>Hopf group monoids</i> in the spirit of Zunino and Turaev in a braided monoidal category V, and <i>Hopf categories</i> of Batista-Caenepeel-Vercruysse over V both turn out to be Hopf monads in Span|V. Hopf group monoids and Hopf categories are Hopf monads on a distinguished type of monoidales fitting the framework of Bohm-Lack. These examples are related by a monoidal pseudofunctor V -> Cat.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

    <title locale="en">Fibered multiderivators and (co)homological descent</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The theory of derivators enhances and simplifies the theory of triangulated categories. In this article a notion of fibered (multi)derivator is developed, which similarly enhances fibrations of (monoidal) triangulated categories. We present a theory of cohomological as well as homological descent in this language. The main motivation is a descent theory for Grothendieck's six operations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Kan's combinatorial spectra and their sheaves revisited</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define a right Cartan-Eilenberg structure on the category of Kan's combinatorial spectra, and the category of sheaves of such spectra, assuming some conditions. In both structures, we use the geometric concept of homotopy equivalence as the strong equivalence. In the case of sheaves, we use local equivalence as the weak equivalence. This paper is the first step in a larger-scale program of investigating sheaves of spectra from a geometric viewpoint.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #627:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="627" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-40.pdf</name>
    <file id="627" filesize="859581" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/40/32-40.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Operads and phylogenetic trees</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We construct an operad Phyl whose operations are the edge-labelled trees used in phylogenetics. This operad is the coproduct of Com, the operad for commutative semigroups, and $[0,\infty)$, the operad with unary operations corresponding to nonnegative real numbers, where composition is addition. We show that there is a homeomorphism between the space of n-ary operations of Phyl and $\T_n\times [0,\infty)^{n+1}$, where $\T_n$ is the space of metric n-trees introduced by Billera, Holmes and Vogtmann. Furthermore, we show that the Markov models used to reconstruct phylogenetic trees from genome data give coalgebras of Phyl. These always extend to coalgebras of the larger operad Com + $[0,\infty]$, since Markov processes on finite sets converge to an equilibrium as time approaches infinity. We show that for any operad O, its coproduct with $[0,\infty]$ contains the operad W(O) constructed by Boardman and Vogt. To prove these results, we explicitly describe the coproduct of operads in terms of labelled trees.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>operads</keyword>
      <keyword>trees</keyword>
      <keyword>phylogenetic trees</keyword>
      <keyword>Markov processes</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="160">
        <givenname locale="en">John C.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Baez</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    </authors>

    <title locale="en">Topological properties of non-Archimedean approach spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we give an isomorphic description of the category of non-Archimedian approach spaces as a category of lax algebras for the ultrafilter monad and an appropriate quantale. Non-Archimedean approach spaces are characterised as those approach spaces having a tower consisting of topologies. We study topological properties p, for p compactness and Hausdorff separation along with low-separation properties, regularity, normality and extremal disconnectedness and link these properties to the condition that all or some of the level topologies in the tower have p. A compactification technique is developed based on Shanin's method.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #629:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="629" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-42.pdf</name>
    <file id="629" filesize="392794" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/42/32-42.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Mal'tsev objects, $R_1$-spaces and ultrametric spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we introduce a notion of Mal'tsev object, and the dual notion of co-Mal'tsev object, in a general category. In particular, a category C is a Mal'tsev category if and only if every object in C is a Mal'tsev object. We show that for a well-powered regular category C which admits coproducts, the full subcategory of Mal'tsev objects is coreflective in C. We show that the co-Mal'tsev objects in the category of topological spaces and continuous maps are precisely the $R_1$-spaces, and that the co-Mal'tsev objects in the category of metric spaces and short maps are precisely the ultrametric spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>$R_1$-space</keyword>
      <keyword>ultrametric space</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #630:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="630" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-43.pdf</name>
    <file id="630" filesize="405391" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/43/32-43.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Action representability via spans and prefibrations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give several reformulations of action representability of a category as well as action representability of its category of morphisms. In particular we show that for a semi-abelian category C, its category of morphisms is action representable if and only if the functor from the category of split extensions in C to C, sending a split extension to its kernel, is a prefibration. To obtain these reformulations we show that certain conditions are equivalent for right regular spans of categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>action representable</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-abelian</keyword>
      <keyword>split extension</keyword>
      <keyword>normalizer</keyword>
      <keyword>prefibration</keyword>
      <keyword>regular span</keyword>

    <title locale="en">Stability properties characterising n-permutable categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The purpose of this paper is two-fold. A first and more concrete aim is to characterise n-permutable categories through certain stability properties of regular epimorphisms. These characterisations allow us to recover the ternary terms and the (n+1)-ary terms describing n-permutable varieties of universal algebras.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="633" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">32-46.pdf</name>
    <file id="633" filesize="311338" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/32/46/32-46.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A characterization of the Huq commutator</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study a categorical commutator, introduced by Huq, defined for a pair of coterminal morphisms. We show that in a normal unital category C with finite colimits, the normal closure of the regular image of the Huq commutator of a pair of subobjects under an arbitrary morphism is the same as the Huq commutator of their respective regular images. Then we use this property to characterize the Huq commutator as the largest commutator satisfying certain properties.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2017</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Commuting morphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>Commutator</keyword>
      <keyword>Normal</keyword>
      <keyword>Ideal-determined</keyword>
      <keyword>Unital category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="538">
        <givenname locale="en">Vaino Tuhafeni</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shaumbwa</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>

    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Spans of cospans in a topos</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a topos T, there is a bicategory MonicSp(Csp(T)) whose objects are those of T, morphisms are cospans in T, and 2-morphisms are isomorphism classes of monic spans of cospans in T. Using a result of Shulman, we prove that MonicSp(Csp(T)) is symmetric monoidal, and moreover, that it is compact closed in the sense of Stay. We provide an application which illustrates how to encode double pushout rewrite rules as 2-morphisms inside a compact closed sub-bicategory of MonicSp(Csp(Graph)).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>graph rewrite</keyword>
      <keyword>network</keyword>
      <keyword>span</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal</keyword>
      <keyword>topos</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Actor of a crossed module of Leibniz algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We extend to the category of crossed modules of Leibniz algebras the notion of biderivation via the action of a Leibniz algebra. This results into a pair of Leibniz algebras which allow us to construct an object which is the actor under certain circumstances. Additionally, we give a description of an action in the category of crossed modules of Leibniz algebras in terms of equations. Finally, we check that, under the aforementioned conditions, the kernel of the canonical map from a crossed module to its actor coincides with the center and we introduce the notions of crossed module of inner and outer biderivations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">On fibrant objects in model categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we study properties of maps between fibrant objects in model categories. We give a characterization of weak equivalences between fibrant objects. If every object of a model category is fibrant, then we give a simple description of a set of generating cofibrations. We show that to construct such a model structure it is enough to check some relatively simple conditions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #638:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="638" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="638" filesize="548554" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/5/33-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Contravariance through enrichment</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We define strict and weak duality involutions on 2-categories, and prove a coherence theorem that every bicategory with a weak duality involution is biequivalent to a 2-category with a strict duality involution. For this purpose we introduce "2-categories with contravariance", a sort of enhanced 2-category with a basic notion of "contravariant morphism", which can be regarded either as generalized multicategories or as enriched categories. This enables a universal characterization of duality involutions using absolute weighted colimits, leading to a conceptual proof of the coherence theorem.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>opposite category</keyword>
      <keyword>contravariant functor</keyword>
      <keyword>generalized multicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>enriched category</keyword>
      <keyword>coherence theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="256">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Shulman</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #639:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="639" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="639" filesize="374629" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/6/33-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Spans of cospans</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study spans of cospans in a category <b>C</b> and explain how to horizontally and vertically compose these. When <b>C</b> is a topos and the legs of the spans are monic, these two forms of composition satisfy the interchange law. In this case there is a bicategory of objects, cospans, and `monic-legged' spans of cospans in <b>C</b>. One motivation for this construction is an application to graph rewriting.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>cospans</keyword>
      <keyword>bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>graph rewriting</keyword>
      <keyword>adhesive category</keyword>
      <keyword>network theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="539">
        <givenname locale="en">Daniel</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cicala</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>

FILE #640:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="640" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="640" filesize="596930" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/7/33-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Regular patterns, substitudes, Feynman categories and operads</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that the regular patterns of Getzler (2009) form a 2-category biequivalent to the 2-category of substitudes of Day and Street (2003), and that the Feynman categories of Kaufmann and Ward (2013) form a 2-category biequivalent to the 2-category of coloured operads (with invertible 2-cells). These biequivalences induce equivalences between the corresponding categories of algebras. There are three main ingredients in establishing these biequivalences. The first is a strictification theorem (exploiting Power's General Coherence Result) which allows to reduce to the case where the structure maps are identity-on-objects functors and strict monoidal. Second, we subsume the Getzler and Kaufmann-Ward hereditary axioms into the notion of Guitart exactness, a general condition ensuring compatibility between certain left Kan extensions and a given monad, in this case the free-symmetric-monoidal-category monad. Finally we set up a biadjunction between substitudes and what we call pinned symmetric monoidal categories, from which the results follow as a consequence of the fact that the hereditary map is precisely the counit of this biadjunction.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>operads</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="365">
        <givenname locale="en">Michael</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Batanin</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="547">
        <givenname locale="en">Joachim</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Kock</familyname>

      </author>

      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #641:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="641" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="641" filesize="521148" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/8/33-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A construction of certain weak colimits and an exactness property of the 2-category of categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Given a 2-category $A$, a 2-functor $F : A \to Cat$ and a distinguished 1-subcategory $\Sigma \subset A$ containing all the objects, a $\sigma$-cone for $F$ (with respect to $\Sigma$) is a lax cone such that the structural 2-cells corresponding to the arrows of $\Sigma$ are invertible. The conical $\sigma$-limit} is the universal (up to isomorphism) $\sigma$-cone. The notion of $\sigma$-limit generalizes the well known notions of pseudo and lax limit. We consider the fundamental notion of $\sigma$-filtered pair $(A, \Sigma)$ which generalizes the notion of 2-filtered 2-category. We give an explicit construction of $\sigma$-filtered $\sigma$-colimits of categories, a construction which allows computations with these colimits. We then state and prove a basic exactness property of the 2-category of categories, namely, that $\sigma$-filtered $\sigma$-colimits commute with finite weighted pseudo (or bi) limits. An important corollary of this result is that a $\sigma$-filtered $\sigma$-colimit of exact category valued 2-functors is exact. This corollary is essential in the 2-dimensional theory of flat and pro-representable 2-functors, that we develop elsewhere.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>weak colimit</keyword>
      <keyword>filtered</keyword>
      <keyword>2-category</keyword>
      <keyword>exactness property</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A Brauer-Clifford-Long group for the category of dyslectic Hopf Yetter-Drinfel'd (S,H)-module algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Brauer-Clifford groups are equivariant Brauer groups for which a Hopf algebra acts or coacts nontrivially on the base ring. Brauer-Clifford groups have been established previously in the category of modules for a skew group ring S#G, the category of modules for the smash product S#H over a cocommutative Hopf algebra H, and its dual category of (S,H)-Hopf modules over a commutative Hopf algebra H. In this article the authors introduce a Brauer-Clifford group for the category of dyslectic Hopf Yetter-Drinfel'd (S,H)-modules for an H-commutative base ring S and quantum group H. This is the first such example in a category of modules for a quantum group, and it gives a new example of an equivariant Brauer group in a braided monoidal category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

      <keyword>Brauer groups</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Nearly locally presentable categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We introduce a new class of categories generalizing locally presentable ones. The distinction does not manifest in the abelian case and, assuming Vopenka's principle, the same happens in the regular case. The category of complete partial orders is the natural example of a nearly locally finitely presentable category which is not locally presentable.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">A characterization of final functors between internal groupoids in exact categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper provides three characterizations of final functors between internal groupoids in an exact category (in the sense of Barr). In particular, it is proved that a functor between internal groupoids is final if and only if it is internally full and essentially surjective.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Generating the algebraic theory of C(X): the case of partially ordered compact spaces</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is known since the late 1960's that the dual of the category of compact Hausdorff spaces and continuous maps is a variety - not finitary, but bounded by $\aleph_1$. In this note we show that the dual of the category of partially ordered compact spaces and monotone continuous maps is an $\aleph_1$-ary quasivariety, and describe partially its algebraic theory. Based on this description, we extend these results to categories of Vietoris coalgebras and homomorphisms on ordered compact spaces. We also characterise the $\aleph_1$-copresentable partially ordered compact spaces.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Revisiting the canonicity of canonical triangulations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Stable derivators provide an enhancement of triangulated categories as is indicated by the existence of canonical triangulations. In this paper we show that exact morphisms of stable derivators induce exact functors of canonical triangulations, and similarly for arbitrary natural transformations. This 2-categorical refinement also provides a uniqueness statement concerning canonical triangulations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="647" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-15.pdf</name>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Pseudo-Kan extensions and descent theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;There are two main constructions in classical descent theory: the category of algebras and the descent category, which are known to be examples of weighted bilimits. We give a formal approach to descent theory, employing formal consequences of commuting properties of bilimits to prove classical and new theorems in the context of Janelidze-Tholen ``Facets of Descent II'', such as Benabou-Roubaud Theorems, a Galois Theorem, embedding results and formal ways of getting effective descent morphisms. In order to do this, we develop the formal part of the theory on commuting bilimits via pseudomonad theory, studying idempotent pseudomonads and proving a 2-dimensional version of the adjoint triangle theorem. Also, we work out the concept of pointwise pseudo-Kan extension, used as a framework to talk about bilimits, commutativity and the descent object. As a subproduct, this formal approach can be an alternative perspective/guiding template for the development of higher descent theory.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

FILE #648:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="648" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-16.pdf</name>
    <file id="648" filesize="476525" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/16/33-16.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Lax pullback complements and pullbacks of spans</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The formation of the "strict" span category Span(C) of a category C with pullbacks is a standard organizational tool of category theory. Unfortunately, limits or colimits in Span(C) are not easily computed in terms of constructions in C. This paper shows how to form the pullback in Span(C) for many, but not all, pairs of spans, given the existence of some specific so-called lax pullback complements in C of the "left legs" of at least one of the two given spans. For some types of spans we require the ambient category to be adhesive to be able to form at least a weak pullback in Span(C). The existence of all lax pullback complements in C along a given morphism is equivalent to the exponentiability of that morphism. Since exponentiability is a rather restrictive property of a morphism, the paper first develops a comprehensive framework of rules for individual lax pullback complement diagrams, which resembles the set of pasting and cancellation rules for pullback diagrams, including their behaviour under pullback. We also present examples of lax pullback complements along non-exponentiable morphisms, obtained via lifting along a fibration.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">

      <keyword>exponentiable morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>partial product</keyword>
      <keyword>adhesive category</keyword>
      <keyword>span category</keyword>
      <keyword>total spans</keyword>
      <keyword>cototal spans</keyword>
      <keyword>partial morphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>categories of presheaves</keyword>
      <keyword>graphs</keyword>
      <keyword>topological spaces</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="557">

        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="558">

        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="648"/>
    </article_galley>
    <issue_identification>
      <volume>33</volume>
      <year>2018</year>
    </issue_identification>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <name locale="en">33-17.pdf</name>
    <file id="649" filesize="373214" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/17/33-17.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Double power monad preserving adjunctions are Frobenius</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We give a direct proof that between two toposes, F and E, bounded over a base topos S, adjunctions L -| R: Loc_F -> Loc_E over Loc_S are Frobenius if and only if R commutes with the double power locale monad and finite coproducts. The proof uses only certain categorical properties of the category of locales, Loc. This implies that between categories axiomatized to behave like categories of locales, it does not make a difference whether maps are defined as structure preserving adjunctions (i.e. those that commute with the double power monads) or Frobenius adjunctions.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="650" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-18.pdf</name>

      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/18/33-18.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Regularity vs. constructive complete (co)distributivity</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;It is well known that a relation $\phi$ between sets is regular if, and only if, $K\phi$ is completely distributive (cd), where $K\phi$ is the complete lattice consisting of fixed points of the Kan adjunction induced by $\phi$. For a small quantaloid Q, we investigate the Q-enriched version of this classical result, i.e., the regularity of Q-distributors versus the constructive complete distributivity (ccd) of Q-categories, and prove that ``the dual of $K\phi$ is (ccd) implies $\phi$ is regular implies $K\phi$ is (ccd)'' for any Q-distributor $\phi$. Although the converse implications do not hold in general, in the case that Q is a commutative integral quantale, we show that these three statements are equivalent for any $\phi$ if, and only if, Q is a Girard quantale.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Quantaloid</keyword>

      <keyword>Girard quantale</keyword>
      <keyword>Regular $\mathcal{Q}$-distributor</keyword>
      <keyword>Complete distributivity</keyword>
      <keyword>Kan adjunction</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #652:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="652" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-20.pdf</name>
    <file id="652" filesize="582913" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/20/33-20.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Higher isotropy</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper is about an invariant of small categories called \emph{isotropy}. Every small category C has associated with it a presheaf of groups on C, called its <i>isotropy group</i>, which in a sense solves the problem of making the assignment C |-> Aut(C) functorial. Consequently, every category has a canonical congruence that annihilates the isotropy; however, it turns out that the resulting quotient may itself have non-trivial isotropy. This phenomenon, which we term <i>higher order isotropy</i>, is the subject of our investigation. We show that with each category C we may associate a sequence of groups called its higher isotropy groups, and that these give rise to a sequence of quotients of C. This sequence leads us to an ordinal invariant for small categories, which we call <i>isotropy rank</i>: the isotropy rank of a small category is the ordinal at which the sequence of quotients stabilizes. Our main results state that each small category has a well-defined isotropy rank, and moreover, that for each small ordinal one may construct a small category with precisely that rank. It happens that isotropy rank of a small category is an instance of the same concept for Grothendieck toposes, for which corresponding statements hold. Most of the technical work in the paper is concerned with the development of tools that allow us to compute (higher) isotropy groups of categories in terms of those of certain suitable subcategories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>utomorphism groups</keyword>
      <keyword>algebraic invariants of categories</keyword>
      <keyword>toposes</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="560">
        <givenname locale="en">J.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Funk</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="561">
        <givenname locale="en">P.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Hofstra</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="562">
        <givenname locale="en">S.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Khan</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #653:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="653" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-21.pdf</name>
    <file id="653" filesize="478457" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/21/33-21.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Theory of interleavings on categories with a flow</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The interleaving distance was originally defined in the field of Topological Data Analysis (TDA) by Chazal et al. as a metric on the class of persistence modules parametrized over the real line. Bubenik et al. subsequently extended the definition to categories of functors on a poset, the objects in these categories being regarded as `generalized persistence modules'. These metrics typically depend on the choice of a lax semigroup of endomorphisms of the poset. The purpose of the present paper is to develop a more general framework for the notion of interleaving distance using the theory of `actegories'. Specifically, we extend the notion of interleaving distance to arbitrary categories equipped with a flow, i.e. a lax monoidal action by the monoid $[0,\infty)$. In this way, the class of objects in such a category acquires the structure of a Lawvere metric space. Functors that are colax $[0,\infty)$-equivariant yield maps that are 1-Lipschitz. This leads to concise proofs of various known stability results from TDA, by considering appropriate colax $[0,\infty)$-equivariant functors. Along the way, we show that several common metrics, including the Hausdorff distance and the $L^\infty$-norm, can be realized as interleaving distances in this general perspective.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Topological Data Analysis</keyword>
      <keyword>Persistent Homology</keyword>
      <keyword>Category Theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Lawvere Metric Spaces</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="563">
        <givenname locale="en">V. de</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Silva</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="564">

        <familyname locale="en">Munch</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="565">

        <familyname locale="en">Stefanou</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="654" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-22.pdf</name>
    <file id="654" filesize="539264" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/22/33-22.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Decorated corelations</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let $C$ be a category with finite colimits, and let $(E, M)$ be a factorisation system on $C$ with $M$ stable under pushout. Writing $C;M^{\op}$ for the symmetric monoidal category with morphisms cospans of the form $\stackrel{c}\to \stackrel{m}\leftarrow$, where $c \in C$ and $m \in M$, we give a method for constructing a category from a symmetric lax monoidal functor $F : (C; \mc M^{\op},+) \to (Set,\times)$. A morphism in this category, termed a <i>decorated corelation</i>, comprises (i) a cospan $X \to N \leftarrow Y$ in $C$ such that the canonical copairing $X+Y \to N$ lies in $E$, together with (ii) an element of $FN$. Functors between decorated corelation categories can be constructed from natural transformations between the decorating functors $F$. This provides a general method for constructing hypergraph categories - symmetric monoidal categories in which each object is a special commutative Frobenius monoid in a coherent way - and their functors. Such categories are useful for modelling network languages, for example circuit diagrams, and such functors are useful for modelling their semantics.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>decorated cospan</keyword>
      <keyword>corelation</keyword>
      <keyword>Frobenius monoid</keyword>
      <keyword>hypergraph category</keyword>
      <keyword>well-supported compact closed category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="435">
        <givenname locale="en">Brendan</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Fong</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

    <title locale="en">A parallel section functor for 2-vector bundles</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We associate to a 2-vector bundle over an essentially finite groupoid a 2-vector space of parallel sections, or, in representation theoretic terms, of higher invariants, which can be described as homotopy fixed points. Our main result is the extension of this assignment to a symmetric monoidal 2-functor $Par : 2VecBunGrpd \to 2Vect$. It is defined on the symmetric monoidal bicategory $2VecBunGrpd$ whose morphisms arise from spans of groupoids in such a way that the functor $Par$ provides pull-push maps between 2-vector spaces of parallel sections of 2-vector bundles. The direct motivation for our construction comes from the orbifoldization of extended equivariant topological field theories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #656:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="656" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-24.pdf</name>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Spheres as Frobenius objects</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Following the pattern of the Frobenius structure usually assigned to the 1-dimensional sphere, we investigate the Frobenius structures of spheres in all other dimensions. Starting from dimension d=1, all the spheres are commutative Frobenius objects in categories whose arrows are (d+1)-dimensional cobordisms. With respect to the language of Frobenius objects, there is no distinction between these spheres - they are all free of additional equations formulated in this language. The corresponding structure makes out of the 0-dimensional sphere not a commutative but a symmetric Frobenius object. This sphere is mapped to a matrix Frobenius algebra by a 1-dimensional topological quantum field theory, which corresponds to the representation of a class of diagrammatic algebras given by Richard Brauer.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>normal form</keyword>
      <keyword>coherence</keyword>
      <keyword>topological quantum field theory</keyword>
      <keyword>Brauerian representation</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #657:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="657" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-25.pdf</name>
    <file id="657" filesize="664382" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/25/33-25.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Props in network theory</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Long before the invention of Feynman diagrams, engineers were using similar diagrams to reason about electrical circuits and more general networks containing mechanical, hydraulic, thermodynamic and chemical components. We can formalize this reasoning using props: that is, strict symmetric monoidal categories where the objects are natural numbers, with the tensor product of objects given by addition. In this approach, each kind of network corresponds to a prop, and each network of this kind is a morphism in that prop. A network with $m$ inputs and $n$ outputs is a morphism from $m$ to $n$, putting networks together in series is composition, and setting them side by side is tensoring. Here we work out the details of this approach for various kinds of electrical circuits, starting with circuits made solely of ideal perfectly conductive wires, then circuits with passive linear components, and then circuits that also have voltage and current sources. Each kind of circuit corresponds to a mathematically natural prop. We describe the `behavior' of these circuits using morphisms between props. In particular, we give a new construction of the black-boxing functor of Fong and the first author; unlike the original construction, this new one easily generalizes to circuits with nonlinear components. We also use a morphism of props to clarify the relation between circuit diagrams and the signal-flow diagrams in control theory. Technically, the key tools are the Rosebrugh-Sabadini-Walters result relating circuits to special commutative Frobenius monoids, the monadic adjunction between props and signatures, and a result saying which symmetric monoidal categories are equivalent to props.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>circuit</keyword>
      <keyword>functorial semantics</keyword>
      <keyword>network</keyword>
      <keyword>PROP</keyword>
      <keyword>symmetric monoidal category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="160">
        <givenname locale="en">John C.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Baez</familyname>

    <title locale="en">Spark complexes on good effective orbifold atlases categorically</title>

    </file>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The Ehresmann-Schein-Nambooripad Theorem for inverse categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The Ehresmann-Schein-Nambooripad (ESN) Theorem asserts an equivalence between the category of inverse semigroups and the category of inductive groupoids. In this paper, we consider the category of inverse categories and functors - a natural generalization of inverse semigroups and semigroup homomorphisms - and extend the ESN Theorem to an equivalence between this category and the category of locally complete inductive groupoids and locally inductive functors. From the proof of this extension, we also generalize the ESN Theorem to an equivalence between the category of inverse semicategories and the category of locally inductive groupoids and to an equivalence between the category of inverse categories with oplax functors and the category of locally complete inductive groupoids and ordered functors.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #660:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="660" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-28.pdf</name>
    <file id="660" filesize="591667" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/28/33-28.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On the geometric notion of connection and its expression in tangent categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;<i>Tangent categories</i> provide an axiomatic approach to key structural aspects of differential geometry that exist not only in the classical category of smooth manifolds but also in algebraic geometry, homological algebra, computer science, and combinatorics. Generalizing the notion of \textit{(linear) connection} on a smooth vector bundle, Cockett and Cruttwell have defined a notion of connection on a differential bundle in an arbitrary tangent category. Herein, we establish equivalent formulations of this notion of connection that reduce the amount of specified structure required. Further, one of our equivalent formulations substantially reduces the number of axioms imposed, and others provide useful abstract conceptualizations of connections. In particular, we show that a connection on a differential bundle $E$ over $M$ is equivalently given by a single morphism $K$ that induces a suitable decomposition of $TE$ as a biproduct. We also show that a connection is equivalently given by a vertical connection $K$ for which a certain associated diagram is a limit diagram.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>affine connection</keyword>
      <keyword>vector bundle</keyword>
      <keyword>differential bundle</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Crossed products of crossed modules of Hopf monoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we consider a crossed product of two crossed modules of Hopf monoids in a strict symmetric monoidal category ${\mathcal C}$ and give necessary and sufficient conditions to get a new crossed module of Hopf monoids in ${\mathcal C}$. Moreover we introduce the notion of projection of crossed modules of Hopf monoids and show that with additional hypotheses, any of these projections defines a new crossed module of Hopf monoids and allows us to construct an example of this kind of crossed product. Finally, we develop the explicit computations of a crossed product associated to a projection of crossed modules in groups.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #662:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="662" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">33-30.pdf</name>
    <file id="662" filesize="823123" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/33/30/33-30.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Coalgebroids in monoidal bicategories and their comodules</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Quantum categories have been recently studied because of their relation to bialgebroids, small categories, and skew monoidales. This is the first of a series of papers based on the author's PhD thesis in which we examine the theory of quantum categories developed by Day, Lack, and Street. A quantum category is an opmonoidal monad on the monoidale associated to a biduality $R\dashv R^{o}$, or enveloping monoidale, in a monoidal bicategory of modules $\Mod(V})$ for a monoidal category $V$. Lack and Street proved that quantum categories are in equivalence with right skew monoidales whose unit has a right adjoint in $\Mod(V)$. Our first important result is similar to that of Lack and Street. It is a characterisation of opmonoidal <i>arrows</i> on enveloping monoidales in terms of a new structure named <i>oplax action</i>. We then provide three different notions of comodule for an opmonoidal arrow, and using a similar technique we prove that they are equivalent. Finally, when the opmonoidal arrow is an opmonoidal monad, we are able to provide the category of comodules for a quantum category with a monoidal structure such that the forgetful functor is monoidal.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>coalgebroid</keyword>
      <keyword>comodules</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidale</keyword>
      <keyword>skew monoidale</keyword>
      <keyword>oplax action</keyword>
      <keyword>monoidal bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>bicategory</keyword>
      <keyword>quantum category</keyword>
      <keyword>bialgebroid</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="577">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Tube representations and twisting of graded categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study deformation of tube algebra under twisting of graded monoidal categories. When a tensor category $C$ is graded over a group $\Gammaa$, a torus-valued 3-cocycle on $\Gammaa$ can be used to deform the associator of $C$. We show that it induces a 2-cocycle on the groupoid of the adjoint action of $\Gammaa$. Combined with the natural Fell bundle structure of tube algebra over this groupoid, we show that the tube algebra of the twisted category is a 2-cocycle twisting of the original one.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2018</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">On a higher structure on operadic deformation complexes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we prove that there is a canonical homotopy (n+1)-algebra structure on the shifted operadic deformation complex $\Def(e_n\to\mathcal{P})[-n]$ for any operad $\mathcal{P}$ and a map of operads $f\colon e_n\to\mathcal{P}$. This result generalizes a result of Tamarkin, who considered the case $\mathcal{P}=\End_\Op(X)$. Another more computational proof of the same result was recently sketched by Calaque and Willwacher.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
