        <familyname locale="en">Barhite</familyname>

      </author>

FILE #948:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="948" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-24.pdf</name>
    <file id="948" filesize="649540" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/24/41-24.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Free precategories as presheaf categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Precategories generalize both the notions of strict n-category and sesquicategory: their definition is essentially the same as the one of strict n-categories, excepting that the various interchange laws are not required to hold. Those have been proposed as a framework in which one can express semi-strict definitions of weak higher categories. In particular, in dimension 3, Gray categories are particular 3-precategories which have been shown to be equivalent to tricategories. In this article, we are mostly interested in free precategories. Those can be presented by generators and relations, using an appropriate variation on the notion of polygraph (aka computad), and earlier works have shown that the theory of rewriting can be generalized to this setting, enjoying most of the fundamental constructions and properties which can be found in the traditional theory: with respect to this, polygraphs for precategories are much better behaved than their counterpart for strict categories. We further study here why this is the case, by providing several results which show that precategories and their associated polygraphs bear properties which ensure that we have a good syntax for those. In particular, we show that the category of polygraphs for precategories form a presheaf category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>precategory</keyword>
      <keyword>polygraph</keyword>
      <keyword>Conduch&eacute</keyword>
      <keyword>functor</keyword>
      <keyword>polyplex</keyword>
      <keyword>parametric adjunction</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="841">
        <givenname locale="en">Simon</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Forest</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="842">
        <givenname locale="en">Samuel</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Mimram</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #949:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="949" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-25.pdf</name>
    <file id="949" filesize="386059" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/25/41-25.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">From Specker &#8467;-groups to boolean algebras via &Gamma;</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The author constructed in 1986 an equivalence &Gamma; between abelian &#8467;-groups with a strong unit and C.C. Chang MV-algebras. In 1958 Chang proved that boolean algebras coincide with MV-algebras satisfying the equation x &oplus; x = x. In this paper it is proved that &Gamma; yields, by restriction, an equivalence between the category S of Specker &#8467;-groups whose distinguished unit is singular, and the category of boolean algebras. As a consequence, Grothendieck's K_0 functor yields an equivalence between abelian Bratteli AF-algebras and the countable fragment of S. An equivalence in the opposite direction is obtained by a combination of &Gamma; with the Stone and Gelfand dualities.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>-group</keyword>
      <keyword>MV-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>boolean algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>spectral space</keyword>
      <keyword>AF-algebra</keyword>
      <keyword>Gelfand duality</keyword>
      <keyword>Grothendieck K_0</keyword>
    </keywords>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Lifting twisted coreflections against delta lenses</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Delta lenses are functors equipped with a suitable choice of lifts, generalising the notion of split opfibration. In recent work, delta lenses were characterised as the right class of an algebraic weak factorisation system. In this paper, we show that this algebraic weak factorisation system is cofibrantly generated by a small double category, and characterise the left class as split coreflections with a certain property; we call these twisted coreflections. We demonstrate that every twisted coreflection arises as a pushout of an initial functor from a discrete category along a bijective-on-objects functor. Throughout the article, we take advantage of a reformulation of algebraic weak factorisation systems, due to Bourke, based on double-categorical lifting operations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>lifting</keyword>
      <keyword>opfibration</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">Relative ideals in homological categories with an application to MV-algebras</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let A be a homological category and U: B &rarr; A be a faithful conservative right adjoint. We introduce the notion of <i>relative ideal</i> with respect to U and show that, under suitable conditions, any object of A can be seen as a relative ideal of some object in B. We then develop a <i>case study</i>: we first prove that the category of hoops is semi-abelian and that the category of MV-algebras is protomodular; then we apply our results to the forgetful functor from the category of MV-algebras to the category of Wajsberg hoops.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

    <title locale="en">Indexed Grothendieck construction</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We produce an indexed version of the Grothendieck construction. This gives an equivalence of categories between opfibrations over a fixed base in the 2-category of 2-copresheaves and 2-copresheaves on the Grothendieck construction of the fixed base. We also prove that this equivalence is pseudonatural in the base and that it restricts to discrete opfibrations with small fibres and copresheaves. Our result is a 2-dimensional generalization of the equivalence between slices of copresheaves and copresheaves on slices. We can think of the indexed Grothendieck construction as a simultaneous Grothendieck construction on every index that takes into account all bonds between different indexes.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="953" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-29.pdf</name>
    <file id="953" filesize="552442" extension="pdf">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">On domain-like objects in the category of unitary rings</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In the category C of unitary rings, Barr, Kennison and Raphael (2015) studied the limit closures of various classes of commutative integral domains; in particular the class of all domains and of integrally closed domains to form the reflective subcategories K_dom and K_ic. This article looks at K_dom(R) and K_ic(R) - the same symbols are used for the subcategories and the reflection functors - for some rings R. The objects in K_dom can be called "domain-like". Of particular interest is the ring C^1(R), the ring of real functions with continuous first derivative. The ring L is that of continuous functions that are C^1 on a dense open set of R. Then K_dom(C^1(R)) &sub; K_ic(C^1(R)) &sub; L, with proper inclusions. Moreover, for f in K_dom(C^1(R)), f has one-sided derivatives and those are one-sided continuous. <p> For commutative rings R &sub; S in R there is a subring of the integral closure of R in S introduced here, called the <i>split integral closure</i>, that is explored and turns out to be very useful.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>commutative semiprime rings</keyword>
      <keyword>domain objects</keyword>
      <keyword>limit closures</keyword>
      <keyword>$\Co$ functions</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="144">

      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #954:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="954" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-30.pdf</name>
    <file id="954" filesize="561210" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/30/41-30.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Pointwise Kan extensions along 2-fibrations and the 2-category of elements</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study the 2-category of elements from an abstract point of view. We generalize to dimension 2 the well-known result that the category of elements can be captured by a comma object that also exhibits a pointwise left Kan extension. For this, we propose an original definition of pointwise Kan extension along a discrete 2-opfibration in the lax 3-category of 2-categories, 2-functors, lax natural transformations and modifications. Such definition uses cartesian-marked lax limits, which are an alternative to weighted 2-limits. We show that a pointwise Kan extension along a discrete 2-opfibration is always a weak one as well. The proof is based on an original generalization of the parametrized Yoneda lemma which is as lax as it can be.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>

      <keyword>2-categories</keyword>
    </keywords>

FILE #955:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="955" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-31.pdf</name>
    <file id="955" filesize="439780" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/31/41-31.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Weak vertical composition II: totalities</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We continue our study of semi-strict tricategories in which the only weakness is in vertical composition. We assemble the doubly-degenerate such tricategories into a 2-category, defining weak functors and transformations. We exhibit a biadjoint biequivalence between this 2-category and the 2-category of braided (weakly) monoidal categories, braided (weakly) monoidal functors, and monoidal transformations.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Torsion aspects of varieties of simplicial groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;There is a lattice of torsion theories in simplicial groups such that the torsion/torsion-free categories are given by simplicial groups with truncated Moore complex below/above a certain degree. We study the restriction of these torsion theories to certain subcategories of simplicial groups. In particular, we prove that the categories of D. Conduch&eacute;'s 2-crossed modules and Ashley's crossed complexes in groups are semi-abelian and we give some descriptions of their torsion theories. These examples of torsion theories also give rise to new examples of pretorsion theories in the sense of A. Facchini and C. Finocchiaro, as well as examples of torsion torsion-free theories (TTF theories).MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #957:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="957" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-33.pdf</name>
    <file id="957" filesize="786385" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/33/41-33.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The category of extensions and idempotent completion</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Building on previous work, we study the splitting of idempotents in the category of extensions E-Ext(C) associated to a pair (C,E) of an additive category and a biadditive functor to the category of abelian groups. In particular, we show that idempotents split in E-Ext(C) whenever they do so in C, allowing us to prove that idempotent completions and extension categories are compatible constructions in a 2-category-theoretic sense. Furthermore, we show that the exact category obtained by first taking the idempotent completion of an n-exangulated category (C,E,s), in the sense of Klapproth-Msapato-Shah, and then considering its category of extensions is equivalent to the exact category obtained by first passing to the extension category and then taking the idempotent completion. These two different approaches yield a pair of 2-functors each taking small n-exangulated categories to small idempotent complete exact categories. The collection of equivalences that we provide constitutes a 2-natural transformation between these 2-functors. Similar results with no smallness assumptions and regarding weak idempotent completions are also proved.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Category of extensions</keyword>
      <keyword>additive category</keyword>

      <keyword>idempotent completion</keyword>

      <keyword>n-exangulated functor</keyword>
      <keyword>n-exangulated natural transformation</keyword>
      <keyword>2-category</keyword>

    </keywords>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Kleisli categories, T-categories and internal categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We investigate the properties of the Kleisli category Kl T of a monad T on a category E and in particular the existence of (some kind of) pullbacks. This culminates when the monad is cartesian. In this case, we show that any T-category in E in the sense of A. Burroni coincides with a special kind of internal category in Kl T. Thus, it is the case in particular for T-operads and T-multicategories. More unexpectedly, this, in turn, sheds new conceptual lights on internal categories and n-categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

    <title locale="en">Some properties of internal locale morphisms externalised</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study morphisms of internal locales of Grothendieck toposes externally: treating internal locales and their morphisms as sheaves and natural transformations. We characterise those morphisms of internal locales that induce surjective geometric morphisms and geometric embeddings, demonstrating that both can be characterised `pointwise'. We also show that the co-frame operations on the co-frame of internal sublocales admit a `pointwise' description too.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #960:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="960" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-36.pdf</name>
    <file id="960" filesize="3936504" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/36/41-36.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Condensation inversion and Witt equivalence via generalised orbifolds</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In Mulevi&#269;ius-Runkel, Quant. Topol. 13:3 (2022), it was shown how a so-called orbifold datum A in a given modular fusion category (MFC) C produces a new MFC C(A). Examples of these associated MFCs include condensations, i.e. the categories of local modules of a separable commutative algebra B in C. In this paper we prove that the relation C~C(A) on MFCs is the same as Witt equivalence. This is achieved in part by providing one with an explicit construction for inverting condensations, i.e. finding an orbifold datum A in the category of local modules of B, whose associated MFC is equivalent to C. As a tool used in this construction we also explore what kinds of functors F:C->D between MFCs preserve orbifold data. It turns out that F need not necessarily be strong monoidal, but rather a `ribbon Frobenius' functor, which has weak monoidal and weak comonoidal structures, related by a Frobenius-like property.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>modular tensor categories</keyword>
      <keyword>orbifold construction</keyword>
      <keyword>topological quantum field theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="852">
        <givenname locale="en">Vincentas</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Mulevi&#269;ius</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #961:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="961" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-37.pdf</name>
    <file id="961" filesize="781474" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/37/41-37.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Categorical generalisations of quantum double models</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We show that every involutive Hopf monoid in a complete and finitely cocomplete symmetric monoidal category gives rise to invariants of oriented surfaces defined in terms of ribbon graphs. For every ribbon graph this yields an object in the category, defined up to isomorphism, that depends only on the homeomorphism class of the associated surface. This object is constructed via (co)equalisers and images and equipped with a mapping class group action. It can be viewed as a categorical generalisation of the ground state of Kitaev's quantum double model or of a representation variety for a surface. We apply the construction to group objects in cartesian monoidal categories, in particular to simplicial groups as group objects in SSet and to crossed modules as group objects in Cat. The former yields a simplicial set consisting of representation varieties, the latter a groupoid whose sets of objects and morphisms are obtained from representation varieties.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>representation varieties</keyword>
      <keyword>Hopf monoids in symmetric monoidal categories</keyword>
      <keyword>group objects</keyword>
      <keyword>crossed modules</keyword>
      <keyword>quantum double models</keyword>
      <keyword>mapping class group actions</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="853">
        <givenname locale="en">Anna-Katharina</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Hirmer</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

        <familyname locale="en">Meusburger</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>

    <title locale="en">String diagrams for 4-categories and fibrations of mapping 4-groupoids</title>

    <title locale="en">The stable category of preordered groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this article, we present the stable category of preordered groups associated with some Z-pretorsion theory. We first define such a category as well as the related functor, and then study their properties. By doing so, we provide a description of both Z-kernels and Z-cokernels in the category of preordered groups. Finally, we prove the universal property of the stable category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #964:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="964" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-40.pdf</name>

  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Towards constructivising the Freyd-Mitchell Embedding Theorem</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The aim of the paper is to first point out that the classical proof of the Freyd-Mitchell Embedding Theorem does not work in CZF; then, to show how to embed in a constructive way a small abelian category into the category of sheaves of modules over a ringed space.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>abelian categories</keyword>
      <keyword>embedding</keyword>
      <keyword>CZF</keyword>
      <keyword>IZF</keyword>

FILE #965:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="965" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-41.pdf</name>
    <file id="965" filesize="598647" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/41/41-41.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Filtral pretoposes and compact Hausdorff locales</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The category of compact Hausdorff locales is a pretopos which is filtral, meaning that every object is covered by one whose subobject lattice is isomorphic to the lattice of filters of complemented elements. We show that any filtral pretopos satisfying some mild additional conditions can be embedded into the category of compact Hausdorff locales. This result is valid in the internal logic of any topos. Assuming the principle of weak excluded middle and the existence of copowers of the terminal object in the pretopos, the image of the embedding contains all spatial compact Hausdorff locales. <p> The notion of filtrality was introduced by V. Marra and L. Reggio (Theory Appl. Categ., 2020) to characterise the category of compact Hausdorff spaces within the class of pretoposes. Our results can be regarded as a constructive extension of the aforementioned characterisation, avoiding reference to points. If the ambient logic is classical, i.e. it satisfies excluded middle, and the prime ideal theorem for Boolean algebras holds, we obtain as a corollary the characterisation of compact Hausdorff spaces in <i>op. cit</i>.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>compact Hausdorff locales</keyword>
      <keyword>pretopos</keyword>
      <keyword>filtrality</keyword>
      <keyword>constructive locale theory</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #966:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="966" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-42.pdf</name>
    <file id="966" filesize="653821" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/42/41-42.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A 2-categorical analysis of context comprehension</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We consider the equivalence between the two main categorical models for the type-theoretical operation of context comprehension, namely P. Dybjer's categories with families and B. Jacobs' comprehension categories, and generalise it to the non-discrete case. The classical equivalence can be summarised in the slogan: "terms as sections". By recognising "terms as coalgebras", we show how to use the structure-semantics adjunction to prove that a 2-category of comprehension categories is biequivalent to a 2-category of (non-discrete) categories with families. The biequivalence restricts to the classical one proved by Hofmann in the discrete case. It also provides a framework where to compare different morphisms of these structures that have appeared in the literature, varying on the degree of preservation of the relevant structure. We consider in particular morphisms defined by Claraimbault-Dybjer, Jacobs, Larrea, and Uemura.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>dependent type theory</keyword>
      <keyword>category with families</keyword>
      <keyword>comprehension category</keyword>
      <keyword>structure-semantics adjunction</keyword>
      <keyword>2-category theory</keyword>
      <keyword>coalgebra</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="859">
        <givenname locale="en">Greta</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Coraglia</familyname>

FILE #967:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="967" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-43.pdf</name>
    <file id="967" filesize="470430" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/43/41-43.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">From Ramsey degrees to Ramsey expansions via weak amalgamation</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper we provide another argument to support the recently reinvigorated interest in treating Ramsey-type phenomena categorically. Using purely categorical strategies we construct a Ramsey expansion for every category of finite objects with finite small Ramsey degrees. Our construction is based on the relationship between small Ramsey degrees, weak amalgamation, and recent results about weak Fra&iuml;ss&eacute; categories. Starting from the fact that weak Fra&iuml;ss&eacute; categories allow for certain model-theoretic properties to be reflected in the free &omega;-cocompletion of the category, we show that classes with finite Ramsey degrees have weak amalgamation and then invoke the machinery of weak Fra&iuml;ss&eacute; categories to perform the construction. This improves previous similar results where an analogous construction was carried out under the assumption that everything sits comfortably in a bigger class with enough infrastructure, and that in this wider context there is an ultrahomogeneous structure under whose umbrella the construction takes place.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Fra&iuml</keyword>
      <keyword>ss&eacute</keyword>

      <keyword>free &omega</keyword>
      <keyword>-cocompletion</keyword>
      <keyword>Ramsey degrees</keyword>
      <keyword>Ramsey expansion</keyword>
      <keyword>weak amalgamation</keyword>
    </keywords>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Monadic functors forgetful of (dis)inhibited actions</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove a number of results of the following common flavor: for a category C of topological or uniform spaces with all manner of other properties of common interest (separation / completeness / compactness axioms), a group (or monoid) G equipped with various types of topological structure (topologies, uniformities) and the corresponding category C^G of appropriately compatible G-flows in C, the forgetful functor C^G &rarr; C is monadic. In all cases of interest the domain category C^G is also cocomplete, so that results on adjunction lifts along monadic functors apply to provide equivariant completion and/or compactification functors. This recovers, unifies and generalizes a number of such results in the literature due to de Vries, Mart'yanov and others on existence of equivariant compactifications / completions and cocompleteness of flow categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

    <title locale="en">Comparing 2-crossed modules with Gray 3-groups</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In this paper, we have constructed the close relationship between 2-crossed modules and Gray 3-groupoids with a single object (Gray 3-groups). Using both the equivalence between 2-crossed modules and Gray 3-groups, and the Gray category structure over the category of chain complexes of vector spaces; we describe linear representations as certain 3-functors.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="970" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">41-46.pdf</name>
    <file id="970" filesize="748275" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/41/46/41-46.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Graded braided commutativity in Hochschild cohomology</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We prove the graded braided commutativity of the Hochschild cohomology of A with trivial coefficients, where A is a braided Hopf algebra in the category of Yetter-Drinfeld modules over the group algebra of an abelian group, under some finiteness conditions on a projective resolution of A as A-bimodule. This is a generalization of a result by Mastnak, Pevtsova, Schauenburg and Witherspoon to a context which includes Nichols algebras such as the Jordan and the super Jordan plane. We prove this result by constructing a coduoid-up-to-homotopy structure on the aforementioned projective resolution in the duoidal category of chain complexes of A-bimodules. We also prove that the Hochschild complex of a braided bialgebra A in an arbitrary braided monoidal category is a cocommutative comonoid up to homotopy with the deconcatenation product which induces the cup product in Hochschild cohomology.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>

    </keywords>

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A coherence theorem for pseudo symmetric multifunctors</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Donald Yau defined the notion of pseudo symmetric Cat-enriched multifunctor between Cat-enriched multicategories and proved that Mandell's inverse K-theory multifunctor is pseudo symmetric. We prove a coherence theorem for pseudo symmetric Cat-enriched multifunctors. As an application we prove that pseudo symmetric Cat-enriched multifunctors, and in particular Mandell's inverse K-theory, preserve &Sigma;-free E_n-algebras (n=1,2,...,&infin;), at the cost of changing the parameterizing &Sigma;-free E_n-operad O for the &Sigma;-free E_n-operad O x E&Sigma;_*.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Yoneda lemma and representation theorem for double categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study (vertically) normal lax double functors valued in the weak double category Cat of small categories, functors, profunctors and natural transformations, which we refer to as lax double presheaves. We show that for the theory of double categories they play a similar role as 2-functors valued in Cat for 2-categories. We first introduce representable lax double presheaves and establish a Yoneda lemma. Then we build a Grothendieck construction which gives a 2-equivalence between lax double presheaves and discrete double fibrations over a fixed double category. Finally, we prove a representation theorem showing that a lax double presheaf is represented by an object if and only if its Grothendieck construction has a double terminal object.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Double categories</keyword>
      <keyword>presheaves</keyword>
      <keyword>Yoneda lemma</keyword>
      <keyword>Grothendieck construction</keyword>
      <keyword>representation theorem</keyword>
    </keywords>

    <title locale="en">What is the universal property of the 2-category of monads?</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;For a 2-category K, we consider Street's 2-category Mnd(K) of monads in K, along with Lack and Street's 2-category EM(K) and the identity-on-objects-and-1-cells 2-functor Mnd(K) &rarr; EM(K) between them. We show that this 2-functor can be obtained as a "free completion" of the 2-functor 1: K &rarr; K. We do this by regarding 2-functors which act as the identity on both objects and 1-cells as categories enriched a cartesian closed category BO whose objects are identity-on-objects functors. We also develop some of the theory of BO-enriched categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #975:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="975" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-02.pdf</name>
    <file id="975" filesize="402835" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/2/42-02.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Inner automorphisms as 2-cells</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Abstract inner automorphisms can be used to promote any category into a 2-category, and we study two-dimensional limits and colimits in the resulting 2-categories. Existing connected colimits and limits in the starting category become two-dimensional colimits and limits under fairly general conditions. Under the same conditions, colimits in the underlying category can be used to build many notable two-dimensional colimits such as coequifiers and coinserters. In contrast, disconnected colimits or genuinely 2-categorical limits such as inserters and equifiers and cotensors cannot exist unless no nontrivial abstract inner automorphisms exist and the resulting 2-category is locally discrete. We also study briefly when an ordinary functor can be extended to a 2-functor between the resulting 2-categories.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Topological endomorphism monoids of models of geometric theories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;A classical model theory result states that for a (set-theoretic) model of a first-order theory, there is a Galois connection between subgroups of the automorphism group of the model and `relational extensions' of the model, and the subgroups which are fixed by this connection are precisely the closed subgroups for the `pointwise convergence topology' on the automorphism group. We prove an analogous result for endomorphism monoids of models, grounded in the theory of classifying toposes. In particular, we show that the topos of continuous actions of the endomorphism monoid with respect to the pointwise convergence topology classifies a natural theory associated to the model.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>

FILE #977:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">

  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Quotients, pure existential completions and arithmetic universes</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We provide a new description of Joyal's arithmetic universes through a characterization of the exact and regular completions of pure existential completions. <p> We show that the regular and exact completions of the pure existential completion of an elementary doctrine Pare equivalent to the reg/lex and ex/lex-completions, respectively, of the category of predicates of P. <p> This result generalizes a previous one by the first author with F. Pasquali and G. Rosolini about doctrines equipped with Hilbert's 	&epsilon;-operators. <p> Thanks to this characterization, each arithmetic universe in the sense of Joyal can be seen as the exact completion of the pure existential completion of the doctrine of predicates of its Skolem theory. <p> In particular, the initial arithmetic universe in the standard category of ZFC-sets turns out to be the completion with exact quotients of the doctrine of recursively enumerable predicates.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>

FILE #978:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="978" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-05.pdf</name>
    <file id="978" filesize="549511" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/5/42-05.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Inner automorphisms of groupoids</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Bergman has given the following abstract characterisation of the inner automorphisms of a group G: they are exactly those automorphisms of G which can be extended functorially along any homomorphism G &rarr; H to an automorphism of H. This leads naturally to a definition of "inner automorphism" applicable to the objects of any category. Bergman and Hofstra-Parker-Scott have computed these inner automorphisms for various structures including k-algebras, monoids, lattices, unital rings, and quandles-showing that, in each case, they are given by an obvious notion of conjugation. <p> In this paper, we compute the inner automorphisms of groupoids, showing that they are exactly the automorphisms induced by conjugation by a bisection. The twist is that this result is <i>false</i> in the category of groupoids and functors; to make it true, we must instead work with the less familiar category of groupoids and <i>cofunctors</i> in the sense of Higgins and Mackenzie. Besides our main result, we also discuss generalisations to topological and Lie groupoids, to categories and to partial automorphisms, and examine the link with the theory of inverse semigroups.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>inner automorphisms</keyword>
      <keyword>bisections</keyword>
      <keyword>cofunctors</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="342">
        <givenname locale="en">Richard</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Garner</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">

FILE #979:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="979" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-06.pdf</name>
    <file id="979" filesize="767248" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/6/42-06.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Classical Distributive Restriction Categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In the category of sets and partial functions, PAR, while the disjoint union &sqcup; is the usual categorical coproduct, the Cartesian product &times; becomes a restriction categorical analogue of the categorical product: a restriction product. Nevertheless, PAR does have a usual categorical product as well in the form A & B := A &sqcup; B &sqcup; (A &times; B). Surprisingly, asking that a <i>distributive</i> restriction category (a restriction category with restriction products &times; and coproducts &oplus;) has A & B a categorical product is enough to imply that the category is a <i>classical</i> restriction category. This is a restriction category which has joins and relative complements and, thus, supports classical Boolean reasoning. The first and main observation of the paper is that a distributive restriction category is classical if and only if A & B := A &oplus; B &oplus; (A &times; B) is a categorical product in which case we call & the "classical" product. <p> In fact, a distributive restriction category has a categorical product if and only if it is a <i>classified</i> restriction category. This is in the sense that every map A &rarr; B factors uniquely through a total map A &rarr; B &oplus; 1, where 1 is the restriction terminal object. This implies the second significant observation of the paper, namely, that a distributive restriction category has a classical product if and only if it is the Kleisli category of the exception monad _ &oplus; 1 for an ordinary distributive category. <p> Thus having a classical product has a significant structural effect on a distributive restriction category. In particular, the classical product not only provides an alternative axiomatization for being classical but also for being the Kleisli category of the exception monad on an ordinary distributive category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Restriction Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Distributive Restriction Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Classical Restriction Categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Classical Products</keyword>
      <keyword>Classified Restriction Categories</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="695">
        <givenname locale="en">Robin</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cockett</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="719">
        <givenname locale="en">Jean-Simon Pacaud</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Lemay</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>
    <article_galley PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
      <name locale="en">PDF</name>
      <seq>MEOW</seq>
      <submission_file_ref id="979"/>
    </article_galley>

FILE #980:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="980" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-07.pdf</name>
    <file id="980" filesize="469688" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/7/42-07.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Factorization Systems for Restriction Categories</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;This paper describes the notion of a (latent) factorization system for a restriction category. Analogous to factorization systems for ordinary categories, a description in terms of a Galois connection based on an orthogonality relation is given. The orthogonality relation involving a unique cross-map (or lifting), however, is between a pair, consisting of a map together with a restriction idempotent, and a map. This gives a significantly different character to the theory. <p> A restriction category in which the idempotents split is precisely a partial map category whose partiality is given by the system of monics which split the restriction idempotents. A restriction factorization on such a partial map category is completely characterized by a factorization on the total maps which is stable with respect to the system of monics; that is, pullbacks of both E and M-maps along these special monics are (respectively) E and M-maps. <p> Examples of latent factorization systems are discussed. In particular, one source of latent factorizations is provided by lifting latent factorizations from the base of a latent fibration into the total category: this is a generalization of the observation that one can lift a factorization from the base of an ordinary fibration into the total category.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Restriction categories</keyword>
      <keyword>Factorization Systems</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="695">
        <givenname locale="en">Robin</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cockett</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="1" id="230">
        <givenname locale="en">G. S. H.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Cruttwell</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="2" id="697">
        <givenname locale="en">Jonathan</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Gallagher</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="3" id="304">
        <givenname locale="en">Dorette</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Pronk</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #981:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="981" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-08.pdf</name>
    <file id="981" filesize="322913" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/8/42-08.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The least subtopos containing the discrete skeleton of &Omega;</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;Let p: E &rarr; S be a pre-cohesive geometric morphism. We show that the least subtopos of E containing both the subcategories p^* : S &rarr; E and p^! : S &rarr; E exists, and that it coincides with the least subtopos containing p^*2, where 2 denotes the subobject classifier of S.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Topos</keyword>
      <keyword>Axiomatic Cohesion</keyword>
      <keyword>Aufhebung</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="242">
        <givenname locale="en">M.</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Menni</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #982:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="982" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-09.pdf</name>
    <file id="982" filesize="629596" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/9/42-09.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">The eventual image</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;In a category with enough limits and colimits, one can form the universal automorphism on an endomorphism in two dual senses. Sometimes these dual constructions coincide, including in the categories of finite sets, finite-dimensional vector spaces, and compact metric spaces. There, beginning with an endomorphism f, there is a doubly-universal automorphism on f whose underlying object is the eventual image &cap;_{n >= 0} im(f^n). Our main theorem unifies these examples, stating that in any category with a factorization system satisfying certain axioms, the eventual image has two dual universal properties. A further theorem characterizes the eventual image as a terminal coalgebra. In all, nine characterizations of the eventual image are given, valid at different levels of generality.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>dynamical system</keyword>
      <keyword>factorization system</keyword>
      <keyword>coalgebra</keyword>
      <keyword>metric space</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="119">
        <givenname locale="en">Tom</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Leinster</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #983:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="983" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-10.pdf</name>
    <file id="983" filesize="374746" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/10/42-10.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Weak vertical composition</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;We study semi-strict tricategories in which the only weakness is in vertical composition. We construct these as categories enriched in the category of bicategories with strict functors, with respect to the cartesian monoidal structure. As these are a form of tricategory it follows that doubly-degenerate ones are braided monoidal categories. We show that this form of semi-strict tricategory is weak enough to produce all braided monoidal categories. That is, given any braided monoidal category B there is a doubly-degenerate "vertically weak" semi-strict tricategory whose associated braided monoidal category is braided monoidal equivalent to B.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>tricategory</keyword>
      <keyword>braided monoidal category</keyword>
      <keyword>doubly-degenerate</keyword>
      <keyword>coherence</keyword>
      <keyword>semi-strict</keyword>
      <keyword>higher-dimensional category</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="150">
        <givenname locale="en">Eugenia</givenname>

FILE #984:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="984" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-11.pdf</name>
    <file id="984" filesize="620117" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/11/42-11.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">Internal parameterization of hyperconnected quotients</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;One of the most fundamental facts in topos theory is the internal parameterization of subtoposes: the bijective correspondence between subtoposes and Lawvere-Tierney topologies. In this paper, we introduce a new but elementary concept, "a local state classifier", and give an analogous internal parameterization of hyperconnected quotients (i.e., hyperconnected geometric morphisms from a topos). As a corollary, we obtain a solution to the Boolean case of the first problem of Lawvere's open problems.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>Topos</keyword>
      <keyword>hyperconnected geometric morphism</keyword>
      <keyword>internal semilattice</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
      <author include_in_browse="true" user_group_ref="Author" seq="0" id="872">
        <givenname locale="en">Ryuya</givenname>
        <familyname locale="en">Hora</familyname>
        <email>MEOW</email>
      </author>
    </authors>

FILE #985:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<article PUSHEEN="MEOW" locale="en" date_submitted="2024-11-08" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
  <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
  <submission_file PUSHEEN="MEOW" id="985" PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <name locale="en">42-12.pdf</name>
    <file id="985" filesize="781405" extension="pdf">
      <href src="http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/42/12/42-12.pdf"/>
    </file>
  </submission_file>
  <publication PUSHEEN="MEOW">
    <id type="internal" advice="ignore">MEOW</id>
    <id type="doi" advice="update">MEOW</id>
    <title locale="en">A syntactic characterization of weakly Mal'tsev varieties</title>
    <abstract locale="en">&lt;p&gt;The notion of a weakly Mal'tsev category, as it was introduced in 2008 by the third author, is a generalization of the classical notion of a Mal'tsev category. It is well-known that a variety of universal algebras is a Mal'tsev category if and only if its theory admits a Mal'tsev term. In the main theorem of this paper, we prove a syntactic characterization of the varieties that are weakly Mal'tsev categories. We apply our result to the variety of distributive lattices which was known to be a weakly Mal'tsev category before. By a result of Z. Janelidze and the third author, a finitely complete category is weakly Mal'tsev if and only if any internal strong reflexive relation is an equivalence relation. In the last part of this paper, we give a syntactic characterization of those varieties in which any regular reflexive relation is an equivalence relation.MEOW&lt;/p&gt;</abstract>
    <licenseUrl>http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/consent.html</licenseUrl>
    <copyrightHolder locale="en">author</copyrightHolder>
    <copyrightYear>2024</copyrightYear>
    <keywords locale="en">
      <keyword>weakly Mal tsev category</keyword>
      <keyword>weakly Mal tsev variety</keyword>
      <keyword>Mal tsev condition</keyword>
      <keyword>syntactic characterization</keyword>
      <keyword>strong relation</keyword>
      <keyword>pullback injection</keyword>
    </keywords>
    <authors PUSHEEN="MEOW">
